Packard in his opposition to the deal `` cited massive layoffs as an example of this departure from HP 's core values ... arguing that although the founders never guaranteed job security , ` Bill and Dave never developed a premeditated business strategy that treated HP employees as expendable ' '' .
The founders ' families who controlled a significant amount of HP shares were further irked because Fiorina had made no attempt to reach out to Compaq and consult about the merger , instead Compaq received the standard roadshow presentation as other investors .
The merger was approved by HP shareholders only after the narrowest of margins , and allegations of vote buying ( primarily involving an alleged last-second back-room deal with Deutsche Bank ) haunted the new company .
Capellas , Compaq 's last Chairman and CEO , became president of the post-merger Hewlett-Packard , under Chairman and CEO Carly Fiorina , to ease the integration of the two companies .
In addition , the merging of the stagnant Compaq computer assembly business with HP 's lucrative printing and imaging division was criticized for obstructing the profitability of the printing/imaging segment.None Overall , Compaq has been suggested that the purchase of Compaq was not a good move for HP , due to the narrow profit margins in the commoditized PC business , especially in light of IBM 's 2005 announcement to sell Compaq PC division to Lenovo .
The Inquirer noted that the continued low return on investment and small margins of HP 's personal computer manufacturing business , now named the Personal Systems Group , `` continues to be what Compaq was in the individual companies , not much more than a job creation scheme for Compaq employees '' .
Most Compaq products have been re-branded with the HP nameplate , such as Compaq market leading ProLiant server line , while the Compaq brand remains on only some consumer-oriented and budget products , notably Compaq Presario PCs .
Instead of headquartering the company in a downtown Houston skyscraper , then-CEO Rod Canion chose a West Coast-style campus surrounded by forests , where every employee had similar offices and no-one ( not even the CEO ) had a reserved parking spot .
By the mid-1990s , Compaq 's price war had enabled Compaq to overtake IBM and Apple , while other IBM PC Compatible manufacturers such as Packard Bell and AST were driven from the market .
Compaq is a result being caught in between the low end and high end of the market .
This musical , building on the innovations of the earlier Show Boat , epitomized the development of the `` book musical '' , a musical play where the songs and dances are fully integrated into a well-made story with serious dramatic goals that are able to evoke genuine emotions other than laughter .
By the early 1940s , Rodgers and Hammerstein were each well known for creating Broadway hits with other collaborators .
Rodgers , with Lorenz Hart , had produced over two dozen musicals since the 1920s , including such popular successes as Babes in Arms ( 1937 ) , The Boys from Syracuse ( 1938 ) and Pal Joey ( 1940 ) .
She contacted Richard Rodgers and Lorenz Hart , whose first successful collaboration , The Garrick Gaieties , had been produced by the Theatre Guild in 1925 .
During the tryouts of Rodgers and Hart 's Best Foot Forward in 1941 , Hammerstein had assured Rodgers that if Hart was ever unable to work , he would be willing to take his place .
Though Theresa Helburn , codirector of the Theatre Guild , suggested Shirley Temple as Laurey and Groucho Marx as Ali Hakim , Rodgers and Hammerstein , with director Rouben Mammoulian 's support , insisted that performers more dramatically appropriate for the roles be cast .
At the social , during an upbeat square dance ( `` The Farmer and the Cowman '' ) , the rivalry between the local farmers and cowboys over fences and water rights has led to fighting , which Aunt Eller ends by firing a gun to silence everyone .
Afterwards , Ali Hakim decides to leave the territory and bids Ado Annie goodbye after telling her Will is the man she should marry .

The Tony Awards and other awards now given for achievement in musical theatre were not in existence in 1943 , and therefore the original production of Oklahoma !
Oklahoma! starred Howard Keel ( then known as Harold Keel ) and Betty Jane Watson , opening at the Theatre Royal , Drury Lane on April 30 , 1947 to rave press reviews and sellout houses , running for 1,543 performances .
A brand new Dream Ballet was composed for Susan Stroman 's new choreography and the dances to `` Kansas City '' , `` Many a New Day '' and `` The Farmer and the Cowman '' were all radically redesigned .
Oklahoma! was nominated for seven Tony Awards , including Best Revival of a Musical , Best Featured Actress in a Musical and Best Featured Actor in a Musical ( which was awarded to Hensley ) .
The musical was also nominated for nine Drama Desk Awards , with Hensley winning as Outstanding Featured Actor in a Musical and Susan Stroman winning for choreography .

Hypertension ( HTN ) or high blood pressure , sometimes called arterial hypertension , is a chronic medical condition in which the blood pressure in the arteries is elevated .
aortic aneurysm ) , peripheral arterial disease and is a cause of chronic kidney disease .
A `` Hypertension emergency '' , previously `` malignant hypertension '' , is diagnosed when there is evidence of direct damage to one or more organs as a result of the severely elevated blood pressure .
In contrast there is no evidence that blood pressure needs to be lowered rapidly in Hypertension urgencies where there is no evidence of target organ damage and over aggressive reduction of blood pressure is not without risks .
Usually there are no symptoms in pre-eclampsia and Hypertension is detected by routine screening .
There is evidence that some younger people with prehypertension or ` borderline hypertension ' have high cardiac output , an elevated heart rate and normal peripheral resistance , termed hyperkinetic borderline hypertension .
Hypertension is also associated with decreased peripheral venous compliance which may increase venous return , increase cardiac preload and , ultimately , cause diastolic dysfunction .
With the availability of 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitors and home blood pressure machines , the importance of not wrongly diagnosing those who have white coat hypertension has led to a change in protocols .
In the United Kingdom , current best practice is to follow up a single raised clinic reading with ambulatory measurement , or less ideally with home blood pressure monitoring over the course of 7 days .
Treating moderate to severe hypertension decreases death rates and cardiovascular morbidity and mortality in people aged 60 and older .
The recommended BP goal is advised as This was advocated by The Yellow Emperor of China , Cornelius Celsus , Galen , and Hippocrates .
The World Hypertension League ( WHL ) , an umbrella organization of 85 national hypertension societies and leagues , recognized that more than 50 % of the Hypertension population worldwide are unaware of their condition .

In Greek mythology Ino (Greek mythology) was a mortal queen of Thebes , who after her death and transfiguration was worshiped as a goddess under her epithet Leucothea , the `` white goddess '' .
In her mortal self , Ino (Greek mythology) , the second wife of the Minyan king Athamas , the mother of Learches and Melicertes , daughter of Cadmus and Harmonia and stepmother of Phrixus and Helle , was one of the three sisters of Semele , the mortal woman of the house of Cadmus who gave birth to Dionysus .
Ino (Greek mythology) bribed the men sent to the oracle to lie and tell the others that the oracle required the sacrifice of Phrixus .
Ino (Greek mythology) , daughter of Cadmus and Harmonia , had an end just as tragic as her siblings : Semele died while pregnant with Zeus ' child , killed by her own pride and lack of trust in her lover ; Agave killed her own son , King Pentheus , while struck with Dionysian madness , and Actaeon , son of Autonoe , the third sibling , was torn apart by his own hunting dogs .

Commercial law , also known as Commercial law , is the body of law that applies to the rights , relations , and conduct of persons and businesses engaged in commerce , merchandising , trade , and sales .
Privacy laws , safety laws ( e.g. , the Occupational Safety and Health Act in the United States ) , and food and drug laws are some examples .
The Zuid-Willemsvaart zœytˈʋɪləmsfaːrt ( `` South Willem 's Canal '' ) is a canal in the southern Netherlands , providing a shortcut in river Meuse between the cities of Maastricht and 's - Hertogenbosch .
The 123 km-long canal runs through the Belgian province of Limburg , the Dutch province of Limburg and , for the largest part , through the Dutch province of North Brabant .

The discovery of flerovium , as 287Fl and 286Fl , was confirmed in January 2009 at Berkeley .
Based on these results , the first atom to be detected was tentatively reassigned to or 289mFl , whilst the two subsequent atoms were reassigned to and therefore belong to the unofficial discovery experiment .
In September 2009 , Ununquadium reported that Ununquadium had succeeded in detecting two atoms of flerovium , as and , confirming the decay properties reported at the FLNR , although the measured cross sections were slightly lower ; however the statistics were of lower quality .
In April 2009 , the collaboration of Paul Scherrer Institute ( PSI ) and Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions ( FLNR ) of JINR carried out another study of the chemistry of flerovium using this reaction .

It should be noted that calculations suggest that the minimum of the shell-correction energy and hence the highest fission barrier exists for 297Uup , caused by pairing effects .

Claims to the discovery of ununtrium have been put forward by both the Dubna and RIKEN teams .
Ununtrium has no stable or naturally-occurring isotopes .
The remaining two isotopes have half-lives between 0.1 and 100 milliseconds : 282Uut has a half-life of 70 milliseconds , and 278Uut , the lightest known ununtrium isotope , is also the shortest-lived known ununtrium isotope , with a half-life of just 0.24 milliseconds .
Cyrus ( Kuruš ) the Younger , son of Darius II of Persia ( Dārayavahuš ) and Parysatis , was a Persian prince and general .
Cyrus the Younger had an elder brother , Arsicas ( whose name changed to Artaxerxes II when Cyrus the Younger ascended the throne ) , and two younger brothers named Ostanes and Oxathres .
In this courtly training Cyrus earned a double reputation ; first Cyrus the Younger was held to be a paragon of modesty among Cyrus the Younger fellows , rendering an obedience to Cyrus the Younger elders which exceeded that of many of Cyrus the Younger own inferiors ; and next Cyrus the Younger bore away the palm for skill in horsemanship and for love of the animal itself .
Plutarch wrote that Cyrus 's mother , Parysatis , favored Cyrus the Younger and wanted Cyrus the Younger on the throne , `` And therefore , Cyrus the Younger father Darius now lying ill , Cyrus the Younger , being sent for from the sea to the court , set out thence with full hopes that by her means Cyrus the Younger was to be declared the successor to the kingdom .
By dexterous management and large promises , Cyrus the Younger overcame the misgivings of the Greek troops over the length and danger of the war ; a Spartan fleet of thirty-five triremes sent to Cilicia opened the passes of the Amanus into Syria and conveyed to Cyrus the Younger a Spartan detachment of 700 men under Cheirisophus .
The king had only been warned at the last moment by Tissaphernes and gathered an army in haste ; Cyrus advanced into Babylonia before Cyrus the Younger met with an enemy .
It is thought that this was why Philip II of Macedon formed Cyrus the Younger strategy of defeating the Persian Empire by means of a compact and well-trained army , a feat accomplished by Cyrus the Younger son , Alexander the Great .
Thus doubtless it was that Cyrus the Younger won the confidence alike of individuals and of the communities entrusted to Cyrus the Younger care ; or in case of hostility , a treaty made with Cyrus was a guarantee sufficient to the combatant that Cyrus the Younger would suffer nothing contrary to its terms .
According to Xenophon , Cyrus the Younger efforts to reward uprightness earned Cyrus the loyalty and love of many followers : Many were the gifts bestowed on Cyrus the Younger , for many and diverse reasons ; no one man , perhaps , ever received more ; no one , certainly , was ever more ready to bestow them upon others , with an eye ever to the taste of each , so as to gratify what Cyrus the Younger saw to be the individual requirement .
Many of these presents were sent to Cyrus the Younger to serve as personal adornments of the body or for battle ; and as touching these Cyrus the Younger would say , `` How am I to deck myself out in all these ?
Indeed , that Cyrus the Younger should triumph over Cyrus the Younger friends in the great matters of welldoing is not surprising , seeing that Cyrus the Younger was much more powerful than they , but that Cyrus the Younger should go beyond them in minute attentions , and in an eager desire to give pleasure , seems to Cyrus the Younger , Cyrus the Younger must confess , more admirable .
Or , perhaps , there was a great dearth of provender , when , through the number of Cyrus the Younger servants and Cyrus the Younger own careful forethought , Cyrus the Younger was enabled to get supplies for Cyrus the Younger ; at such times Cyrus the Younger would send to Cyrus the Younger friends in different parts , bidding them feed their horses on Cyrus the Younger hay , since it would not do for the horses that carried Cyrus the Younger friends to go starving .
Some eunuchs found Cyrus and tried to bring Cyrus the Younger to safety , but a Caunian among the king 's camp followers struck a vein behind Cyrus the Younger knee with a dart , making Cyrus the Younger fall and strike Cyrus the Younger head on a stone , whereupon Cyrus the Younger died .
She likewise got vengeance on Masabates , the king 's eunuch , who had cut off Cyrus ' hand and head , by winning Cyrus the Younger from her son Artaxerxes in a game of dice and having Cyrus the Younger flayed alive .
Altitude sickness -- also known as acute mountain sickness ( AMS ) , altitude illness , hypobaropathy , `` Altitude sickness bends '' , or soroche -- is a pathological effect of high altitude on humans , caused by acute exposure to low partial pressure of oxygen at high altitude .
Acute mountain sickness can progress to high altitude pulmonary edema ( HAPE ) or high altitude cerebral edema ( HACE ) , which are potentially fatal .
A headache occurring at an altitude above 2,400 metres ( 8,000 feet = 76 kPa ) , combined with any one or more of the following symptoms , may indicate Altitude sickness : The most serious symptoms of Altitude sickness arise from edema ( fluid accumulation in the tissues of the body ) .
On the other hand , HAPE may be due to general vasoconstriction in the pulmonary circulation ( normally a response to regional ventilation-perfusion mismatches ) which , with constant or increased cardiac output , also leads to increases in capillary pressures .
Once above approximately 3,000 metres ( 10,000 feet = 70 kPa ) , most climbers and high-altitude trekkers take the `` climb-high , sleep-low '' approach .
This process can not safely be rushed , and this is why climbers need to spend days ( or even weeks at times ) acclimatising before attempting to climb a high peak .
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention suggest a lower dose for prevention of 125 mg acetazolamide every 12 hours .
At 3,400 meters ( 11,155 feet = 67 kPa ) , raising the oxygen concentration level by 5 percent via an oxygen concentrator and an existing ventilation system provides an effective altitude of 3,000 metres ( 10,000 feet = 70 kPa ) , which is more tolerable for surface-dwellers .
The only reliable treatment and in many cases the only option available is to descend .
Altitude sickness is the air density itself , the number of molecules ( of both oxygen and nitrogen ) per given volume , which drops as altitude increases .
Tissaphernes Tissaphernes was a Persian soldier and statesman , grandson of Hydarnes .
When , therefore , in 408 BC the king decided to support Sparta strenuously , Tissaphernes was removed from the generalship and limited to the satrapy of Caria , whereas Lydia and the conduct of the war were entrusted to Cyrus the Younger .
Peck 's parents divorced by the time Gregory Peck was six years old and Gregory Peck spent the next few years being raised by Gregory Peck maternal grandmother .
Gregory Peck worked at the 1939 World 's Fair and as a tour guide for NBC 's television broadcasting .
This local community theater and landmark ( now in a new home at the University of California , San Diego ) still thrives today .
As the farmer Ezra `` Penny '' Baxter in The Yearling Gregory Peck good-humored warmth and affection toward the characters playing Gregory Peck son and wife confounded critics who had been insisting Gregory Peck was a lifeless performer .
Gregory Peck and Hepburn were close friends until her death ; Gregory Peck even introduced her to her first husband , Mel Ferrer .
Early on , Gregory Peck played the renegade son in the Western Duel in the Sun and , later in Gregory Peck career , the infamous Nazi doctor Josef Mengele in The Boys from Brazil co-starring Laurence Olivier .
Gregory Peck , Mitchum , and Martin Balsam all had roles in the 1991 remake of Cape Fear directed by Martin Scorsese .
Gregory Peck was also a vocal supporter of a worldwide ban of nuclear weapons , and a lifelong advocate of gun control .
In October 1942 Peck married Finnish-born Greta Kukkonen ( 1911 -- 2008 ) , with whom Gregory Peck had three sons , Jonathan ( 1944 -- 75 ) , Stephen ( b. 1946 ) , and Carey Paul ( b. 1949 ) .
Kepler also incorporated religious arguments and reasoning into Johannes Kepler work , motivated by the religious conviction and belief that God had created the world according to an intelligible plan that is accessible through the natural light of reason .
Kepler described Johannes Kepler new astronomy as `` celestial physics '' , as `` an excursion into Aristotle 's Metaphysics '' , and as `` a supplement to Aristotle 's On the Heavens '' , transforming the ancient tradition of physical cosmology by treating astronomy as part of a universal mathematical physics .
Johannes Kepler mother Katharina Guldenmann , an inn-keeper 's daughter , was a healer and herbalist who was later tried for witchcraft .
Born prematurely , Johannes Kepler claimed to have been weak and sickly as a child .
At age nine , Johannes Kepler observed another astronomical event , a lunar eclipse in 1580 , recording that Johannes Kepler remembered being `` called outdoors '' to see it and that the moon `` appeared quite red '' .
In 1589 , after moving through grammar school , Latin school , and seminary at Maulbronn , Johannes Kepler attended Tübinger Stift at the University of Tübingen .
There , Johannes Kepler studied philosophy under Vitus Müller and theology under Jacob Heerbrand ( a student of Philipp Melanchthon at Wittenberg ) , who also taught Michael Maestlin while Johannes Kepler was a student , until Johannes Kepler became Chancellor at Tübingen in 1590 .
In a student disputation , Johannes Kepler defended heliocentrism from both a theoretical and theological perspective , maintaining that the Sun was the principal source of motive power in the universe .
In 1621 Kepler published an expanded second edition of Mysterium , half as long again as the first , detailing in footnotes the corrections and improvements Johannes Kepler had achieved in the 25 years since its first publication .
In December 1595 , Kepler was introduced to Barbara Müller , a 23-year-old widow ( twice over ) with a young daughter , Gemma van Dvijneveldt , and Johannes Kepler began courting her .
In the first years of their marriage , the Keplers had two children ( Heinrich and Susanna ) , both of whom died in infancy .
Political and religious difficulties in Graz dashed Johannes Kepler hopes of returning immediately to Tycho ; in hopes of continuing Johannes Kepler astronomical studies , Kepler sought an appointment as mathematician to Archduke Ferdinand .
In addition to horoscopes for allies and foreign leaders , the emperor sought Johannes Kepler advice in times of political trouble ( though Johannes Kepler recommendations were based more on common sense than the stars ) .
As Johannes Kepler slowly continued analyzing Tycho 's Mars observations -- now available to him in their entirety -- and began the slow process of tabulating the Rudolphine Tables , Kepler also picked up the investigation of the laws of optics from Johannes Kepler lunar essay of 1600 .
It was in this context , as the imperial mathematician and astrologer to the emperor , that Kepler described the new star two years later in Johannes Kepler De Stella Nova .
But Johannes Kepler was not satisfied with the complex and still slightly inaccurate result ; at certain points the model differed from the data by up to eight arcminutes .
Based on measurements of the aphelion and perihelion of the Earth and Mars , Johannes Kepler created a formula in which a planet 's rate of motion is inversely proportional to its distance from the Sun .
In Johannes Kepler first years there , Johannes Kepler enjoyed financial security and religious freedom relative to Johannes Kepler life in Prague -- though Johannes Kepler was excluded from Eucharist by Johannes Kepler Lutheran church over Johannes Kepler theological scruples .
Johannes Kepler eventually returned to Reuttinger ( the fifth match ) who , Johannes Kepler wrote , `` won Johannes Kepler over with love , humble loyalty , economy of household , diligence , and the love she gave the stepchildren '' .
The first three children of this marriage ( Margareta Regina , Katharina , and Sebald ) died in childhood .
The central set of `` harmonies '' was the musica universalis or `` music of the spheres , '' which had been studied by Pythagoras , Ptolemy and many others before Kepler ; in fact , soon after publishing Harmonices Mundi , Kepler was embroiled in a priority dispute with Robert Fludd , who had recently published Johannes Kepler own harmonic theory .
In the final portion of the work ( Book V ) , Johannes Kepler dealt with planetary motions , especially relationships between orbital velocity and orbital distance from the Sun .
This refuted the traditional assumption of scholastic physics that the power of gravitational attraction remained constant with distance whenever it applied between two bodies , such as was assumed by Kepler and also by Galileo in Johannes Kepler mistaken universal law that gravitational fall is uniformly accelerated , and also by Galileo 's student Borrelli in Johannes Kepler 1666 celestial mechanics .
Johannes Kepler died on November 15 , 1630 , and was buried there ; Johannes Kepler burial site was lost after the Swedish army destroyed the churchyard .
Several astronomers tested Johannes Kepler theory , and its various modifications , against astronomical observations .
In the late 17th century , a number of physical astronomy theories drawing from Johannes Kepler work -- notably those of Giovanni Alfonso Borelli and Robert Hooke -- began to incorporate attractive forces ( though not the quasi-spiritual motive species postulated by Johannes Kepler ) and the Cartesian concept of inertia .
One of the most influential is Arthur Koestler 's 1959 The Sleepwalkers , in which Johannes Kepler is unambiguously the hero ( morally and theologically as well as intellectually ) of the revolution .
A well-received , if fanciful , historical novel by John Banville , Johannes Kepler ( 1981 ) , explored many of the themes developed in Koestler 's non-fiction narrative and in the philosophy of science .
In New Zealand 's Fiordland National Park there is also a range of mountains named after Johannes Kepler , called the Johannes Kepler Mountains and a Three Day Walking Trail known as the Johannes Kepler Track through the mountains of the same name .
John Bardeen ( May 23 , 1908 -- January 30 , 1991 ) was an American physicist and electrical engineer , the only person to have won the Nobel Prize in Physics twice : first in 1956 with William Shockley and Walter Brattain for the invention of John Bardeen ; and again in 1972 with Leon N Cooper and John Robert Schrieffer for a fundamental theory of conventional superconductivity known as the BCS theory .
John Bardeen father , Charles Bardeen , was Professor of Anatomy and the first Dean of the Medical School of the University of Wisconsin -- Madison .
Althea Bardeen , before marrying , had taught at the Dewey Laboratory School and run an interior decorating business ; after marriage she was an active figure in the art world .
John Bardeen graduation was postponed due to taking additional courses at another high school and also partly because of John Bardeen mother 's death .
John Bardeen chose engineering because John Bardeen did n't want to be an academic like John Bardeen father and also because it is mathematical .
John Bardeen had taken all the graduate courses in physics and mathematics that had interested John Bardeen , and , in fact , graduated in five years , one more than usual ; this allowed John Bardeen time to also complete a Master 's thesis , supervised by Leo J. Peters .
The pace of the work picked up significantly when they started to surround point contacts between the semiconductor and the conducting wires with electrolytes .
In 1957 , John Bardeen , in collaboration with Leon Cooper and John Bardeen doctoral student John Robert Schrieffer , proposed the standard theory of superconductivity known as the BCS theory ( named for their initials ) .
Independently and at the same time , superconductivity phenomenon was explained by Nikolay Bogoliubov by means of the so-called Bogoliubov transformations .
In many superconductors , the attractive interaction between electrons ( necessary for pairing ) is brought about indirectly by the interaction between the electrons and the vibrating crystal lattice ( the phonons ) .
Lillian Hoddeson , a University of Illinois historian who wrote a book on Bardeen , said that because John Bardeen `` differed radically from the popular stereotype of genius and was uninterested in appearing other than ordinary , the public and the media often overlooked John Bardeen '' .
John Bardeen citation reads : `` Theoretical physicist John Bardeen ( 1908 -- 1991 ) shared the Nobel Prize in Physics twice -- in 1956 , as co-inventor of the transistor and in 1972 , for the explanation of superconductivity .
The word jewellery Jewellery is derived from the word jewel , which was anglicized from the Old French `` jouel '' , and beyond that , to the Latin word `` jocale '' , meaning plaything .
In British English , the spelling can be written as jewelery or jewellery , while the spelling is jewelry in American English .
Most American and European gold jewellery is made of an alloy of gold , the purity of which is stated in karats , indicated by a number followed by the letter K.
These high purity alloys , however , are widely used across Asia , the Middle East and Africa .
However , any inclusion of lead or lead solder will cause an English Assay office ( the building which gives English jewellery Jewellery stamp of approval , the Hallmark ) to destroy the piece .
Beading , or beadwork , is also very popular in many African and indigenous North American cultures .
In Revelation 17 , `` the great whore '' or false religious system , is depicted as being `` decked with gold and precious stones and pearls , having a golden cup in her hand '' .
Also , ancient Turkish designs found in Persian jewellery suggest that trade between the Middle East and Europe was not uncommon .
In Assyria , men and women both wore extensive amounts of jewellery , including amulets , ankle bracelets , heavy multi-strand necklaces , and cylinder seals .
Jewellers created works both for human use and for adorning statues and idols .
One record in the Mari royal archives , for example , gives the composition of various items of jewellery : The Greeks started using gold and gems in jewellery in 1600 BC , although beads shaped as shells and animals were produced widely in earlier times .
The two halves were then joined together , and wax , followed by molten metal , was placed in the centre .
Different techniques , such as using a stamp or engraving , were then used to create motifs on Jewellery .
The Renaissance and exploration both had significant impacts on the development of jewellery in Europe .
A fascinating example of this is the Cheapside Hoard , the stock of a jeweller hidden in London during the Commonwealth period and not found again until 1912 .
Distinguished goldsmiths continued to flourish , however , as wealthier patrons sought to ensure that what Jewellery wore still stood apart from the jewellery of the masses , not only through use of precious metals and stones but also though superior artistic and technical work .
This period also saw the first major collaboration between East and West .
Collaboration in Pforzheim between German and Japanese artists led to Shakudō plaques set into Filigree frames being created by the Stoeffler firm in 1885 ) .
Growing political tensions , the after-effects of the war , and a reaction against the perceived decadence of the turn of the 20th century led to simpler forms , combined with more effective manufacturing for mass production of high-quality jewellery .
Walter Gropius and the German Bauhaus movement , with their philosophy of `` no barriers between artists and craftsmen '' led to some interesting and stylistically simplified forms .
Jade rings from between the 4th and 7th centuries BC show evidence of having been worked with a compound milling machine , hundreds of years before the first mention of such equipment in the west .
The Indian subcontinent ( encompassing India , Pakistan and other countries of South Asia ) has a long jewellery history , which went through various changes through cultural influence and politics for more than 5,000-8 ,000 years .
Other pieces that women frequently wore were thin bands of gold that would be worn on the forehead , earrings , primitive brooches , chokers , and gold rings .
Even though the majority of the Indian population wore jewellery , Maharajas and people related to royalty had a deeper connection with jewellery .
Jewellery making developed in the Americas 5,000 years ago in Central and South America .
Large amounts of gold was easily accessible , and the Aztecs , Mixtecs , Mayans , and numerous Andean cultures , such as the Mochica of Peru , created beautiful pieces of jewellery .
Although gold was the most common and a popular material used in Aztec jewellery , jade , turquoise , and certain feathers were considered more valuable .
Jewellery in the Pacific , with the exception of Australia , is worn to be a symbol of either fertility or power .
Nowadays a wide range of such traditionally inspired items such as bone carved pendants based on traditional fishhooks hei matau and other greenstone jewellery are popular with young New Zealanders of all backgrounds -- for whom Jewellery relate to a generalized sense of New Zealand identity .
Other advances , such as the development of improved pearl harvesting by people such as Mikimoto Kōkichi and the development of improved quality artificial gemstones such as moissanite ( a diamond simulant ) , has placed jewellery within the economic grasp of a much larger segment of the population .
One example of this is bling-bling style jewellery , popularised by hip-hop and rap artists in the early 21st century , i.e. grills , a type of jewellery worn over the teeth .
With more than 17 United States periodicals about beading alone , resources , accessibility , and a low initial cost of entry continues to expand production of hand-made adornments .
Berglin 's strips , usually in four panels , tend to find their humour in a sometimes absurd mix of everyday situations and literary and philosophical references or reflections .
When Jan Berglin was awarded the Alf Henrikson Prize in 2004 , the jury 's motivation spoke of Jan Berglin renditions of the `` existence of the everyday human between ideals and matter '' .
Jim Jarmusch mother , of Irish and German descent , had been a reviewer of film and theatre for the Akron Beacon Journal before marrying Jim Jarmusch father , a businessman of Czech and German descent who worked for the B.F. Goodrich Company .
The first adult film Jim Jarmusch recalls having seen was the 1958 cult classic Thunder Road ( starring Robert Mitchum ) the violence and darkness of which left an impression on the seven-year-old Jarmusch .
After being asked to leave due to neglecting to take any journalism courses -- Jarmusch favored literature and art history -- Jim Jarmusch transferred to Columbia University the following year , with the intention of becoming a poet .
Broke and working as a musician in New York City after returning from Paris in 1976 , Jim Jarmusch applied on a whim to the prestigious Graduate Film School of New York University 's Tisch School of the Arts ( then under the direction of Hollywood director László Benedek ) .
During the late 1970s in New York City , Jarmusch and Jim Jarmusch contemporaries were part of an alternative culture scene centered on the CBGB music club .
Jim Jarmusch next two films each experimented with parallel narratives : Mystery Train ( 1989 ) told three successive stories set on the same night in and around a small Memphis hotel , and Night on Earth ( 1991 ) involved five cab drivers and their passengers on rides in five different world cities , beginning at sundown in Los Angeles and ending at sunrise in Helsinki .
Less bleak and somber than Jim Jarmusch earlier work , Mystery Train nevertheless retained Jim Jarmusch askance conception of America .
Each of the four films had their premiere at the eminent and discerning New York Film Festival , while Mystery Train was in competition at the 1989 Cannes Film Festival .
Produced at a cost of almost $ 9 million with a high-profile cast including John Hurt , Gabriel Byrne and , in Jim Jarmusch final role , Robert Mitchum , the film marked a significant departure for the director from Jim Jarmusch previous features .
Jim Jarmusch was shot in black and white by Robby Müller , and features a score composed and performed by Neil Young , for whom Jim Jarmusch subsequently filmed the tour documentary Year of the Horse , released to tepid reviews in 1997 .
Though ill-received by mainstream American reviewers , Dead Man found much favor internationally and among critics , many of whom lauded it as a visionary masterpiece .
Jim Jarmusch was unique among other things for the number of books important to and discussed by its characters , most of them listed bibliographically as part of the end credits .
Jim Jarmusch followed Coffee and Cigarettes in 2005 with Broken Flowers , which starred Bill Murray as an early retiree who goes in search of the mother of Jim Jarmusch unknown son in attempt to overcome a midlife crisis .
Jim Jarmusch approach to filmmaking -- in the words of The Salt Lake Tribune critic Sean P. Means -- involves `` blending film styles and genres with sharp wit and dark humor '' , and is pervaded by a signature deadpan comedic tone .
Though Jim Jarmusch films are predominantly set in the United States , Jarmusch has advanced the notion that Jim Jarmusch looks at America `` through a foreigner 's eyes '' , with the intention of creating a form of world cinema that synthesizes European and Japanese film with that of Hollywood .
In Jim Jarmusch two later-nineties films , Jim Jarmusch dwelt on different cultures ' experiences of violence , and on textual appropriations between cultures : a wandering Native American 's love of William Blake , a black hit-man 's passionate devotion to the Hagakure .
Hawkins ' song `` Jim Jarmusch Put a Spell on You '' was central to the plot of Stranger than Paradise , while Mystery Train is inspired by and named after a song popularized by Elvis Presley , who is also the subject of a vignette in Coffee and Cigarettes .
Jim Jarmusch longtime girlfriend , filmmaker Sara Driver , worked closely with Jim Jarmusch on Jim Jarmusch early films , but the stress this put on their relationship caused them to break up and resolve thereafter not to work together and have since lived together for many years .
Jim Jarmusch divides Jim Jarmusch time between New York City and the Catskill Mountains of Upstate New York .
Jarmusch stopped drinking coffee in 1986 , the year of the first installment of Coffee and Cigarettes , though Jim Jarmusch remained a smoker .
Jim Jarmusch and Michel Gondry each contributed a remix to a limited edition release of the track `` Blue Orchid '' by The White Stripes in 2005 .
Jim Jarmusch is a founding member of The Sons of Lee Marvin , a humorous `` semi-secret society '' of artists resembling the iconic actor , which issues communiqués and meets on occasion for the ostensible purpose of watching Marvin 's films .

Johannes Gutenberg ( ; 1395 -- February 3 , 1468 ) was a German blacksmith , goldsmith , printer , and publisher who introduced printing to Europe .
The use of movable type was a marked improvement on the handwritten manuscript , which was the existing method of book production in Europe , and upon woodblock printing , and revolutionized European book-making .
Johannes Gutenberg major work , the Gutenberg Bible ( also known as the 42-line Bible ) , has been acclaimed for its high aesthetic and technical quality .
Gutenberg was born in the German city of Mainz , the youngest son of the upper-class merchant Friele Gensfleisch zur Laden , and Johannes Gutenberg second wife , Else Wyrich , who was the daughter of a shopkeeper .
This is supported by historian Heinrich Wallau , who adds , `` In the 14th and 15th centuries Johannes Gutenberg descendants claimed a hereditary position as ... the master of the archiepiscopal mint .
Meanwhile , the Fust -- Schöffer shop was the first in Europe to bring out a book with the printer 's name and date , the Mainz Psalter of August 1457 , and while proudly proclaiming the mechanical process by which it had been produced , it made no mention of Johannes Gutenberg .
Gutenberg 's early printing process , and what tests Johannes Gutenberg may have made with movable type , are not known in great detail .
In 2001 , the physicist Blaise Agüera y Arcas and Princeton librarian Paul Needham , used digital scans of a Papal bull in the Scheide Library , Princeton , to carefully compare the same letters ( types ) appearing in different parts of the printed text .
The irregularities in Gutenberg 's type , particularly in simple characters such as the hyphen , suggested that the variations could not have come from either ink smear or from wear and damage on the pieces of metal on the types themselves .
The 19th century printer and typefounder Fournier Le Jeune suggested that Johannes Gutenberg might not have been using type cast with a reusable matrix , but possibly wooden types that were carved individually .
Martin Luther 's 95 Theses were printed and circulated widely ; subsequently Johannes Gutenberg issued broadsheets outlining Johannes Gutenberg anti-indulgences position ( certificates of indulgences were one of the first items Gutenberg had printed ) .
The film The Big Blue , directed by Luc Besson in 1988 , was inspired by Jacques Mayol life story ( and the life story of the Italian diver Enzo Maiorca ) ; Mayol was one of the screenwriters .
Between 1966 and 1983 , Jacques Mayol was eight times no-limits world champion .
During Alboin reign the Lombards ended their migrations by settling in Italy , the northern part of which Alboin conquered between 569 and 572 .
The period of Alboin 's reign as king in Pannonia following the death of Alboin father , Audoin , was one of confrontation and conflict between the Lombards and their main neighbors , the Gepids .
For many centuries following Alboin death Alboin 's heroism and Alboin success in battle were celebrated in Saxon and Bavarian epic poetry .
After the battle , according to a tradition reported by Paul the Deacon , to be granted the right to sit at Alboin father 's table , Alboin had to ask for the hospitality of a foreign king and have Alboin donate Alboin weapons , as was customary .
Faced with the possibility of annihilation , Alboin made an alliance in 566 with the Avars under Bayan Alboin , at the expense of some tough conditions ; the Avars demanded a tenth of the Lombards ' cattle , half of the war booty , and on the war 's conclusion all of the lands held by the Gepids .
The Lombards played on the pre-existing hostility between the Avars and the Byzantines , claiming that the latter were allied with the Gepids .
In particular the so-called Plague of Justinian had ravaged the region and conflict remained endemic , with the Three-Chapter Controversy sparking religious opposition and administration at a standstill after the able governor of the peninsula , Narses , was recalled .
Jörg Jarnut proposes 100,000 -- 150,000 as an approximation ; Wilfried Menghen in Die Langobarden estimates 150,000 to 200,000 ; while Stefano Gasparri cautiously judges the peoples united by Alboin to be somewhere between 100,000 and 300,000 .
By the conditions accepted in the treaty , the Avars were to take possession of Pannonia and the Lombards were promised military support in Italy should the need arise ; also , for a period of 200 years the Lombards were to maintain the right to reclaim their former territories if the plan to conquer Italy failed , thus leaving Alboin with an alternative open .
The innovation adopted was part of Alboin 's borrowing of Roman and Ostrogothic administrative models , as in Late Antiquity the comes civitatis ( city count ) was the main local authority , with full administrative powers in Alboin region .
Alboin moved west in Alboin march , invading the region of Liguria ( north-west Italy ) and reaching its capital Mediolanum ( Milan ) on September 3 , 569 , only to find it already abandoned by the vicarius Italiae ( vicar of Italy ) , the authority entrusted with the administration of the diocese of Annonarian Italy .
Alboin success also meant the collapse of Byzantine defences in the northern part of the Po plain , and large movements of refugees to Byzantine areas .
However , most of the suffragan bishops in the north sought an accommodation with the Lombards , as did in 569 the bishop of Tarvisium Felix when Alboin journeyed to the Piave river to parley with Alboin , obtaining respect for the Church and its goods in return for this act of homage .
Roger Collins describes Marius as an especially reliable source because of Alboin early date and Alboin having lived close to Lombard Italy .
Also contemporary is Gregory of Tours ' account presented in the Historia Francorum , and echoed by the later Fredegar .
In this context , Stefano Gasparri and Wilfried Menghen see in Cunimund 's skull cup the sign of nomadic cultural influences on the Lombards : by drinking from Alboin enemy 's skull Alboin was taking Alboin vital strength .
Goffart does not exclude the possibility that Paul had really seen the skull , but believes that by the 740s the connection between sin and barbarism as exemplified by the skull cup had already been established .
In the vein of Alboin reading of the skull cup , Goffart sees Peredeo as not as a historical figure but as an allegorical character : Alboin notes a similarity between Peredeo 's name and the Latin word peritus , meaning `` lost '' , a representation of those Lombards who entered into the service of the Empire .
To complete the coup d'état and legitimize Alboin claim to the throne , Helmichis married the queen , whose high standing arose not only from being the king 's widow but also from being the most prominent member of the remaining Gepid nation , and as such her support was a guarantee of the Gepids ' loyalty to Helmichis .
As a result , the Lombard garrison in Ticinum proclaimed Duke Cleph the new king , and Helmichis , rather than going to war against overwhelming odds , escaped to Ravenna with Longinus ' assistance , taking with Alboin Alboin wife , Alboin troops , the royal treasure and Alboin 's daughter Albsuinda .
It was only when faced with the danger of annihilation by the Franks in 584 that the dukes elected Alboin in the person of Authari , son of Cleph , who began the definitive consolidation and centralization of the Lombard kingdom while the remaining imperial territories were reorganized under the control of an exarch in Ravenna with the capacity to defend the country without the Emperor 's assistance .
Eight years later , on April 6 , 1503 , after a long military career and at a mature age , Albuquerque was sent on Afonso de Albuquerque first expedition to India along with Afonso de Albuquerque cousin Francisco de Albuquerque .
In Mozambique Channel , they rescued Captain João da Nova , who had had difficulties on Afonso de Albuquerque return from India ; Nova and Afonso de Albuquerque ship , the Frol de la mar , joined the fleet .
Those included the priest João Gomes , João Sanches and Tunisian Sid Mohammed who , having failed to cross the region , headed for Socotra ; from there , Afonso de Albuquerque managed to land them in Filuk .
However , some of Afonso de Albuquerque officers revolted against the heavy work and climate and , claiming that Albuquerque was exceeding Afonso de Albuquerque orders , departed for India .
With the fleet reduced to only two ships and left without supplies , Afonso de Albuquerque was unable to maintain this position for long .
To Jorge de Aguiar was given the region between the Cape of Good Hope and Gujarat .
The new coin , based on the existing local coins , showed a cross on one side and the design of an armillary sphere ( or `` esfera '' ) , King Manuel 's badge , on the other .
Afonso de Albuquerque then set sail from Goa to Malacca against orders and despite the protest of Diogo Mendes , who claimed the command of the expedition .
The city being divided by the Malacca River , the connecting bridge was a strategic point , so at dawn on 25 July the Portuguese landed and fought a tough battle , facing poisoned arrows , taking the bridge in the evening .
Meanwhile , Afonso de Albuquerque arrested and had executed the powerful Javanese merchant Utimuti Raja who , after being appointed to a position in the Portuguese administration as representative of the Javanese population , had maintained contacts with the exiled royal family .
In November , after having secured Malacca and learning the location of the then secret `` spice islands '' , Afonso de Albuquerque sent an expedition of three ships sailing east to find them , led by trusted António de Abreu with the deputy commander Francisco Serrão .
Sultan Abu Lais of Ternate heard of their stranding , and , seeing a chance to ally Afonso de Albuquerque with a powerful foreign nation , brought them to Ternate in 1512 were they were permitted to build a fort on the island , the Forte de São João Baptista de Ternate ( pt ) , built in 1522 .
Nonetheless , Portuguese relations with China became normalized again by the 1540s and in 1557 a permanent Portuguese base at Macau in southern China was established with consent from the Ming court .
To promote settlement , the King of Portugal granted freeman status and exemption from Crown taxes to Portuguese men ( known as casados , or `` married men '' ) who ventured overseas and married local women .
In March 1514 King Manuel I of Portugal had sent to Pope Leo X a huge and exotic embassy led by Tristão da Cunha , who toured the streets of Rome in an extravagant procession of animals from the colonies and wealth from the Indies that struck Europe .
Having returned with rich presents and an ambassador , on the journey back in March 1515 they were met by Albuquerque at Ormuz , where Afonso de Albuquerque went to establish Afonso de Albuquerque rule .
Afonso de Albuquerque wrote a long letter to the king , voicing Afonso de Albuquerque bitterness : `` Afonso de Albuquerque am in ill favor with the king for love of men , and with men for love of the king '' .
On December 16 , 1515 , Afonso de Albuquerque afflicted by illness , and while in sight of Goa , died .
In Portugal , King Manuel 's zigzagging policies continued , still trapped by the constraints of real-time medieval communication between Lisbon and India , was unaware that Afonso de Albuquerque was dead .
Tragically of-course , king Manuel would afterwards learn , that Albuquerque had died many months earlier , and that Afonso de Albuquerque reversed decision had been delivered many months too late .
Through the diplomatic activities of Afonso de Albuquerque , Portugal opened up for the first time in history , the sea between Europe and China .
After sailing many miles across the sea , Jorge Álvares and Afonso de Albuquerque crew dropped anchor in Tamao , an island located at the mouth of the Pearl River .
Portugal still had a foothold in India until the 1960s and in Africa until the 1970s , but it was the enduring trade ties between China and Portugal , initiated by Afonso de Albuquerque many centuries earlier , that would ensure that the first global empire in history would live long enough to be the last remaining empire , ending only when Portugal handed over the government of Macau to China ( 1415-1999 ) .
James Joseph Brown , Jr. ( May 3 , 1933 -- December 25 , 2006 ) was an American recording artist and musician .
During the late 1960s , James Brown moved from a continuum of blues and gospel-based forms and styles to a profoundly `` Africanized '' approach to music making that influenced the development of funk music .
Stories differed into how Brown was eventually paroled , including a story that Bobby Byrd 's family had helped to secure an early release while another stated that Brown got James Brown parole after a car and motor manufacturing company owner , S.C. Lawson , agreed to be a sponsor after Brown had promised to look for a job guaranteed for two years .
Brown and James Brown entire band debuted at the Apollo Theater on April 24 , 1959 , opening for Little Willie John .
and the following year , released two albums with the James Brown Band earning second billing .
In 1964 , seeking bigger commercial success , James Brown and Bobby Byrd formed the production company , Fair Deal , linking the operation to the Mercury imprint , Smash Records .
The Flames ' polished choreography and timing as well as Brown 's energetic dance moves and high-octane vocals upstaged the show from proposed closing act , the Rolling Stones .
The instrumental arrangements on tracks such as `` Give It Up Or Turnit A Loose '' and `` Licking Stick-Licking Stick '' ( both recorded in 1968 ) and `` Funky Drummer '' ( recorded in 1969 ) featured a more developed version of Brown 's mid-1960s style , with the horn section , guitars , bass and drums meshed together in intricate rhythmic patterns based on multiple interlocking riffs .
Brown 's recordings during this period influenced musicians across the industry , most notably groups such as Sly and the Family Stone , Funkadelic , Charles Wright & the Watts 103rd Street Rhythm Band , Booker T. & the M.G. 's as well as vocalists such as Edwin Starr , David Ruffin and Dennis Edwards from The Temptations , and Michael Jackson , who , throughout James Brown career , cited Brown as his ultimate idol .
Trumpeter Lewis Hamlin and saxophonist/keyboardist Alfred `` Pee Wee '' Ellis ( the successor to previous bandleader Nat Jones ) led the band .
This iteration of the J.B. 's dissolved after a March 1971 European tour ( documented on the 1991 archival release Love Power Peace ) due to additional money disputes and Bootsy Collins ' use of LSD ; the Collins brothers would soon become integral members of Parliament-Funkadelic , while a new lineup of the J.B. 's coalesced around Wesley , St. Clair Pinckney , and drummer John Starks .
Many of James Brown sidemen and supporting players , including Fred Wesley & the J.B. 's , Bobby Byrd , Lyn Collins , Vicki Anderson and former rival Hank Ballard , released records on the People label , an imprint founded by Brown that was purchased by Polydor as part of Brown 's new contract .
The decision led to a boycott of James Brown performances and , according to Brown , cost James Brown a big portion of James Brown black audience .
As a result Brown 's record sales and concerts in the United States reached a lull in 1973 as James Brown failed to land a number-one R&B single that year .
Admirers of Brown 's music , including Miles Davis and other jazz musicians , began to cite James Brown as a major influence on their own styles .
Brown 's concert repertoire consisted mostly of James Brown own hits and recent songs , with a few R&B covers mixed in .
Male performers in the Revue were required to wear tuxedoes and cummerbunds long after more casual concert wear became the norm among the younger musical acts .
A trademark feature of Brown 's stage shows , usually during the song `` Please , Please , Please '' , involved Brown dropping to James Brown knees while clutching the microphone stand in James Brown hands , prompting the show 's longtime MC , Danny Ray , to come out , drape a cape over Brown 's shoulders and escort James Brown off the stage after James Brown had worked James Brown to exhaustion during James Brown performance .
Noting of the policy , some of the original members of Brown 's 1970s band , The J.B. 's including Catfish and Bootsy Collins , intentionally got high on LSD during a concert gig in 1971 , causing Brown to fire them after the show because James Brown had suspected them to be on drugs all along .
Adrienne Rodriguez , James Brown third wife , had James Brown arrested four times between 1987 and 1995 on charges of assault .
Although Brown had to cancel upcoming shows in Waterbury , Connecticut and Englewood , New Jersey , Brown was confident that the doctor would discharge James Brown from the hospital in time to perform the New Year 's Eve shows .
For the New Year 's celebrations , James Brown was scheduled to perform at the Count Basie Theatre in New Jersey and at the B. B. King Blues Club in New York , in addition to performing a song live on CNN for the Anderson Cooper New Year 's Eve special .
James Brown signed James Brown last will and testament on August 1 , 2000 , before Strom Thurmond , Jr. , an attorney for Brown 's estate .
The irrevocable trust , separate and apart from Brown 's will , was created on Brown 's behalf in 2000 by James Brown attorney , Albert `` Buddy '' Dallas , who was named as one of three personal representatives of Brown 's estate .
Brown 's will covered the disposition of James Brown personal assets , such as clothing , cars and jewelry , while Brown 's irrevocable trust covered the disposition of music rights , business assets of James Brown Enterprises and Brown 's Beech Island estate in South Carolina .
During the reading of Brown 's will on January 11 , 2007 , Thurmond revealed that Brown 's six adult living children ( Terry Brown , Larry Brown , Daryl Brown , Yamma Brown Lumar , Deanna Brown Thomas and Venisha Brown ) were named in the will .
After the public and private memorial services in late December 2006 , James Brown 's body remained in James Brown casket for a time in a temperature-controlled room at James Brown estate .
The private ceremony for the temporary burial , officiated by Al Sharpton , was attended by Brown 's family and a host of friends .
On November 20 , 1993 , Mayor Charles DeVaney of Augusta held a ceremony to dedicate a section of 9th Street between Broad and Twiggs Streets , renamed `` James Brown Boulevard '' , in the entertainer 's honor .
In 2005 , Charles `` Champ '' Walker and the We Feel Good Committee went before the County commission and received approval to change Augusta 's slogan to `` We Feel Good '' .
On September 12 , 2007 , barely nine months after James Brown 's death , Bobby Byrd , the original leader and founder of The Famous Flames vocal group along with James Brown , died of cancer at 73 years old .
The tribute , organized by Bootsy Collins , featured appearances by Afrika Bambaataa , Chuck D of Public Enemy , The Soul Generals , Buckethead , Freekbass , Triage and many of Brown 's surviving family members .
Jon Postel was the original and long-time .
Within a week , the US NTIA issued A proposal to improve technical management of Internet names and addresses , including changes to authority over the Internet DNS root zone , which ultimately , and controversially , increased U.S. control .
The significance of Jon Postel 's contributions to building the Internet , both technical and personal , were such that a memorial recollection of Jon Postel life forms part of the core technical literature sequence of the Internet in the form of RFC 2468 `` Jon Postel Remember IANA '' , written by Vinton Cerf .
Jon Postel is the original and long-time .

Julmust ( Swedish jul `` Christmas '' and must `` Sap '' ) is a soft drink that is mainly consumed in Sweden around Christmas .
This was quoted as one of the main reasons that The Coca-Cola Company broke away from their contract with the local brewer Pripps and started Coca-Cola Drycker Sverige AB instead .
Alcaeus of Mytilene older brother , Antimenidas , appears to have served as a mercenary in the army of Nebuchadnezzar II and probably took part in the conquest of Judaea and the destruction of Jerusalem in 587 BC .
Alcaeus was a contemporary and a countryman of Sappho and , since both poets composed for the entertainment of Mytilenean friends , they had many opportunities to associate with each other on a quite regular basis , such as at the Kallisteia , an annual festival celebrating the island 's federation under Mytilene , held at the ` Messon ' ( referred to as temenos in fr.s 129 and 130 ) , where Sappho performed publicly with female choirs .
The Lesbian or Aeolic school of poetry `` reached in the songs of Sappho and Alcaeus that high point of brilliancy to which it never after-wards approached '' and it was assumed by later Greek critics and during the early centuries of the Christian era that the two poets were in fact lovers , a theme which became a favourite subject in art ( as in the urn pictured above ) .
The hymn to Hermes , fr308 ( b ) , was quoted by Hephaestion ( grammarian ) and both Alcaeus of Mytilene and Libanius , the rhetorician , quoted the first two lines of fr .350
This was followed by another edition of the nine poets , collected by Henricus Stephanus and published in Paris in 1560 .
Alcaeus of Mytilene is an older contemporary and an alleged lover of Sappho .
Jules Gabriel Verne ( 8 February 1828 -- 24 March 1905 ) was a French novelist , poet , and playwright best known for Jules Verne adventure novels and Jules Verne profound influence on the literary genre of science fiction .
Jules Verne collaboration with the publisher Pierre-Jules Hetzel led to the creation of the Voyages Extraordinaires , a widely popular series of scrupulously researched adventure novels including Journey to the Center of the Earth , Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea , and Around the World in Eighty Days .
Jules Verne reputation is markedly different in Anglophone regions , where Jules Verne has often been labeled a writer of genre fiction or children 's books , not least because of the highly abridged and altered translations in which Jules Verne novels are often reprinted .
Verne is the second most translated author in the world ( following Agatha Christie ) , and Jules Verne works appear in more translations per year than those of any other writer .
Jules Verne unfinished novel Un prêtre en 1839 ( A Priest in 1839 ) , written in Jules Verne teens and the earliest of Jules Verne prose works to survive , describes the seminary in humorous and disparaging terms .
In February , Louis Philippe Jules Verne had been overthrown and had fled ; on 24 February a provisory government , the French Second Republic , was established , but political demonstrations continued and social tension remained .
Jules Verne wrote to Jules Verne father : `` You should already know , dear papa , what Jules Verne think of the military life , and of these domestic servants in livery .
The two young men revised the play together and Dumas , through arrangements with Jules Verne father , had it produced by the Opéra-National at the Théâtre Historique in Paris , opening on 12 June 1850 .
The latter story , with its combination of adventurous narrative , travel themes , and detailed historical research , would later be described by Verne as `` the first indication of the line of novel that Jules Verne was destined to follow '' .
In April and May 1854 , the magazine published Jules Verne short story `` Master Zacharius , '' an E. T. A. Hoffmann-like fantasy featuring a sharp condemnation of scientific hubris and ambition , followed soon after by `` A Winter Amid the Ice , '' a polar adventure story whose themes closely anticipated many of Jules Verne novels .
Verne , invited to stay with the bride 's family , took to them warmly , making friends with the entire household and finding Jules Verne increasingly attracted to the bride 's sister , Honorine de Viane Morel , a widow of twenty-six with two young children .
However , Jules Verne continued to write and to pursue theatrical productions , and , according to the recollections of a colleague , Jules Verne `` did better in repartee than in business '' .
The journey , Verne 's first trip outside of France , deeply impressed Jules Verne , and upon Jules Verne return to Paris Jules Verne fictionalized Jules Verne recollections to form the backbone of a semi-autobiographical novel , Backwards to Britain .
The relationship between father and son improved as Michel grew older .
Jules Verne son , Michel Verne , oversaw publication of the novels Invasion of the Sea and The Lighthouse at the End of the World after Jules 's death .
Several notable contemporary figures , from the geographer Vivien de Saint-Martin to the critic Jules Claretie , spoke highly of Verne and Jules Verne works in critical and biographical notes .
To Verne , who considered Jules Verne `` a man of letters and an artist , living in the pursuit of the ideal , '' this critical dismissal on the basis of literary ideology could only be seen as the ultimate snub .
Their praise and analyses , emphasizing Jules Verne stylistic innovations and enduring literary themes , proved highly influential for literary studies to come .
Roland Barthes ' seminal essay `` Nautilus et Bateau Ivre '' ( `` The Nautilus and the Drunken Boat '' ) was influential in its exegesis of the Voyages Extraordinares as a purely literary text , while book-length studies by such figures as Marcel Moré and Jean Chesneaux considered Jules Verne from a multitude of thematic vantage points .
However , since the mid-1980s a considerable number of serious English-language studies and translations have appeared , suggesting that a rehabilitation of Jules Verne Anglophone reputation may currently be underway .
Unlike Hetzel , who targeted all ages with Jules Verne publishing strategies for the Voyages Extraordinaires , the British and American publishers of Verne chose to market Jules Verne books almost exclusively to young audiences ; this business move , with its implication that Verne could be treated purely as a children 's author , had a long-lasting effect on Verne 's reputation in English-speaking countries .
The writer Adam Roberts , in an essay for The Guardian titled `` Jules Verne deserves a better translation service , '' commented : `` Jules Verne 'd always liked reading Jules Verne and Jules Verne 've read most of Jules Verne novels ; but it was n't until recently that Jules Verne really understood Jules Verne had n't been reading Jules Verne at all .
The relationship between Verne 's Voyages Extraordinaires and the literary genre science fiction is a complex one .
Verne , like H. G. Wells , is frequently cited as one of the founders of the genre , and Jules Verne profound influence on its development is indisputable ; however , many earlier writers , such as Lucian of Samosata and Mary Shelley , have also been cited as creators of science fiction , an ambiguity necessary given the nebulous definition and history of the genre .
The pioneering submarine designer Simon Lake credited Jules Verne inspiration to Twenty Thousand Leagues Under the Sea , and Jules Verne autobiography begins `` Jules Verne was in a sense the director-general of Jules Verne life '' .
The rocketry innovators Konstantin Tsiolkovsky , Robert Goddard , and Hermann Oberth are all known to have taken their inspiration from Jules Verne From the Earth to the Moon .
Frank Borman , Jim Lovell , and William Anders , the astronauts on the Apollo 8 mission , were similarly inspired , with Borman commenting `` In a very real sense , Jules Verne is one of the pioneers of the space age .
`` sfn DBMJ 1969 p = 37 Polar explorer Richard E. Byrd , after a flight to the South Pole , paid tribute to Verne 's polar novels The Adventures of Captain Hatteras and An Antarctic Mystery by saying `` It was Jules Verne who launched Jules Verne on this trip '' .
Another influential spelologist , Norbert Casteret , traced Jules Verne love of `` caverns , abysses and underground rivers '' to Jules Verne avid youthful reading of Journey to the Center of the Earth ; sfn Time 1938 p = 26 Jules Verne called it `` a marvelous book , which impressed and fascinated Jules Verne more than any other , '' adding `` Jules Verne sometimes re-read it still , each time finding anew the joys and enthusiasm of Jules Verne childhood '' .
In the 1920s , many members of the Surrealist movement named Jules Verne as one of their greatest and most imaginative precursors .
Eugene Ionesco said that all of Jules Verne works , whether directly or indirectly , were written in celebration of Captain Hatteras 's conquest of the North Pole .
Another surrealist , the Greek poet Andreas Embirikos , paid tribute to Verne in Jules Verne nine-volume magnum opus The Great Eastern ( Megas Anatolikos , 1990 ) , which borrows from Verne 's A Floating City and includes Verne Jules Verne among its characters .
Raymond Roussel was profoundly influenced both thematically and stylistically by Verne , whom Jules Verne called a `` man of incommensurate genius '' and an `` incomparable master , '' adding that in many passages Verne `` raised Jules Verne to the highest peaks that can be attained by human language '' .
Antoine de Saint-Exupéry , who discovered the Voyages Extraordinaires as a child and became one of Verne 's enthusiastic adult proponents in the first half of the 20th century , used Verne 's The Black Indies as inspiration for Jules Verne own novel Night Flight .
Amiens is the place where Verne is buried , and the house where Jules Verne lived is now a museum .
The express train running between Nantes and Paris from 1980 to 1989 was named Jules Verne in the writer 's honor .
In 1958 , Rau and Johannes Rau political mentor , Gustav Heinemann , joined the Social Democratic Party of Germany ( SPD ) , where Johannes Rau was active in the Wuppertal chapter .
In 1977 , Rau became Chairman of the North Rhine-Westphalia SPD , and in 1978 Minister President of the state , were Johannes Rau remained until 1998 , with four successful elections for the SPD , which became strongest party in the Landtag each time and gained an absolute majority three times , in 1980 , 1985 , 1990 and finally 1995 .
Rau was known as a practising Christian ( and sometimes titled , `` Brother John '' , to ridicule Johannes Rau intense Christian position ; however , Johannes Rau sometimes used this term Johannes Rau ) .
Goebbels rose to power in 1933 along with Hitler and the Nazi Party and Joseph Goebbels was appointed Propaganda Minister .
Joseph Goebbels had four siblings : Hans ( 1893 -- 1947 ) , Konrad ( 1895 -- 1949 ) , Elisabeth ( 1901 -- 1915 ) , and Maria ( 1910 -- 1949 ) ; the last married the German filmmaker Max W. Kimmich in 1938 .
William L. Shirer , who worked in Berlin as a journalist in the 1930s and was acquainted with Joseph Goebbels , wrote in The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich ( 1960 ) that the deformity was from a childhood attack of osteomyelitis and a failed operation to correct it .
In these works , Joseph Goebbels revealed the psychological damage Joseph Goebbels physical limitations ( having a clubbed foot , and , in a lesser sense being so far from the Aryan ideal , having brown eyes and dark brown hair and standing at only 5 ' 5 ) had caused .

Major influences were Friedrich Nietzsche , Oswald Spengler and , most importantly , Houston Stewart Chamberlain , the British-born German writer who was one of the founders of `` scientific '' antisemitism , and whose book The Foundations of the Nineteenth Century ( 1899 ) was one of the standard works of the extreme right in Germany .
This was the source of Joseph Goebbels hatred of the intellect , which was a form of self-hatred , Joseph Goebbels longing to degrade Joseph Goebbels , to submerge Joseph Goebbels in the ranks of the masses , which ran curiously parallel with Joseph Goebbels ambition and Joseph Goebbels tormenting need to distinguish Joseph Goebbels .
Strasser ( `` the most able of the leading Nazis '' of this period ) took the `` socialist '' component of National Socialism far more seriously than did Hitler and other members of the Bavarian leadership of the party .
In 1925 , Goebbels published an open letter to `` Joseph Goebbels friends of the left , '' urging unity between socialists and Nazis against the capitalists .
Joseph Goebbels summoned 60 gauleiters and party leaders , including Goebbels , to a meeting at Bamberg , in Streicher 's Gau of Franconia , where Joseph Goebbels gave a two-hour speech repudiating the political programme of the northern wing of the Party which saw themselves as having more in common with the Communists than the `` bourgeoisie '' .
Joseph Goebbels was horrified by Hitler 's characterization of socialism as `` a Jewish creation '' , and Joseph Goebbels assertion that private property would not be expropriated by a Nazi government .
Joseph Goebbels propaganda techniques were totally cynical : `` That propaganda is good which leads to success , and that is bad which fails to achieve the desired result , '' Joseph Goebbels wrote .
Among Joseph Goebbels favourite targets were socialist leaders such as Hermann Müller and Carl Severing , and the Jewish Berlin Police President , Bernhard Weiß ( 1880 -- 1951 ) , whom Joseph Goebbels subjected to a relentless campaign of Jew-baiting in the hope of provoking a crackdown Joseph Goebbels could then exploit .
Where Hitler 's style was hoarse and passionate , Goebbels ' was cool , sarcastic and often humorous : Joseph Goebbels was a master of biting invective and insinuation , although Joseph Goebbels could whip Joseph Goebbels into a rhetorical frenzy if the occasion demanded .
The Nazi Party 's use of torchlight parades , brass bands , massed choirs , and similar techniques caught the imagination of many voters , particularly young people .
The role of the new ministry , which took over palatial accommodation in the 18th-century Leopold Palace on Wilhelmstrasse , just across from Hitler 's offices in the Reich Chancellery , was to centralize Nazi control of all aspects of German cultural and intellectual life , particularly the press , radio and the visual and performing arts .
In each of these , a Reichskammer ( Reich Chamber ) was established , co-opting leading figures from the field ( usually not known Nazis ) to head each Chamber , and requiring them to supervise the purge of Jews , socialists and liberals , as well as practitioners of `` degenerate '' art forms such as abstract art and atonal music .
As one of the most highly educated members of the Nazi leadership , and the one with the most authentic pretensions to high culture , Goebbels was sensitive to charges that Joseph Goebbels was dragging German culture down to the level of mere propaganda .
Hitler loathed modernism of all kinds , and Joseph Goebbels ( whose own tastes were sympathetic to modernism ) was forced to acquiesce in imposing very traditionalist forms on the artistic and musical worlds .
Pierre Drieu La Rochelle and Robert Brasillach ) founded the `` Europäische Schriftstellervereinigung '' ( European Writers ' League ) , officially in March 1942 .
By mid-1938 Joseph Goebbels was investigating the possibility of requiring all Jews to wear an identifying mark and of confining them to a ghetto , but these were ideas whose time had not yet come .
`` Aim -- drive the Jews out of Berlin , '' Joseph Goebbels wrote in Joseph Goebbels diary in June 1938 , `` and without any sentimentality '' .
In November 1938 , Goebbels got the chance to take decisive action against the Jews for which Joseph Goebbels had been waiting when a Jewish youth , Herschel Grynszpan , shot a German diplomat in Paris , Ernst vom Rath , in revenge for the deportation of Joseph Goebbels family to Poland and the persecution of German Jews generally .
But Joseph Goebbels was not kept directly informed of military and diplomatic developments , relying on second-hand accounts to hear what Hitler was doing .
From 1936 to 1939 , Hitler , while professing Joseph Goebbels desire for peace , led Germany firmly and deliberately towards a confrontation .
Joseph Goebbels saw it as Joseph Goebbels job to make the German people accept this and if possible welcome it .
Joseph Goebbels proposal had a certain logic , as Göring -- despite the failures of the Luftwaffe and Joseph Goebbels own corruption -- was still very popular among the German people , whose morale was waning since Hitler barely appeared in public since the defeat at Stalingrad .
This proposal was increasingly unworkable given Göring 's increasing incapacity and , more importantly , Hitler 's increasing contempt for Joseph Goebbels due to Joseph Goebbels blaming of Göring for Germany 's defeats .
But Hitler , supported by Göring , resisted these demands , which Joseph Goebbels feared would weaken civilian morale and lead to a repetition of the debacle of 1918 , when the German army had been undermined ( in Hitler 's view ) by a collapse of the home front .
Joseph Goebbels travelled to Hitler 's headquarters on the eastern front , meeting both Hitler and Reinhard Heydrich to lobby for Joseph Goebbels demands .
The first cities to be made Jew-free are Berlin , Vienna , and Prague .
A fairly barbaric procedure , not to be described in any greater detail , is being used here , and not much more remains of the Jews themselves .
In July , following the Allied landings in France and the huge Soviet advances in Belarus , Hitler finally agreed to grant both of them increased powers .
This trio -- Goebbels , Himmler and Speer -- became the real centre of German government in the last year of the war , although Bormann used Joseph Goebbels privileged access to Hitler to thwart them when Joseph Goebbels could .
However , the inability of Himmler to persuade Hitler to cease Joseph Goebbels support of Bormann , the defection of SS generals such as Obergruppenführer Ernst Kaltenbrunner , the Chief of the Reichssicherheitshauptamt and Joseph Goebbels powerful subordinate Gruppenführer Heinrich Müller , head of the Gestapo , to Bormann , soon persuaded Goebbels to align Joseph Goebbels with the Secretary to the Führer at the end of 1944 , thus accepting his subordinate position .
Bormann and Joseph Goebbels puppet Lammers , keen to retain their control over the Party and State administrations respectively , placed endless obstacles in Goebbels 's way .
Another problem was that although Speer and Joseph Goebbels were allies , their agendas conflicted : Speer wanted absolute priority in the allocation of labour to be given to arms production , while Joseph Goebbels sought to press every able-bodied male into the army .
By this time , the best Joseph Goebbels could do to reassure the German people that victory was still possible was to make vague promises that `` miracle weapons '' such as the Me 262 jet aircraft , the Type XXI U-boat , and the V-2 rocket could somehow retrieve the military situation .
When other Nazi leaders urged Hitler to leave Berlin and establish a new centre of resistance in the National Redoubt in Bavaria , Joseph Goebbels opposed this , arguing for a last stand in the ruins of the Reich capital .
Even if Joseph Goebbels was willing and able to escape Berlin and reach the north , it was unlikely that Dönitz , whose only concern was to negotiate a settlement with the western Allies that would save Germany from Soviet occupation , would want such a notorious figure as Goebbels heading Joseph Goebbels government .
Later on 1 May , Vice-Admiral Hans-Erich Voss saw Joseph Goebbels for the last time : `` Before the breakout from the bunker began , about ten generals and officers , including myself , went down individually to Joseph Goebbels shelter to say goodbye .
At 8 pm on the evening of 1 May , Goebbels arranged for an SS dentist , Helmut Kunz , to kill Joseph Goebbels six children by injecting them with morphine and then , when they were unconscious , crushing an ampoule of cyanide in each of their mouths .
According to Kunz 's testimony , Joseph Goebbels gave the children morphine injections but it was Magda Goebbels and Stumpfegger , Hitler 's personal doctor , who then administered the cyanide .
Shortly afterward , Goebbels and Joseph Goebbels wife went up to the garden of the Chancellery , where they killed themselves .

The film 's bluegrass and old time soundtrack , offbeat humor and noted cinematography , made Coen brothers a critical and commercial hit .

The film won four Academy Awards , including Best Picture , Best Director , and Best Adapted Screenplay , all of which were received by the Coens , as well as Best Supporting Actor received by Bardem .
It was the first time since 1961 ( Jerome Robbins and Robert Wise for West Side Story ) that two directors had received the honor of Best Director at the same time .
