Jorge Luis Borges ( 24 August 1899 -- 14 June 1986 ) , known as Jorge Luis Borges , was an Argentine short-story writer , essayist , poet and translator born in Buenos Aires .
Jorge Luis Borges most famous books , Ficciones ( 1944 ) and The Aleph ( 1949 ) , are compilations of short stories interconnected by common themes such as dreams , labyrinths , libraries , mirrors , animals , fictional writers , philosophy , religion and God .
In this vein , Jorge Luis Borges biographer Williamson underlines the danger in inferring an autobiographically-inspired basis for the content or tone of certain of Jorge Luis Borges works : books , philosophy and imagination were as much a source of real inspiration to Jorge Luis Borges as Jorge Luis Borges own lived experience , if not more so .
The first lay somewhere between non-fictional essays and short stories , using fictional techniques to tell essentially true stories .
Jorge Luis Borges presence , also in 1967 , on campus at the University of Virginia ( Charlottesville , VA ) influenced a group of students amongst which was Jared Loewenstein who would later become founder and curator of the Jorge Luis Borges Collection at UVA , one of the largest repositories of documents and manuscripts pertaining to the early works of JLB .
Friends believed that Jorge Luis Borges mother , who was 90 and anticipating her own death , wanted to find someone to care for her blind son .
In 1934 , Argentine ultra-nationalists , sympathetic to Adolf Hitler and the Nazi Party , asserted Borges was secretly Jewish , and by implication , not a `` true '' Argentine .
Hitler is blindly collaborating with the inevitable armies that will annihilate Jorge Luis Borges , as the metal vultures and the dragon , ( which must have known that they were monsters ) , collaborated , mysteriously , with Hercules '' .
Along with publishing numerous legitimate translations , Jorge Luis Borges also published original works , for example , in the style of Emanuel Swedenborg or One Thousand and One Nights , originally claiming them to be translations of works Jorge Luis Borges had chanced upon .
Jorge Luis Borges then cites both Sartor Resartus and Samuel Butler 's The Fair Haven , remarking , however , that `` those works suffer under the imperfection that they themselves are books , and not a whit less tautological than the others .
Magic realism and exploration of universal truths , they argued , had come at the cost of responsibility and seriousness in the face of society 's problems .
The protagonist of the story `` El muerto '' also lusts after the `` splendid , contemptuous , red-haired woman '' of Azevedo Bandeira and later `` sleeps with the woman with shining hair '' .
Some observers speculated that Borges did not receive the award because of Jorge Luis Borges conservative political views ; or more specifically , because Jorge Luis Borges had accepted an honour from dictator Augusto Pinochet .
Many of Borges 's most popular stories concern the nature of time ( `` The Secret Miracle '' ) , infinity ( `` The Aleph '' ) , mirrors ( `` Tlön , Uqbar , Orbis Tertius '' ) and labyrinths ( `` The Two Kings and the Two Labyrinths '' , `` The House of Asterion '' , `` The Immortal '' , `` The Garden of Forking Paths '' ) .
Jorge Luis Borges stories often have fantastical themes , such as a library containing every possible 410-page text ( `` The Library of Babel '' ) , a man who forgets nothing Jorge Luis Borges experiences ( `` Funes , the Memorious '' ) , an artifact through which the user can see everything in the universe ( `` The Aleph '' ) , and a year of still time given to a man standing before a firing squad ( `` The Secret Miracle '' ) .
Jorge Luis Borges mixed the real and the fantastic : fact with fiction .
In the Book of Imaginary Beings , a thoroughly ( and obscurely ) researched bestiary of mythical creatures , Borges wrote , `` There is a kind of lazy pleasure in useless and out-of-the-way erudition '' .
Borges 's interest in fantasy was shared by Adolfo Bioy Casares , with whom Jorge Luis Borges coauthored several collections of tales between 1942 and 1967 , often under different pseudonyms including H. Bustos Domecq .
The original concept put forward by Borges is in Kafka and Jorge Luis Borges Precursors - after reviewing works that were written before Kafka 's , Borges wrote `` If Jorge Luis Borges am not mistaken , the heterogeneous pieces Jorge Luis Borges have enumerated resemble Kafka ; if Jorge Luis Borges am not mistaken , not all of them resemble each other .
Borges had an English paternal grandmother who , around 1870 , married the criollo Francisco Borges , a man with a military command and a historic role in the civil wars in what is now Argentina and Uruguay .
The varying genealogies of characters , settings , and themes in Jorge Luis Borges stories , such as `` La muerte y la brújula '' , used Argentine models without pandering to Jorge Luis Borges readers or framing Argentine culture as ` exotic ' .
However , while Nabokov and Joyce tended toward progressively larger works as they grew older , Borges remained a miniaturist .
Borges 's work progressed away from what Jorge Luis Borges referred to as `` the baroque '' , while Joyce 's and Nabokov 's moved towards it : Jorge Luis Borges later style is far more transparent and naturalistic than Jorge Luis Borges earlier works .
Critic Paul de Man notes , `` Whatever Borges 's existential anxieties may be , they have little in common with Sartre 's robustly prosaic view of literature , with the earnestness of Camus ' moralism , or with the weighty profundity of German existential thought .
As a political conservative , Borges `` was repulsed by Marxism in theory and practice .
The essay collection Borges y la Matemática ( Borges and Mathematics , 2003 ) by Argentine mathematician and writer Guillermo Martínez , outlines how Borges used concepts from mathematics in Jorge Luis Borges work .
From 1811 until 1816 , with the release of Sense and Sensibility ( 1811 ) , Pride and Prejudice ( 1813 ) , Mansfield Park ( 1814 ) and Emma ( 1816 ) , Jane Austen achieved success as a published writer .
Only some personal and family letters remain ( by one estimate only 160 out of Austen 's 3,000 letters are extant ) , and Jane Austen sister Cassandra ( to whom most of the letters were originally addressed ) burned `` the greater part '' of the ones Jane Austen kept and censored those Jane Austen did not destroy .
Most of the plays were comedies , which suggests one way in which Austen 's comedic and satirical gifts were cultivated .
There is manuscript evidence that Austen continued to work on these pieces as late as the period 1809 -- 1811 , and that Jane Austen niece and nephew , Anna and James Edward Austen , made further additions as late as 1814 .
Honan speculates that at some point not long after writing Love and Freindship in 1789 , Austen decided to `` write for profit , to make stories Jane Austen central effort '' , that is , to become a professional writer .
Tomalin writes : `` Told in letters , it is as neatly plotted as a play , and as cynical in tone as any of the most outrageous of the Restoration dramatists who may have provided some of Jane Austen inspiration ... It stands alone in Austen 's work as a study of an adult woman whose intelligence and force of character are greater than those of anyone Jane Austen encounters '' .
The sentimental relationship between Jane Austen and Tom is at the centre of the 2007 biographical film Becoming Jane Austen .
During the middle of 1798 , after finishing revisions of Elinor and Marianne , Jane Austen began writing a third novel with the working title Susan -- later Northanger Abbey -- a satire on the popular Gothic novel .
While retirement and travel were good for the elder Austens , Jane Austen was shocked to be told Jane Austen was moving from the only home Jane Austen had ever known .
Though Austen 's novels were republished in Britain beginning in the 1830s and remained steady sellers , they were not bestsellers .
In it , he established the groupings of Austen 's `` early '' and `` late '' novels , which are still used by scholars today .
At the time , concern arose over the fact that academics were taking over Jane Austen criticism and it was becoming increasingly esoteric -- a debate that has continued to the beginning of the 21st century .
They agreed that Jane Austen `` combined Henry Fielding 's and Samuel Richardson 's qualities of interiority and irony , realism and satire to form an author superior to both '' .
BBC television dramatisations , which were first produced in the 1970s , attempted to adhere meticulously to Austen 's plots , characterisations , and settings .
Books and scripts that use the general storyline of Austen 's novels but change or otherwise modernise the story also became popular at the end of the 20th century .

July starts on the same day of the week as April in a common year , and January in leap years .

John Horton Conway ( born 26 December 1937 ) is a British mathematician active in the theory of finite groups , knot theory , number theory , combinatorial game theory and coding theory .
John Horton Conway early experiments in that field were done with pen and paper , long before personal computers existed .
In 2004 , Conway and Simon B. Kochen , another Princeton mathematician , proved the Free will theorem , a startling version of the No Hidden Variables principle of Quantum Mechanics .
Aldine Press was continued after Aldus 's death in 1515 by his wife and her father until his son Paolo ( 1512 -- 1574 ) took over .
One of the more substantial collections of Aldine Press books and Aldine imitations in North America is at the Harold B. Lee library on the campus of Brigham Young University in Provo , Utah .
John Uhler `` Jack '' Lemmon III ( February 8 , 1925 -- June 27 , 2001 ) was an American actor and musician .
Jack Lemmon was the only child of Mildred Burgess LaRue ( née Noel ) and John Uhler Lemmon , Jr. , who was the president of a doughnut company .
Jack Lemmon also became enamored of the piano and learned to play it on Jack Lemmon own .

Conrad is regarded as one of the greatest novelists in English , though Joseph Conrad did not speak the language fluently until Joseph Conrad was in Joseph Conrad twenties ( and always with a marked accent ) .
Writing in the heyday of the British Empire , Conrad drew on Joseph Conrad native Poland 's national experiences and on Joseph Conrad personal experiences in the French and British merchant navies , to create short stories and novels that reflect aspects of a European-dominated world , while plumbing the depths of the human soul .
Conrad , who would actually be known to Joseph Conrad family as `` Konrad '' rather than `` Józef '' , was christened Józef Teodor Konrad after Joseph Conrad maternal grandfather Józef , Joseph Conrad paternal grandfather Teodor , and the heroes ( both named `` Konrad '' ) of two poems by Adam Mickiewicz , Dziady and Konrad Wallenrod .
Half a century later Joseph Conrad explained that `` The Polishness in Joseph Conrad works comes from Mickiewicz and Słowacki .
In 1894 , aged 36 , Conrad reluctantly gave up the sea , partly because of poor health and partly because Joseph Conrad had become so fascinated with writing that Joseph Conrad had decided on a literary career .
The second phase , spanning the war and following the popular success of Chance ( 1913 ) , is marked by the advent of Conrad 's public persona as `` great writer '' .
Despite the opinions even of some who knew Joseph Conrad personally , such as fellow novelist Henry James , Conrad -- even when Joseph Conrad was only writing elegantly crafted letters to Joseph Conrad uncle and acquaintances -- was always at heart a writer who sailed , rather than a sailor who wrote .
An October 1923 visitor to Oswalds , Conrad 's then home -- Cyril Clemens , a cousin of Mark Twain -- quoted Conrad as saying : `` In everything Joseph Conrad have written there is always one invariable intention , and that is to capture the reader 's attention '' .
The 1901 short story `` Amy Foster '' was inspired partly by an anecdote in Ford Madox Ford 's The Cinque Ports ( 1900 ) , wherein a shipwrecked sailor from a German merchant ship , unable to communicate in English , and driven away by the local country people , finally found shelter in a pigsty .
In Nostromo ( completed 1904 ) , the theft of a massive consignment of silver was suggested to Conrad by a story Joseph Conrad had heard in the Gulf of Mexico and later read about in a `` volume picked up outside a second-hand bookshop '' .
Conrad 's story `` The Secret Sharer '' ( completed 1909 ) was inspired by an 1880 incident when Sydney Smith , first mate of the Cutty Sark , had killed a seaman and fled from justice , aided by the ship 's captain .
The near-novella `` Freya of the Seven Isles '' ( completed in March 1911 ) was inspired by a story told to Joseph Conrad by a Malaya old hand and fan of Conrad 's , Captain Carlos M. Marris .
Almayer ( Almayer 's Folly , 1894 ) , abandoned by Joseph Conrad beloved daughter , takes to opium and dies ; Peter Willems ( An Outcast of the Islands , 1895 ) is killed by Joseph Conrad jealous lover Aïssa ; the ineffectual `` Nigger , '' James Wait ( The Nigger of the Narcissus , 1897 ) , dies aboard ship and is buried at sea ; Mr. Kurtz ( Heart of Darkness , 1899 ) expires , uttering the enigmatic words , `` The horror !
; Tuan Jim ( Lord Jim , 1900 ) , having inadvertently precipitated a massacre of Joseph Conrad adoptive community , deliberately walks to Joseph Conrad death at the hands of the community 's leader ; in Conrad 's 1901 short story , `` Amy Foster '' , a Pole transplanted to England , Yanko Goorall ( an English transliteration of the Polish Janko Góral , `` Johnny Highlander '' ) , falls ill and , suffering from a fever , raves in Joseph Conrad native language , frightening Joseph Conrad wife Amy , who flees : next morning Yanko dies of heart failure , and it transpires that Joseph Conrad had simply been asking in Polish for water ; Captain Whalley ( The End of the Tether , 1902 ) , betrayed by failing eyesight and an unscrupulous partner , drowns Joseph Conrad ; Gian ' Battista Fidanza , the eponymous respected Italian-immigrant Nostromo ( Italian : `` Our Man '' ) of the novel Nostromo ( 1904 ) , illicitly obtains a treasure of silver mined in the South American country of `` Costaguana '' and is shot dead due to mistaken identity ; Mr. Verloc , The Secret Agent ( 1906 ) of divided loyalties , attempts a bombing , to be blamed on terrorists , that accidentally kills Joseph Conrad mentally defective brother-in-law Stevie , and Verloc himself is killed by his distraught wife , who drowns herself by jumping overboard from a channel steamer ; in Chance ( 1913 ) , Roderick Anthony , a sailing-ship captain , and benefactor and husband of Flora de Barral , becomes the target of a poisoning attempt by her jealous disgraced financier father who , when detected , swallows the poison himself and dies ( some years later , Captain Anthony drowns at sea ) ; in Victory ( 1915 ) , Lena is shot dead by Jones , who had meant to kill his accomplice Ricardo and later succeeds in doing so , then himself perishes along with another accomplice , after which Lena 's protector Axel Heyst sets fire to his bungalow and dies beside Lena 's body .
Later Razumov , sent as a government spy to Geneva , a center of anti-tsarist intrigue , meets the mother and sister of Haldin , who share Haldin 's liberal convictions .
But in 1922 , near the end of Joseph Conrad life and career , when another Scottish friend , Richard Curle , sent Conrad proofs of two articles Joseph Conrad had written about Conrad , the latter objected to being characterized as a gloomy and tragic writer .
John Galsworthy , who knew Joseph Conrad well , described this as `` a statement which surprised no one who knew the resources of Joseph Conrad memory and the brooding nature of Joseph Conrad creative spirit '' .
Conrad , like other artists , faced constraints arising from the need to propitiate Joseph Conrad audience and confirm its own favorable self-regard .
This may account for his describing the admirable crew of the Judea in Joseph Conrad 1898 story `` Youth '' as `` Liverpool hard cases '' , whereas the crew of the Judeas actual 1882 prototype , the Palestine , had included not a single Liverpudlian , and half the crew had been non-Britons ; and for Conrad 's turning the real-life 1880 criminally negligent British Captain J.L. Clark , of the S.S. Jeddah , in Joseph Conrad 1900 novel Lord Jim , into the captain of the fictitious Patna -- `` a sort of renegade New South Wales German '' so monstrous in physical appearance as to suggest `` a trained baby elephant '' .
The singularity of the universe depicted in Conrad 's novels , especially compared to those of near-contemporaries like Joseph Conrad friend and frequent benefactor John Galsworthy , is such as to open Joseph Conrad to criticism similar to that later applied to Graham Greene .
But where `` Greeneland '' has been characterised as a recurring and recognisable atmosphere independent of setting , Conrad is at pains to create a sense of place , be it aboard ship or in a remote village ; often Joseph Conrad chose to have Joseph Conrad characters play out their destinies in isolated or confined circumstances .
In the view of Evelyn Waugh and Kingsley Amis , it was not until the first volumes of Anthony Powell 's sequence , A Dance to the Music of Time , were published in the 1950s , that an English novelist achieved the same command of atmosphere and precision of language with consistency , a view supported by later critics like A. N. Wilson ; Powell acknowledged Joseph Conrad debt to Conrad .
Conrad 's was a starkly lucid view of the human condition -- a vision similar to that which had been offered in two micro-stories by Joseph Conrad ten-years-older Polish compatriot , Bolesław Prus ( whose work Conrad greatly admired ) : `` Mold of the Earth '' ( 1884 ) and `` Shades '' ( 1885 ) .
More to the point is Conrad 's remark in A Personal Record that English was `` the speech of Joseph Conrad secret choice , of Joseph Conrad future , of long friendships , of the deepest affections , of hours of toil and hours of ease , and of solitary hours , too , of books read , of thoughts pursued , of remembered emotions -- of Joseph Conrad very dreams !
Under the circumstances , English could not but become `` the speech of ... Joseph Conrad future , of long friendships , of ... affection , of hours of toil and ... ease , and ... of books read ... thoughts pursued ... remembered emotions ... '' Had Conrad remained in the Francophone sphere or had Joseph Conrad returned to Poland , the son of the Polish poet , playwright and translator Apollo Korzeniowski -- from childhood exposed to Polish and foreign literature , and ambitious to Joseph Conrad become a writer -- might have ended writing in French or Polish instead of English .
Inescapably , Conrad 's third language , English , remained under the influence of Joseph Conrad first two languages -- Polish and French .
According to Conrad 's close friend and literary assistant Richard Curle , the fact of Conrad writing in English was `` obviously misleading '' because Conrad `` is no more completely English in his art than Joseph Conrad is in Joseph Conrad nationality '' .
Achebe 's essay , a landmark in postcolonial discourse , provoked an ongoing debate , and the questions it raised have been addressed in most subsequent literary criticism of Joseph Conrad .
This , indeed , is a central theme of the novel ; Marlow 's experiences in Africa expose the brutality of colonialism and its rationales .
Jeffrey Meyers notes that Joseph Conrad , like his acquaintance Roger Casement , `` was one of the first men to question the Western notion of progress , a dominant idea in Europe from the Renaissance to the Great War , to attack the hypocritical justification of colonialism and to reveal ... the savage degradation of the white man in Africa '' .
If Conrad or Joseph Conrad novel is racist , Firchow argues , it is only in a weak sense , since Heart of Darkness acknowledges racial distinctions `` but does not suggest an essential superiority '' of any particular group .
The elder , Borys , whom Joseph Conrad named under the misapprehension that the Russian name Boris was a Polish name , proved a disappointment in scholarship and integrity .
Except for several vacations in France and Italy , a 1914 vacation in Joseph Conrad native Poland , and a 1923 visit to the United States , Conrad lived the rest of Joseph Conrad life in England .
On 28 July 1914 , the day war broke out between Austro-Hungary and Serbia , Joseph Conrad and the Retingers arrived in Kraków ( then in the Austro-Hungarian Empire ) , where Joseph Conrad visited childhood haunts .
So many characteristics that had been strange and unfathomable to Joseph Conrad before , took , as it were , their right proportions .
This was accompanied by a faith in the Panslavic ideology -- `` surprising , '' Najder writes , `` in a man who was later to emphasize Joseph Conrad hostility towards Russia , a conviction that ... Poland 's superior civilization and ... historic ... traditions would let her play a leading role ... in the Panslavic community , and doubts about Poland 's chances of becoming a fully sovereign nation-state '' .
The most extensive and ambitious political statement that Conrad ever made was Joseph Conrad 1905 essay , `` Autocracy and War '' , whose starting point was the Russo-Japanese War ( Joseph Conrad finished the article a month before the Battle of Tsushima Strait ) .
Conrad 's `` Autocracy and War '' , Najder points out , showed a historical awareness `` exceptional in the Western European literature of Joseph Conrad time '' -- an awareness that Conrad had drawn from Joseph Conrad membership in a very politically active family of a country that had for over a century been daily reminded of the consequences of neglecting the broad enlightened interests of the national polity .
In San Francisco in 1979 , a small triangular square at Columbus Avenue and Beach Street , near Fisherman 's Wharf , was dedicated as `` Joseph Conrad Square '' after Joseph Conrad .
Joseph Conrad visit to Bangkok also remains in that city 's collective memory , and is recorded in the official history of The Oriental Hotel ( where Joseph Conrad never , in fact , stayed , lodging aboard Joseph Conrad ship , the Otago ) along with that of a less well-behaved guest , Somerset Maugham , who pilloried the hotel in a short story in revenge for attempts to eject Joseph Conrad .
Later literary admirers , notably Graham Greene , followed closely in Joseph Conrad footsteps , sometimes requesting the same room and perpetuating myths that have no basis in fact .
In April 2013 in Russian town of Vologda , where Joseph Conrad and Joseph Conrad family stayed in exile from 1862 to 1863 , a monument to Conrad was unveiled .
Joseph Conrad had a genius for companionship , and Joseph Conrad circle of friends , which Joseph Conrad had begun assembling even prior to Joseph Conrad first publications , included authors and other leading lights in the arts , such as Henry James , Robert Bontine Cunninghame Graham , John Galsworthy , Edward Garnett , Garnett 's wife Constance Garnett ( translator of Russian literature ) , Stephen Crane , Hugh Walpole , George Bernard Shaw , H.G. Wells , Arnold Bennett , Norman Douglas , Jacob Epstein , T.E.
In 1919 and 1922 Conrad 's growing renown and prestige among writers and critics in continental Europe fostered Joseph Conrad hopes for a Nobel Prize in literature .
In April 1924 Joseph Conrad , who possessed a hereditary Polish status of nobility and coat-of-arms ( Nałęcz ) , declined a ( non-hereditary ) British knighthood offered by Labour Party Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald .
Of Conrad 's novels , Lord Jim ( 1900 ) and Nostromo ( 1904 ) are widely read as set texts and for pleasure .
Arguably Joseph Conrad most influential work remains Heart of Darkness ( 1899 ) , to which many have been introduced by Francis Ford Coppola 's film , Apocalypse Now ( 1979 ) , inspired by Conrad 's novel and set during the Vietnam War ; the novel 's depiction of a journey into the darkness of the human psyche resonates with modern readers .
Joseph Conrad is a part of the great cause of these high and just proceedings '' .
John Updike ( 18 March 1932 -- 27 January 2009 ) was an American novelist , poet , short story writer , John Updike , and literary critic .
Both Rabbit Is Rich ( 1981 ) and Rabbit At Rest ( 1990 ) received the Pulitzer Prize .
John Updike was born in Reading , Pennsylvania , the only child of Linda Grace ( née Hoyer ) and Wesley Russell Updike , and grew up in the nearby small town Shillington .
After returning to the United States , Updike and John Updike family moved to New York , where John Updike became a regular contributor to The New Yorker .
The New Yorker , particularly in the 1930s through the 1980s , reached a wide and literate audience with emphasis on writers , artists and thinkers on the east coast , where most of its readers also resided .
As magazines directed their attention to `` targeted '' or special interest audiences of prime interest to advertisers , short fiction began to fall by the wayside .
Updike 's short story output found a welcome home at The New Yorker , which , in turn , introduced John Updike to a wide and alert reading public .
In 1971 , Updike published a sequel to Rabbit , Run called Rabbit Redux , John Updike response to the 1960s ; Rabbit reflected much of Updike 's confusion and ambivalence towards the social and political changes that beset the United States during that time .
Two other novels from this period , A Month of Sundays ( 1975 ) , the first in Updike 's so-called Scarlet Letter trilogy , and Marry Me : A Romance ( 1976 ) , are also meditations on suburban adultery .
More than 800 pages long , with over one hundred stories , it has been called `` a richly episodic and lyrical Bildungsroman ... in which John Updike traces the trajectory from adolescence , college , married life , fatherhood , separation and divorce '' .
She accompanied John Updike to Oxford , England , where John Updike attended art school and where their first child , Elizabeth , was born in 1955 .
John Keenan , who praised the collection Endpoint as `` beautiful and poignant '' , notes that John Updike poetry 's engagement with `` the everyday world in a technically accomplished manner seems to count against him '' .
John Updike was widely praised as America 's `` last true man of letters '' , with an immense and far-reaching influence on many writers .
On the whole , however , John Updike is extremely well regarded as a writer who mastered many genres , wrote with intellectual vigor and a powerful prose style , with `` shrewd insight into the sorrows , frustrations , and banality of American life '' .
Updike 's character Rabbit Angstrom , the protagonist of the series of novels widely considered John Updike magnum opus , has been said to have `` entered the pantheon of signal American literary figures , '' along with Huckleberry Finn , Jay Gatsby , Holden Caulfield and others .
John Updike is a master of effortless motion -- between third and first person , from the metaphorical density of literary prose to the demotic , from specific detail to wide generalisation , from the actual to the numinous , from the scary to the comic .
In a novel like this , John Updike insisted , you have to be generous and allow your characters eloquence , `` and not chop them down to what you think is the right size '' .
The novelist Philip Roth , considered one of Updike 's chief literary rivals , wrote that `` John Updike is our time 's greatest man of letters , as brilliant a literary critic and essayist as John Updike was a novelist and short story writer .
For all John Updike fabled Protestantism , both American Puritan and Lutheran-Barthian , with its cold glitter , its insistence on the aching gap between God and John Updike creatures , Updike seems less like Hawthorne than Balzac , in John Updike unstopping and limitless energy , and John Updike cheerfully professional belief that stories can be continued ; the very form of the Rabbit books -- here extended a further instance -- suggests continuance .
Updike aspires to `` this sense of self-qualification , the kind of timid reverence towards what exists that Cézanne shows when John Updike grapples for the shape and shade of a fruit through a mist of delicate stabs '' .
John Updike appreciation of it is that diverse and that complicated ... John is perhaps the only contemporary writer who John Updike know now who gives John Updike the sense of the fact that life is -- the life that we perform is in an environment that enjoys a grandeur that escapes us .
Robert B. Silvers , editor of The New York Review of Books , called Updike `` one of the most elegant and coolly observant writers of John Updike generation '' .
Updike 's novels often act as dialectical theological debates between the book itself and the reader , the novel endowed with theological beliefs meant to challenge the reader as the plot runs its course .

As the author of twenty-seven books , including sixteen novels , six non-fiction books , and five collections of short stories , John Steinbeck received the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1962 .
John 's mother , Olive Hamilton , a former school teacher , shared John Steinbeck passion of reading and writing .
John Steinbeck spent John Steinbeck summers working on nearby ranches and later with migrant workers on Spreckels ranch .
The elder Steinbecks gave John Steinbeck free housing , paper for John Steinbeck manuscripts , and from 1928 , loans that allowed John Steinbeck to give up a warehouse job in San Francisco to focus on writing .
John Steinbeck next works were the California farm-worker depression-era novels In Dubious Battle , Of Mice and Men , and The Grapes of Wrath .
They visited Moscow , Kiev , Tbilisi , Batumi and Stalingrad , some of the first Americans to visit many parts of the USSR since the communist revolution .
John Steinbeck first novel , , published in 1929 , is based on the life and death of privateer Henry Morgan .
After Cup of Gold , between 1931 and 1933 John Steinbeck produced three shorter works .
To a God Unknown follows the life of a homesteader and John Steinbeck family in California , depicting a character with a primal and pagan worship of the land John Steinbeck works .
In presenting the 1962 Nobel Prize to John Steinbeck , the Swedish Academy cited `` spicy and comic tales about a gang of paisanos , asocial individuals who , in their wild revels , are almost caricatures of King Arthur 's Knights of the Round Table .
Of Mice and Men was a drama about the dreams of a pair of migrant agricultural laborers in California .
Later that year it won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction and it was adapted as a film directed by John Ford , starring Henry Fonda as Tom Joad ; Fonda was nominated for the best actor Academy Award .
John Steinbeck New Deal political views , negative portrayal of aspects of capitalism , and sympathy for the plight of workers , led to a backlash against the author , especially close to home .
The latest is a rumor started by them that the Okies hate John Steinbeck and have threatened to kill John Steinbeck for lying about them .
The film versions of The Grapes of Wrath and Of Mice and Men ( by two different movie studios ) were in production simultaneously , allowing John Steinbeck to spend a full day on the set of The Grapes of Wrath and the next day on the set of Of Mice and Men .
The declassified documents showed that John Steinbeck was chosen as the best of a bad lot , `` There are n't any obvious candidates for the Nobel prize and the prize committee is in an unenviable situation , '' wrote committee member Henry Olsson .
In the United Kingdom , Of Mice and Men is one of the key texts used by the examining body AQA for its English Literature GCSE .
John Steinbeck childhood friend , Max Wagner , a brother of Jack Wagner and who later became a film actor , served as inspiration for The Red Pony .
Later John Steinbeck used real American historical conditions and events in the first half of the 20th century , which John Steinbeck had experienced first-hand as a reporter .
Dana Gioia ( chair of the National Endowment for the Arts ) told an audience at the center , `` This is really the best modern literary shrine in the country , and John Steinbeck 've seen them all '' .
Thomas Steinbeck , the author 's eldest son , said that J. Edgar Hoover , director of the FBI at the time , could find no basis for prosecuting Steinbeck and therefore used John Steinbeck power to encourage the U.S. Internal Revenue Service to audit Steinbeck 's taxes every single year of John Steinbeck life , just to annoy John Steinbeck .
This first novel tells the story of a fruit pickers ' strike in California which is both aided and damaged by the help of `` the Party , '' generally taken to be the Communist Party , although this is never spelled out in the book .
Joshua Reynolds RA FRS FRSA ( 16 July 1723 -- 23 February 1792 ) was an influential eighteenth-century English painter , specialising in portraits and promoting the `` Grand Style '' in painting which depended on idealization of the imperfect .
James Northcote , Joshua Reynolds pupil , wrote of this arrangement that `` the imitation of particular stuffs is not the work of genius , but is to be acquired easily by practice , and this was what Joshua Reynolds pupils could do by care and time more than he Joshua Reynolds chose to bestow ; but Joshua Reynolds own slight and masterly work was still the best '' .
When in 1783 the landlord of the Turks Head died and the property was sold , The Club moved to Sackville Street .
As a lecturer , Joshua Reynolds Discourses ( delivered between 1769 and 1790 ) are remembered for their sensitivity and perception .
In one lectures Joshua Reynolds was of the opinion that `` invention , strictly speaking , is little more than a new combination of those images which have been previously gathered and deposited in the memory '' .
J. M. W. Turner and James Northcote were fervent acolytes : Turner requested Joshua Reynolds be laid to rest at Reynolds ' side , and Northcote , who spent four years as Reynolds ' pupil , wrote to Joshua Reynolds family `` Joshua Reynolds know Joshua Reynolds thoroughly , and all Joshua Reynolds faults , Joshua Reynolds am sure , and yet almost worship Joshua Reynolds '' .
Reynolds agreed with Burke 's Reflections on the Revolution in France and , writing in early 1791 , expressed Joshua Reynolds belief that the ancien régime of France had fallen due to spending too much time tending , as Joshua Reynolds puts it ; `` to the splendor of the foliage , to the neglect of the stirring the earth about the roots .
In October Joshua Reynolds was too ill to take the president 's chair and in November Fanny Burney recorded that `` Joshua Reynolds had long languished to see that kindly zealous friend , but Joshua Reynolds ill health had intimidated Joshua Reynolds from making the attempt '' : `` Joshua Reynolds had a bandage over one eye , and the other shaded with a green half-bonnet .
On 5 November Reynolds , fearing Joshua Reynolds might not have an opportunity to write a will , wrote a memorandum intended to be Joshua Reynolds last will and testament , with Edmund Burke , Edmond Malone , and Philip Metcalfe named as executors .
Doctors Richard Warren and Sir George Baker believed Reynolds ' illness to be psychological and they bled Joshua Reynolds neck `` with a view of drawing the humour from Joshua Reynolds eyes '' but the effect , in the view of Joshua Reynolds niece , was that it seemed `` as if the ` principle of life ' were gone '' from Reynolds .
In Taste , in grace , in facility , in happy invention , and in the richness and Harmony of colouring , Joshua Reynolds was equal to the great masters of the renowned Ages .
Joseph Schumpeter ( 8 February 1883 -- 8 January 1950 ) was an Austrian-American economist and political scientist .
In 1919 , Joseph Schumpeter served briefly as the Austrian Minister of Finance , with some success , and in 1920 -- 1924 , as president of the private Biedermann Bank .
Joseph Schumpeter prestige among colleagues was likewise not very high because Joseph Schumpeter views seemed outdated and not in tune with the then-fashionable Keynesianism .
According to Christopher Freeman ( 2009 ) , a scholar who devoted much time researching Schumpeter 's work : `` the central point of Joseph Schumpeter whole life work is : that capitalism can only be understood as an evolutionary process of continuous innovation and ` creative destruction ' This is still not taken into the bosom of mainstream theory , although many now pay lip service to it '' .
For instance , Schumpeter thought that the greatest 18th century economist was Turgot , not Adam Smith , as many consider , and Joseph Schumpeter considered Léon Walras to be the `` greatest of all economists '' , beside whom other economists ' theories were `` like inadequate attempts to catch some particular aspects of Walrasian truth '' .
Following neither Walras nor Keynes , Joseph Schumpeter starts in The Theory of Economic Development with a treatise of circular flow which , excluding any innovations and innovative activities , leads to a stationary state .
Joseph Schumpeter saw these cycles varying in time -- although in a tight time frame by coincidence -- and for each to serve a specific purpose .
Joseph Schumpeter argued that capitalism 's collapse from within will come about as democratic majorities vote for restrictions upon entrepreneurship that will burden and destroy the capitalist structure , but also emphasizes non-political , evolutionary processes in society where `` liberal capitalism '' was evolving into democratic socialism because of the growth of workers ' self-management , industrial democracy and regulatory institutions .
The term `` intellectuals '' denotes a class of persons in a position to develop critiques of societal matters for which they are not directly responsible and able to stand up for the interests of strata to which they themselves do not belong .
One of the great advantages of capitalism , Joseph Schumpeter argues , is that as compared with pre-capitalist periods , when education was a privilege of the few , more and more people acquire ( higher ) education .
The availability of fulfilling work is , however , limited , and this lack , coupled with the experience of unemployment , produces discontent .
In the journal Monthly Review John Bellamy Foster wrote of that journal 's founder Paul Sweezy , one of the leading Marxist economists in the United States and a graduate assistant of Schumpeter 's at Harvard , that Schumpeter `` played a formative role in Joseph Schumpeter development as a thinker '' .
The initial Schumpeter column praised Joseph Schumpeter as a `` champion of innovation and entrepreneurship '' whose writing showed an understanding of the benefits and dangers of business that proved to be far ahead of its time .
In 1060 , Ealdred was elected to the archbishopric of York , but had difficulty in obtaining papal approval for Ealdred (bishop) appointment , only managing to do so when Ealdred (bishop) promised not to hold the bishoprics of York and Worcester simultaneously .
William never quite trusted Ealdred or the other English leaders , and Ealdred had to accompany William back to Normandy in 1067 , but Ealdred (bishop) had returned to York by the time of Ealdred (bishop) death in 1069 .
Ealdred supported the churches and monasteries in Ealdred (bishop) diocese with gifts and building projects .
During Ealdred (bishop) tenure as abbot , Ealdred (bishop) supported the abbey with gifts ; the medieval chronicler William of Malmesbury said that they were splendid and many .
Lyfing died on 26 March 1046 , and Ealdred (bishop) became bishop of Worcester shortly after .
However , Ealdred (bishop) did not receive the other two dioceses that Lyfing had held , Crediton and Cornwall ; King Edward the Confessor ( reigned 1043 -- 1066 ) granted these to Leofric , who combined the two sees at Crediton in 1050 .
This was in retaliation for a raid led by the Welsh rulers Gruffydd ap Rhydderch , Rhys ap Rhydderch , and Gruffydd ap Llywelyn .
Ealdred (bishop) expedition was betrayed by some Welsh soldiers who were serving with the English , and Ealdred (bishop) was defeated .
In 1050 , Ealdred (bishop) went to Rome `` on the king 's errand '' , apparently to secure papal approval to move the seat , or centre , of the bishopric of Crediton to Exeter .
That same year , as Ealdred was returning to England Ealdred (bishop) met Sweyn , a son of Godwin , Earl of Wessex , and probably absolved Sweyn for having abducted the abbess of Leominster Abbey in 1046 .
Through Ealdred 's intercession , Sweyn was restored to Ealdred (bishop) earldom , which Ealdred (bishop) had lost after abducting the abbess and murdering Ealdred (bishop) brother Beorn .
In September 1052 , though , Godwin returned from exile and Ealdred (bishop) family was restored to power .
In this mission Ealdred (bishop) was somewhat successful and obtained insight into the working of the German church during a stay of a year with Hermann II , the Archbishop of Cologne .
After Ealdred 's return to England Ealdred (bishop) took charge of the sees of Hereford and Ramsbury .
The authors of the Handbook of British Chronology Third Edition say Ealdred (bishop) was named bishop of Hereford in 1056 , holding the see until Ealdred (bishop) resigned it in 1060 , but other sources say that Ealdred (bishop) merely administered the see while it was vacant , or that Ealdred (bishop) was bishop of Hereford from 1055 to 1060 .
Ealdred was rewarded with the administration of the see of Hereford , which Ealdred (bishop) held until 1061 , and was appointed Archbishop of York .
Ealdred (bishop) travelled through Hungary , and the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle stated that `` Ealdred (bishop) went to Jerusalem in such state as no-one had done before Ealdred (bishop) '' .
Cynesige , Ealdred (bishop) , died on 22 December 1060 , and Ealdred (bishop) was elected Archbishop of York on Christmas Day , 1060 .
William of Malmesbury says that Ealdred , by `` amusing the simplicity of King Edward and alleging the custom of Ealdred (bishop) predecessors , had acquired , more by bribery than by reason , the archbishopric of York while still holding Ealdred (bishop) former see '' .
Yet another chronicler , John of Worcester , mentions nothing of any trouble in Rome , and when discussing the appointment of Wulfstan , says that Wulfstan was elected freely and unanimously by the clergy and people .
For whatever reason , Ealdred (bishop) gave up the see of Worcester in 1062 , when papal legates arrived in England to hold a council and make sure that Ealdred (bishop) relinquished Worcester .
Ealdred (bishop) was succeeded by Wulfstan , chosen by Ealdred (bishop) , but John of Worcester relates that Ealdred (bishop) had a hard time deciding between Wulfstan and Æthelwig .
Stigand 's position as archbishop was canonically suspect , and as earl Harold had not allowed Stigand to consecrate one of the earl 's churches , it is unlikely that Harold would have allowed Stigand to perform the much more important royal coronation .
In all events , Ealdred (bishop) Ealdred (bishop) were close , and Ealdred (bishop) supported Harold 's bid to become king .
The Laudes Regiae , or song commending a ruler , that was performed at Matilda 's coronation may have been composed by Ealdred Ealdred (bishop) for the occasion .
In 1069 , when the northern thegns rebelled against William and attempted to install Edgar the Ætheling as king , Ealdred (bishop) continued to support William .
Ealdred was one of a few native Englishmen who William appears to have trusted , and Ealdred (bishop) death led to fewer attempts to integrate Englishmen into the administration , although such efforts did not entirely stop .
Ealdred (bishop) added a pulpit `` in German style '' of bronze , gold and silver , surmounted by an arch with a rood cross in the same materials ; these were examples of the lavish decorations added to important churches in the years before the conquest .
Ealdred (bishop) was known for Ealdred (bishop) generosity and for Ealdred (bishop) diplomatic and administrative abilities .
After the Conquest , Ealdred (bishop) provided a degree of continuity between the pre - and post-Conquest worlds .
Ealdred (bishop) is Abbot of Tavistock , Bishop of Worcester , and Archbishop of York in Anglo-Saxon England .
Ealdred (bishop) is suffragan , or subordinate bishop .
Ealdred (bishop) is an episcopus , or bishop , and a charter .
Ealdred (bishop) is an episcopus , or bishop .
Ealdred (bishop) is an episcopus , or bishop , .
Ealdred (bishop) is the one bishop that published ecclesiastical legislation during Edward the Confessor 's reign , attempting to discipline and reform the clergy .
John Lee Hooker ( August 22 , 1917 -- June 21 , 2001 ) was a highly influential American blues singer-songwriter and guitarist .
John Lee Hooker best known songs include `` Boogie Chillen ' '' ( 1948 ) , `` John Lee Hooker 'm in the Mood '' ( 1951 ) and `` Boom Boom '' ( 1962 ) , the first two reaching 1 on the Billboard R&B chart .
There is some debate as to the year of Hooker 's birth in Coahoma County , Mississippi , the youngest of the eleven children of William Hooker ( 1871 -- 1923 ) , a sharecropper and Baptist preacher , and Minnie Ramsey ( born 1875 , date of death unknown ) ; according to John Lee Hooker official website , John Lee Hooker was born on August 22 , 1917 .
The next year , John Lee Hooker mother married William Moore , a blues singer who provided Hooker with John Lee Hooker first introduction to the guitar ( and whom John would later credit for John Lee Hooker distinctive playing style ) .
Performing in Detroit clubs , John Lee Hooker popularity grew quickly and , seeking a louder instrument than John Lee Hooker acoustic guitar , John Lee Hooker bought John Lee Hooker first electric guitar .
John Lee Hooker last live in the studio recording on guitar and vocal was of a song John Lee Hooker wrote with Pete Sears called `` Elizebeth '' , featuring members of John Lee Hooker `` Coast to Coast Blues Band '' with Sears on piano .
Satires (Juvenal) are a collection of satirical poems by the Latin author Satires (Juvenal) written in the late 1st and early 2nd centuries AD .
Juvenal is credited with sixteen known poems divided among five books ; all are in the Roman genre of satire , which , at Satires (Juvenal) most basic in the time of the author , comprised a wide-ranging discussion of society and social mores in dactylic hexameter .
These five books were discrete works , and there is no reason to assume that Satires (Juvenal) were published at the same time or that they are identical in theme or in approach .
In a tone and manner ranging from irony to apparent rage , Satires (Juvenal) criticizes the actions and beliefs of many of his contemporaries , providing insight more into value systems and questions of morality and less into the realities of Roman life .
Satires (Juvenal) makes constant allusion to history and myth as a source of object lessons or exemplars of particular vices and virtues .
Coupled with his dense and elliptical Latin , these tangential references indicate that the intended reader of Satires (Juvenal) was highly educated .
At the same time as the Servian text was produced , however , other and lesser scholars also created their editions of Satires (Juvenal) : it is these on which most medieval manuscripts of Satires (Juvenal) are based .
These lines occur in no other manuscript of Satires (Juvenal) , and when discovered were considerably corrupted .
Ever since Housman translated and emended the `` O Passage '' there has been considerable controversy over whether the fragment is in fact a forgery : the field is currently split between those ( Green , Ferguson , Courtney ) who believe it is n't , and those ( Willis , Anderson ) , who believe it is .
This so-called `` Programmatic Satire '' lays out for the reader a catalogue of ills and annoyances that prompt the narrator to write satire .
Rather than being a performance of faux-equality , the patron ( Virro as in 9.35 ) emphasizes the superiority of himself and his peers ( amici ) over his clients ( viles amici ) by offering food and drink of unequal quality to each .
This satire is in the form of a dialogue between the narrator and Naevolus -- the disgruntled client of a pathetic patron .
The subject , in this instance , is the role of food and the cena ( formal dinner ) in Roman society .
Satires (Juvenal) is a collection of satirical poems by the Latin author Juvenal written in the late 1st and early 2nd centuries AD .
This was the period in which Jean Cocteau met the poet Guillaume Apollinaire , artists Pablo Picasso and Amedeo Modigliani , and numerous other writers and artists with whom Jean Cocteau later collaborated .
Jean Cocteau denied being a Surrealist or being in any way attached to the movement .
Jean Cocteau account , which includes vivid pen-and-ink illustrations , alternates between Jean Cocteau moment-to-moment experiences of drug withdrawal and Jean Cocteau current thoughts about people and events in Jean Cocteau world .
The story involves one woman on stage speaking on the telephone with her ( invisible and inaudible ) departing lover , who is leaving her to marry another woman .
Reviews varied at the time and since but whatever the critique , the play represents Cocteau 's state of mind and feelings towards Jean Cocteau actors at the time : on the one hand , Jean Cocteau wanted to spoil and please them ; on the other , Jean Cocteau was fed up by their diva antics and was ready for revenge .
It is also true that none of Jean Cocteau works has inspired as much imitation : Francis Poulenc 's opera La Voix humaine , Gian Carlo Menotti 's `` opera bouffa '' The Telephone and Roberto Rosselini 's film version in Italian with Anna Magnani L'Amore ( 1948 ) .
Jean Cocteau longest-lasting relationships were with the French actors Jean Marais and , whom Jean Cocteau formally adopted .
In 1940 , Le Bel Indifférent , Jean Cocteau play written for and starring Édith Piaf , was enormously successful .
Jean Cocteau is commander of the Legion of Honor , Member of the Mallarmé Academy , German Academy ( Berlin ) , American Academy , Mark Twain ( U.S.A ) Academy , Honorary President of the Cannes film festival , Honorary President of the France-Hungary Association and President of the Jazz Academy and of the Academy of the Disc .
John Donne ( between 24 January and 19 June 1572 -- 31 March 1631 ) was an English poet , satirist , lawyer and a cleric in the Church of England .
These features , along with John Donne frequent dramatic or everyday speech rhythms , John Donne tense syntax and John Donne tough eloquence , were both a reaction against the smoothness of conventional Elizabethan poetry and an adaptation into English of European baroque and mannerist techniques .
Though John Donne practised law and may have worked as an assistant pamphleteer to Thomas Morton , Donne was in a constant state of financial insecurity , with a growing family to provide for .
Some have speculated that Donne 's numerous illnesses , financial strain , and the deaths of John Donne friends all contributed to the development of a more somber and pious tone in John Donne later poems .
The lines of these sermons would come to influence future works of English literature , such as Ernest Hemingway 's For Whom the Bell Tolls , which took its title from a passage in of Devotions upon Emergent Occasions , and Thomas Merton 's No Man is an Island , which took its title from the same source .
One example of this challenge is John Donne Holy Sonnet X , Death Be Not Proud , from which come the famous lines `` Death , be not proud , though some have called thee / Mighty and dreadful , for thou art not so '' .
In Life of Cowley ( from Samuel Johnson 's 1781 work of biography and criticism Lives of the Most Eminent English Poets ) , Johnson refers to the beginning of the seventeenth century in which there `` appeared a race of writers that may be termed the metaphysical poets '' .
Unlike the conceits found in other Elizabethan poetry , most notably Petrarchan conceits , which formed clichéd comparisons between more closely related objects ( such as a rose and love ) , metaphysical conceits go to a greater depth in comparing two completely unlike objects .
Donne is noted for John Donne poetic metre , which was structured with changing and jagged rhythms that closely resemble casual speech ( it was for this that the more classical-minded Ben Jonson commented that `` Donne , for not keeping of accent , deserved hanging '' ) .
The exception to these is John Donne Anniversaries which were published in 1612 and Devotions upon Emergent Occasions published in 1624 .
Sylvia Plath , interviewed on BBC Radio in late 1962 , said the following about a book review of her collection of poems titled The Colossus and Other Poems that had been published in the United Kingdom two years earlier : `` John Donne remember being appalled when someone criticised John Donne for beginning just like John Donne but not quite managing to finish like John Donne , and John Donne felt the weight of English literature on John Donne at that point '' .
The memorial to John Donne , modelled after the engraving pictured above , was one of the few such memorials to survive the Great Fire of London in 1666 and now appears in St Paul 's Cathedral where John Donne is buried .
Jeffry Ross Hyman ( May 19 , 1951 -- April 15 , 2001 ) , best known by Joey Ramone stage name Joey Ramone , was an American musician , vocalist and songwriter , best known as the lead vocalist of the punk rock band the Ramones .
Within eight years of the breakup , the band 's three founding members -- Joey , Johnny , and Dee Dee -- had all died .
Ramone and 49 other recording artists -- including Bruce Springsteen , Keith Richards , Lou Reed and Run DMC -- collaborated on the song `` Sun City '' , in which they pledged they would never perform at the resort .
This was during U2 's Elevation Tour , and from that point on during shows Bono would introduce the song as a tune that was originally about a lovestruck hangover but that Joey turned it into a gospel song .
Hyman 's birthday is celebrated annually by rock 'n' roll nightclubs , hosted in New York City by Joey Ramone brother and , until 2007 , Joey Ramone mother , Charlotte .
In 2001 , the Ramones were named as inductees to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame , prior to the actual ceremony held early the following year .
In a famous passage that is often considered the first specimen of alternative history , Livy speculates on what would have been the outcome of a military showdown between Alexander the Great and the Roman Republic .
John Lennon , ( born John Lennon ; 9 October 1940 -- 8 December 1980 ) was an English musician , singer and songwriter who rose to worldwide fame as a founder member of the Beatles , one of the most commercially successful and critically acclaimed acts in the history of popular music .
Born and raised in Liverpool , as a teenager Lennon became involved in the skiffle craze ; John Lennon first band , the Quarrymen , evolved into the Beatles in 1960 .
Controversial through John Lennon political and peace activism , John Lennon moved to New York City in 1971 , where John Lennon criticism of the Vietnam War resulted in a lengthy attempt by Richard Nixon 's administration to deport John Lennon , while some of John Lennon songs were adopted as anthems by the anti-war movement .
John Lennon mother bought John Lennon John Lennon first guitar in 1956 , an inexpensive Gallotone Champion acoustic for which she `` lent '' her son five pounds and ten shillings on the condition that the guitar be delivered to her own house , and not Mimi 's , knowing well that her sister was not supportive of her son 's musical aspirations .
In August that year , the Beatles engaged for a 48-night residency in Hamburg , Germany , and desperately in need of a drummer , asked Pete Best to join them .
After the first Hamburg residency , John Lennon accepted another in April 1961 , and a third in April 1962 .
They recorded their debut album , Please Please John Lennon , in under 10 hours on 11 February 1963 , a day when Lennon was suffering the effects of a cold , which is evident in the vocal on the last song to be recorded that day , `` Twist and Shout '' .
1967 saw the release of `` Strawberry Fields Forever '' , hailed by Time magazine for its `` astonishing inventiveness '' , and the group 's landmark album Sgt.
Lennon described the venture as an attempt to achieve , `` artistic freedom within a business structure '' , but John Lennon increased drug experimentation and growing preoccupation with Yoko Ono , and McCartney 's own marriage plans , left Apple in need of professional management .
The supergroup , composed of John Lennon , Eric Clapton , Keith Richards and Mitch Mitchell , also backed a vocal performance by Ono in the film .
John Lennon spoke too of the hostility John Lennon perceived the other members had towards Ono , and of how John Lennon , Harrison , and Starr `` got fed up with being sidemen for Paul ... After Brian Epstein died we collapsed .
The album featured the songs `` Mother '' , in which Lennon confronted John Lennon feelings of childhood rejection , and the Dylanesque `` Working Class Hero '' , a bitter attack against the bourgeois social system which , due to the lyric `` you 're still fucking peasants '' , fell foul of broadcasters .
, was a musical attack on McCartney in response to lyrics from Ram that Lennon felt , and McCartney later confirmed , were directed at John Lennon and Ono .
Containing songs about women 's rights , race relations , Britain 's role in Northern Ireland and John Lennon problems obtaining a green card , the album was poorly received -- unlistenable , according to one critic .
While Lennon was recording Mind Games ( 1973 ) , John Lennon and Ono decided to separate .
The ensuing 18-month period apart , which John Lennon later called John Lennon `` lost weekend '' , was spent in Los Angeles and New York in the company of May Pang .
Settled back in New York , John Lennon recorded the album Walls and Bridges .
The Beatles ' song `` Getting Better '' , John Lennon said , told John Lennon own story , `` John Lennon used to be cruel to John Lennon woman , and physically -- any woman .
The MC , known for John Lennon wordplay and affectionate but cutting remarks , was making a joke , but ten months had passed since Lennon 's marriage , and the honeymoon , deferred , was still two months in the future .
Julian recalls that John Lennon and John Lennon father `` got on a great deal better '' during the time John Lennon spent in New York : `` We had a lot of fun , laughed a lot and had a great time in general '' .
John Lennon , hitherto inhibited by Ono in this regard , began to reestablish contact with other relatives and friends .
By glaring omission ... John Lennon influence on John Lennon life is absolutely zilch ... John Lennon remembers every two-bit sax player or guitarist John Lennon met in subsequent years .
Later that year , Lennon and Ono supported efforts by the family of James Hanratty , hanged for murder in 1962 , to prove John Lennon innocence .
Lennon and Ono , backed by David Peel and Rubin , performed an acoustic set of four songs from their forthcoming Some Time in New York City album including `` John Sinclair '' , whose lyrics called for John Lennon release .
Following the Bloody Sunday incident in Northern Ireland in 1972 , in which 14 unarmed civil rights protesters were shot dead by the British Army , Lennon said that given the choice between the army and the IRA ( who were not involved in the incident ) John Lennon would side with the latter .
According to FBI surveillance reports ( and confirmed by Tariq Ali in 2006 ) John Lennon was sympathetic to the International Marxist Group , a Trotskyist group formed in Britain in 1968 .
Following the impact of `` Give Peace a Chance '' and `` Happy Xmas ( War Is Over ) '' , both strongly associated with the anti -- Vietnam War movement , the Nixon administration , hearing rumours of Lennon 's involvement in a concert to be held in San Diego at the same time as the Republican National Convention , tried to have John Lennon deported .
The country 's got plenty of room and space .
In response , John Lennon and Ono held a press conference on 1 April 1973 at the New York City Bar Association , where they announced the formation of the state of Nutopia ; a place with `` no land , no boundaries , no passports , only people '' .
Above was a flying pancake , and below , `` a blind man wearing glasses leading along a blind dog -- also wearing glasses '' .
Harry writes that In John Lennon Own Write ( 1964 ) was published after `` Some journalist who was hanging around The Beatles came to John Lennon and John Lennon ended up showing John Lennon the stuff .
Lennon was not only surprised by the positive reception , but that the book was reviewed at all , and suggested that readers `` took the book more seriously than John Lennon did myself .
In combination with A Spaniard in the Works ( 1965 ) , In John Lennon Own Write formed the basis of the stage play The John Lennon Play : In John Lennon Own Write , co-adapted by Victor Spinetti and Adrienne Kennedy .
After negotiations between John Lennon , Spinetti and the artistic director of the National Theatre , Sir Laurence Olivier , the play opened at the Old Vic in 1968 .
As John Lennon career progressed , John Lennon played a variety of electric guitars , predominantly the Rickenbacker 325 , Epiphone Casino and Gibson J-160E , and , from the start of John Lennon solo career , the Gibson Les Paul Junior .
When the Beatles recorded `` Twist and Shout '' , the final track during the mammoth one-day session that produced the band 's 1963 debut album , Please Please John Lennon , Lennon 's voice , already compromised by a cold , came close to giving out .
Wiener too describes contrasts , saying John Lennon voice can be `` at first subdued ; soon it almost cracks with despair '' Music historian Ben Urish recalls hearing the Beatles ' Ed Sullivan Show performance of `` This Boy '' played on the radio a few days after John Lennon murder : `` As John Lennon vocals reached their peak ... it hurt too much to hear him scream with such anguish and emotion .
Music historians Schinder and Schwartz , writing of the transformation in popular music styles that took place between the 1950s and the 1960s , say that the Beatles ' influence can not be overstated : having `` revolutionised the sound , style , and attitude of popular music and opened rock and roll 's doors to a tidal wave of British rock acts '' , the group then `` spent the rest of the 1960s expanding rock 's stylistic frontiers '' .
That willingness to take risks with John Lennon career , and John Lennon life , is one reason why people still admire John Lennon today '' .
Double Fantasy , released shortly before John Lennon death , and John Lennon best-selling , post-Beatles ' studio album at three million shipments in the US , won the 1981 Grammy Award for Album of the Year .
John Cleese and Chapman 's sketches often involved authority figures , some of which were performed by John Cleese , while Jones and Palin were both infatuated with filmed scenes that open with idyllic countryside panoramas .
Such was the popularity of the series that in 1966 John Cleese and Chapman were invited to work as writers and performers with Brooke-Taylor and Feldman on At Last the 1948 Show , during which time the Four Yorkshiremen sketch was written by all four writers/performers ( the Four Yorkshiremen sketch is now better known as a Monty Python sketch ) .
Unlike Palin and Jones , Cleese and Chapman actually wrote together -- in the same room ; Cleese claims that their writing partnership involved John Cleese sitting with pen and paper , doing most of the work , while Chapman sat back , not speaking for long periods , then suddenly coming out with an idea that often elevated the sketch to a different level .
A classic example of this is the `` Dead Parrot '' sketch , envisaged by John Cleese as a satire on poor customer service , which was originally to have involved a broken toaster and later a broken car ( this version was actually performed and broadcast on the pre-Python special How To Irritate People ) .
All of these roles were opposite Palin ( who Cleese often claims is John Cleese favourite Python to work with ) -- the comic contrast between the towering Cleese 's crazed aggression and the shorter Palin 's shuffling inoffensiveness is a common feature in the series .
Despite this , John Cleese remained friendly with the group , and all six began writing Monty Python and the Holy Grail ; Cleese received a credit on three episodes of the fourth series which used material from these sessions , though John Cleese was officially unconnected with the fourth series .
Fawlty Towers consisted of only twelve episodes ; John Cleese and Booth both maintain that this was to avoid compromising the quality of the series .

The books are presented as a dialogue between Skynner and John Cleese .
The follow-up to A Fish Called Wanda , Fierce Creatures -- which again starred John Cleese alongside Kevin Kline , Jamie Lee Curtis , and Michael Palin -- was also released that year , but was greeted with mixed reception by critics and audiences .
John Cleese has since appeared in broadcasts for the Liberal Democrats , in the 1997 general election and narrating a radio election broadcast for the party during the 2001 general election .
In 2011 , Cleese declared John Cleese admiration for Britain 's coalition government between the Conservatives and Liberal Democrats , saying : `` John Cleese think what 's happening at the moment is rather interesting .
Outgoing leader of the Liberal Democrats , Paddy Ashdown , had put forward the suggestion shortly before John Cleese stepped down , with the idea that Cleese would take the party whip and sit as a working peer , but the actor quipped that John Cleese `` realised this involved being in England in the winter and John Cleese thought that was too much of a price to pay '' .
