Alexander governed tyrannically , and according to Diodorus , differently from the former rulers , but Polyphron , at least , seems to have set Alexander of Pherae the example .
During the next three years , Alexander seemed to renew Alexander of Pherae attempts to subdue the states of Thessaly , especially Magnesia and Phthiotis , for upon the expiry of the truce , in 364 BC , they again applied to Thebes for protection from Alexander of Pherae .
The Theban army under Pelopidas is said to have been dismayed by an eclipse ( on July 13 , 364 , see 4th century BC eclipses ) , and Pelopidas , leaving the bulk of Alexander of Pherae army behind , entered Thessaly at the head of three hundred volunteer horsemen and some mercenaries .
John Lynch (New Hampshire) ( born November 25 , 1952 ) is an American businessman and politician who served as the 80th Governor of the U.S. State of New Hampshire .
As a candidate for Governor , John Lynch (New Hampshire) took `` The Pledge '' not to enact any broad-based taxes , especially a Sales or Income tax .
In 2007 , John Lynch (New Hampshire) signed into law the Research and Development Tax credit which , for the following five years , appropriated $ 1,000,000 for companies to write off qualifying `` manufacturing research and development '' expenditures .
John Lynch (New Hampshire) was rated the `` Safest State '' in the Nation in 2008 and 2009 .
John Lynch (New Hampshire) is an American businessman and politician who served as the 80th Governor of the U.S. State of New Hampshire .
J. R. R. Tolkien served as the Rawlinson and Bosworth Professor of Anglo-Saxon at Pembroke College , Oxford , from 1925 to 1945 and Merton Professor of English Language and Literature at Merton College , Oxford from 1945 to 1959 .
After J. R. R. Tolkien death , Tolkien 's son Christopher published a series of works based on J. R. R. Tolkien father 's extensive notes and unpublished manuscripts , including The Silmarillion .
These , together with The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings form a connected body of tales , poems , fictional histories , invented languages , and literary essays about a fantasy world called Arda , and Middle-earth within it .
Between 1951 and 1955 , Tolkien applied the term legendarium to the larger part of these writings .
This has caused Tolkien to be popularly identified as the `` father '' of modern fantasy literature -- or , more precisely , of high fantasy .
As a child , J. R. R. Tolkien was bitten by a large baboon spider in the garden , an event which some think would have later echoes in J. R. R. Tolkien stories , although Tolkien admitted no actual memory of the event and no special hatred of spiders as an adult .
When J. R. R. Tolkien was three , J. R. R. Tolkien went to England with J. R. R. Tolkien mother and brother on what was intended to be a lengthy family visit .
J. R. R. Tolkien enjoyed exploring Sarehole Mill and Moseley Bog and the Clent , Lickey and Malvern Hills , which would later inspire scenes in J. R. R. Tolkien books , along with Worcestershire towns and villages such as Bromsgrove , Alcester , and Alvechurch and places such as J. R. R. Tolkien aunt Jane 's farm of Bag End , the name of which would be used in J. R. R. Tolkien fiction .
Mabel Tolkien herself taught her two children , and Ronald , as J. R. R. Tolkien was known in the family , was a keen pupil .
Young Tolkien liked to draw landscapes and trees , but J. R. R. Tolkien favourite lessons were those concerning languages , and J. R. R. Tolkien mother taught J. R. R. Tolkien the rudiments of Latin very early .
J. R. R. Tolkien liked stories about `` Red Indians '' and the fantasy works by George MacDonald .
In addition , the `` Fairy Books '' of Andrew Lang were particularly important to J. R. R. Tolkien and their influence is apparent in some of J. R. R. Tolkien later writings .
Nine years after J. R. R. Tolkien mother 's death , Tolkien wrote , `` J. R. R. Tolkien own dear mother was a martyr indeed , and it is not to everybody that God grants so easy a way to J. R. R. Tolkien great gifts as J. R. R. Tolkien did to Hilary and myself , giving us a mother who killed herself with labour and trouble to ensure us keeping the faith '' .
J. R. R. Tolkien lived there in the shadow of Perrott 's Folly and the Victorian tower of Edgbaston Waterworks , which may have influenced the images of the dark towers within J. R. R. Tolkien works .
Another strong influence was the romantic medievalist paintings of Edward Burne-Jones and the Pre-Raphaelite Brotherhood ; the Birmingham Museum and Art Gallery had a large collection of works on public display .
While in J. R. R. Tolkien early teens , Tolkien had J. R. R. Tolkien first encounter with a constructed language , Animalic , an invention of J. R. R. Tolkien cousins , Mary and Marjorie Incledon .
At that time , J. R. R. Tolkien was studying Latin and Anglo-Saxon .
Interest in the language soon died away , but Mary and others , including Tolkien J. R. R. Tolkien , invented a new and more complex language called Nevbosh .
The 1911 census of England and Wales shows Tolkien ( occupation `` school '' ) lodging at 4 Highfield Road , Edgbaston , along with J. R. R. Tolkien brother Hilary ( occupation `` hardware merchant 's clerk '' ) .
In 1911 , Tolkien went on a summer holiday in Switzerland , a trip that J. R. R. Tolkien recollects vividly in a 1968 letter , noting that Bilbo 's journey across the Misty Mountains ( `` including the glissade down the slithering stones into the pine woods '' ) is directly based on J. R. R. Tolkien adventures as their party of 12 hiked from Interlaken to Lauterbrunnen and on to camp in the moraines beyond Mürren .
Fifty-seven years later , Tolkien remembered J. R. R. Tolkien regret at leaving the view of the eternal snows of Jungfrau and Silberhorn ( `` the Silvertine ( Celebdil ) of J. R. R. Tolkien dreams '' ) .
J. R. R. Tolkien initially studied Classics but changed J. R. R. Tolkien course in 1913 to English Language and Literature , graduating in 1915 with first-class honours in J. R. R. Tolkien final examinations .
Tolkien wrote that the experience taught J. R. R. Tolkien , ' a deep sympathy and feeling for the Tommy ; especially the plain soldier from the agricultural counties ' .
A weak and emaciated Tolkien spent the remainder of the war alternating between hospitals and garrison duties , being deemed medically unfit for general service .
When J. R. R. Tolkien was stationed at Kingston upon Hull , J. R. R. Tolkien and Edith went walking in the woods at nearby Roos , and Edith began to dance for J. R. R. Tolkien in a clearing among the flowering hemlock .
It was first conceived in a small woodland glade filled with hemlocks at Roos in Yorkshire ( where J. R. R. Tolkien was for a brief time in command of an outpost of the Humber Garrison in 1917 , and she was able to live with J. R. R. Tolkien for a while ) .
But the story has gone crooked , & I am left , and J. R. R. Tolkien can not plead before the inexorable Mandos .
Tolkien 's first civilian job after World War J. R. R. Tolkien was at the Oxford English Dictionary , where J. R. R. Tolkien worked mainly on the history and etymology of words of Germanic origin beginning with the letter W .
While at Leeds , J. R. R. Tolkien produced A Middle English Vocabulary and a definitive edition of Sir Gawain and the Green Knight with E. V. Gordon , both becoming academic standard works for several decades .
J. R. R. Tolkien also translated Sir Gawain , Pearl , and Sir Orfeo .
In 1925 , J. R. R. Tolkien returned to Oxford as Rawlinson and Bosworth Professor of Anglo-Saxon , with a fellowship at Pembroke College .
During J. R. R. Tolkien time at Pembroke College Tolkien wrote The Hobbit and the first two volumes of The Lord of the Rings , whilst living at 20 Northmoor Road in North Oxford ( where a blue plaque was placed in 2002 ) .
In the essay , Tolkien also revealed how highly he regarded Beowulf : `` Beowulf is among J. R. R. Tolkien most valued sources , '' and this influence may be seen throughout J. R. R. Tolkien Middle-earth legendarium .
In 2003 , Tolkien 's handwritten translation of and commentary on Beowulf , running to roughly 2000 pages , was discovered in the archives of the Bodleian Library .
In 1945 , Tolkien moved to Merton College , Oxford , becoming the Merton Professor of English Language and Literature , in which post J. R. R. Tolkien remained until J. R. R. Tolkien retirement in 1959 .
The Tolkiens had four children : John Francis Reuel Tolkien ( 17 November 1917 -- 22 January 2003 ) , Michael Hilary Reuel Tolkien ( 22 October 1920 -- 27 February 1984 ) , Christopher John Reuel Tolkien ( born 21 November 1924 ) and Priscilla Mary Anne Reuel Tolkien ( born 18 June 1929 ) .
During J. R. R. Tolkien life in retirement , from 1959 up to J. R. R. Tolkien death in 1973 , Tolkien received steadily increasing public attention and literary fame .
Fan attention became so intense that Tolkien had to take J. R. R. Tolkien phone number out of the public directory , and eventually J. R. R. Tolkien and Edith moved to Bournemouth , which was then a seaside resort patronized by the British upper middle class .
According to Humphrey Carpenter , Those friends who knew Ronald and Edith Tolkien over the years never doubted that there was deep affection between them .
It was visible in the small things , the almost absurd degree in which each worried about the other 's health , and the care in which they chose and wrapped each other 's birthday presents ' ; and in the large matters , the way in which Ronald willingly abandoned such a large part of J. R. R. Tolkien life in retirement to give Edith the last years in Bournemouth that J. R. R. Tolkien felt she deserved , and the degree in which she showed pride in J. R. R. Tolkien fame as an author .
`` J. R. R. Tolkien grandmother died two years before J. R. R. Tolkien grandfather and J. R. R. Tolkien came back to live in Oxford .
J. R. R. Tolkien went there frequently and J. R. R. Tolkien 'd take J. R. R. Tolkien to lunch in the Eastgate Hotel .
Tolkien was a devout Roman Catholic , and in J. R. R. Tolkien religious and political views J. R. R. Tolkien was mostly a traditionalist moderate , with libertarian and monarchist leanings , in the sense of favouring established conventions and orthodoxies over innovation and modernization , whilst castigating state controls ; in 1943 J. R. R. Tolkien wrote , `` J. R. R. Tolkien political opinions lean more and more to Anarchy ( philosophically understood , meaning abolition of control not whiskered men with bombs ) -- or to ` unconstitutional ' Monarchy '' .
Tolkien had an intense dislike for the side effects of industrialization , which J. R. R. Tolkien considered to be devouring the English countryside and simpler life .
Many commentators have remarked on a number of potential parallels between the Middle-earth saga and events in Tolkien 's lifetime .
This theme is taken up at greater length in J. R. R. Tolkien essay `` On Fairy-Stories '' , where J. R. R. Tolkien argues that fairy-stories are so apt because they are consistent both within themselves and with some truths about reality .
J. R. R. Tolkien love of myths and J. R. R. Tolkien devout faith came together in J. R. R. Tolkien assertion that J. R. R. Tolkien believed mythology to be the divine echo of `` the Truth '' .
In the last years of J. R. R. Tolkien life , Tolkien became greatly disappointed by some of the liturgical reforms and changes implemented after the Second Vatican Council , as J. R. R. Tolkien grandson Simon Tolkien recalls : J. R. R. Tolkien vividly remember going to church with J. R. R. Tolkien in Bournemouth .
Well , well , -- you and J. R. R. Tolkien can do nothing about it .
The Germans have just as much right to declare the Poles and Jews exterminable vermin , subhuman , as we have to select the Germans : in other words , no right , whatever they have done .
J. R. R. Tolkien was horrified by the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki , referring to the scientists of the Manhattan Project as `` these lunatic physicists '' and `` Babel-builders '' .
Tolkien wished to imitate Morris 's prose and poetry romances , from which J. R. R. Tolkien took hints for the names of features such as the Dead Marshes in The Lord of the Rings and Mirkwood , along with some general aspects of approach .
A supposed facsimile of this potsherd appeared in Haggard 's first edition , and the ancient inscription it bore , once translated , led the English characters to She 's ancient kingdom .
Critics starting with Edwin Muir have found resemblances between Haggard 's romances and Tolkien 's .
Tolkien was much inspired by early Germanic , especially Old English , literature , poetry , and mythology , which were J. R. R. Tolkien chosen and much-loved areas of expertise .
Despite the similarities of J. R. R. Tolkien work to the Volsunga saga and the Nibelungenlied , which were the basis for Richard Wagner 's opera cycle Der Ring des Nibelungen , Tolkien dismissed critics ' direct comparisons to Wagner , telling J. R. R. Tolkien publisher , `` Both rings were round , and there the resemblance ceases '' .
J. R. R. Tolkien goes on to argue that in The Lord of the Rings evil does sometimes seem to be an independent force , more than merely the absence of good ( though not independent to the point of the Manichaean heresy ) , and suggests that Alfred 's additions to J. R. R. Tolkien translation of Boethius may have inspired that view .
As for the poem , one dragon , however hot , does not make a summer , or a host ; and a man might well exchange for one good dragon what J. R. R. Tolkien would not sell for a wilderness .
J. R. R. Tolkien wrote annual Christmas letters from Father Christmas for them , building up a series of short stories ( later compiled and published as The Father Christmas Letters ) .
Roverandom and Smith of Wootton Major , like The Hobbit , borrowed ideas from J. R. R. Tolkien legendarium .
Tolkien spent more than ten years writing the primary narrative and appendices for The Lord of the Rings , during which time J. R. R. Tolkien received the constant support of the Inklings , in particular J. R. R. Tolkien closest friend Lewis , the author of The Chronicles of Narnia .
In 2002 Tolkien was voted the 92nd `` greatest Briton '' in a poll conducted by the BBC , and in 2004 J. R. R. Tolkien was voted 35th in the SABC3 's Great South Africans , the only person to appear in both lists .
Tolkien desperately hoped to publish it along with The Lord of the Rings , but publishers ( both Allen & Unwin and Collins ) got cold feet .
In subsequent years ( 1983 -- 1996 ) J. R. R. Tolkien published a large amount of the remaining unpublished materials , together with notes and extensive commentary , in a series of twelve volumes called The History of Middle-earth .
The novel tells the story of Túrin Turambar and J. R. R. Tolkien sister Nienor , children of Húrin Thalion .
The work , which was released worldwide on 5 May 2009 by Houghton Mifflin Harcourt and HarperCollins , retells the legend of Sigurd and the fall of the Niflungs from Germanic mythology .
Christopher Tolkien supplied copious notes and commentary upon J. R. R. Tolkien father 's work .
For J. R. R. Tolkien part , J. R. R. Tolkien can not recall any conversation with J. R. R. Tolkien on the subject until very near the end of J. R. R. Tolkien life , when J. R. R. Tolkien spoke of them to J. R. R. Tolkien , and tried unsuccessfully to find them '' .
In a 1967 letter to W. H. Auden , Tolkien wrote , `` Thank you for your wonderful effort in translating and reorganizing The Song of the Sibyl .
Before J. R. R. Tolkien death Tolkien negotiated the sale of the manuscripts , drafts , proofs and other materials related to J. R. R. Tolkien then-published works -- including The Lord of the Rings , The Hobbit and Farmer Giles of Ham -- to the Department of Special Collections and University Archives at Marquette University 's John P. Raynor , S.J. , Library in Milwaukee , Wisconsin .
After J. R. R. Tolkien death J. R. R. Tolkien estate donated the papers containing Tolkien 's Silmarillion mythology and J. R. R. Tolkien academic work to Oxford University 's Bodleian Library .
Both Tolkien 's academic career and J. R. R. Tolkien literary production are inseparable from J. R. R. Tolkien love of language and philology .
J. R. R. Tolkien worked for the Oxford English Dictionary from 1918 and is credited with having worked on a number of words starting with the letter W , including walrus , over which J. R. R. Tolkien struggled mightily .
J. R. R. Tolkien gave courses in Old English heroic verse , history of English , various Old English and Middle English texts , Old and Middle English philology , introductory Germanic philology , Gothic , Old Icelandic , and Medieval Welsh .
When in 1925 , aged thirty-three , Tolkien applied for the Rawlinson and Bosworth Professorship of Anglo-Saxon at Pembroke College , Oxford , J. R. R. Tolkien boasted that J. R. R. Tolkien students of Germanic philology in Leeds had even formed a `` Viking Club '' .
Privately , Tolkien was attracted to `` things of racial and linguistic significance '' , and in J. R. R. Tolkien 1955 lecture English and Welsh , which is crucial to J. R. R. Tolkien understanding of race and language , J. R. R. Tolkien entertained notions of `` inherent linguistic predilections '' , which J. R. R. Tolkien termed the `` native language '' as opposed to the `` cradle-tongue '' which a person first learns to speak .
J. R. R. Tolkien considered the West Midlands dialect of Middle English to be J. R. R. Tolkien own `` native language '' , and , as J. R. R. Tolkien wrote to W. H. Auden in 1955 , `` J. R. R. Tolkien am a West-midlander by blood ( and took to early west-midland Middle English as a known tongue as soon as J. R. R. Tolkien set eyes on it ) '' .
Tolkien learned Latin , French , and German from J. R. R. Tolkien mother , and while at school J. R. R. Tolkien learned Middle English , Old English , Finnish , Gothic , Greek , Italian , Old Norse , Spanish , Welsh , and Medieval Welsh .
J. R. R. Tolkien was also familiar with Danish , Dutch , Lombardic , Norwegian , Russian , Serbian , Swedish and older forms of modern Germanic and Slavonic languages , revealing J. R. R. Tolkien deep linguistic knowledge , above all of the Germanic languages .
Parallel to Tolkien 's professional work as a philologist , and sometimes overshadowing this work , to the effect that J. R. R. Tolkien academic output remained rather thin , was J. R. R. Tolkien affection for constructing languages .
The most developed of these are Quenya and Sindarin , the etymological connection between which formed the core of much of Tolkien 's legendarium .
A notable addition came in late 1945 with Adûnaic or Númenórean , a language of a `` faintly Semitic flavour '' , connected with Tolkien 's Atlantis legend , which by The Notion Club Papers ties directly into J. R. R. Tolkien ideas about inability of language to be inherited , and via the `` Second Age '' and the story of Eärendil was grounded in the legendarium , thereby providing a link of Tolkien 's 20th-century `` real primary world '' with the legendary past of J. R. R. Tolkien Middle-earth .
Tolkien considered languages inseparable from the mythology associated with them , and J. R. R. Tolkien consequently took a dim view of auxiliary languages : in 1930 a congress of Esperantists were told as much by J. R. R. Tolkien , in J. R. R. Tolkien lecture A Secret Vice , `` Your language construction will breed a mythology '' , but by 1956 J. R. R. Tolkien had concluded that `` Volapük , Esperanto , Ido , Novial , & c , & c , are dead , far deader than ancient unused languages , because their authors never invented any Esperanto legends '' .
In a 1951 letter to Milton Waldman , Tolkien wrote about J. R. R. Tolkien intentions to create a `` body of more or less connected legend '' , of which `` the cycles should be linked to a majestic whole , and yet leave scope for other minds and hands , wielding paint and music and drama '' .
Personally known to J. R. R. Tolkien were Pauline Baynes ( Tolkien 's favourite illustrator of The Adventures of Tom Bombadil and Farmer Giles of Ham ) and Donald Swann ( who set the music to The Road Goes Ever On ) .
In 1946 , J. R. R. Tolkien rejected suggestions for illustrations by Horus Engels for the German edition of The Hobbit as `` too Disnified ... Bilbo with a dribbling nose , and Gandalf as a figure of vulgar fun rather than the Odinic wanderer that J. R. R. Tolkien think of '' .
J. R. R. Tolkien was not implacably opposed to the idea of a dramatic adaptation , however , and sold the film , stage and merchandise rights of The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings to United Artists in 1968 .
In 1977 an animated TV production of The Hobbit was made by Rankin-Bass , and in 1980 they produced an animated The Return of the King , which covered some of the portions of The Lord of the Rings that Bakshi was unable to complete .
In the Dutch town of Geldrop , near Eindhoven , the streets of an entire new neighbourhood are named after Tolkien himself ( `` Laan van Tolkien '' ) and some of the best-known characters from J. R. R. Tolkien books .
In the Silicon Valley towns of Saratoga and San Jose in California , there are two housing developments with street names drawn from Tolkien 's works .
At the University of California at Davis are `` Baggins End Innovative Housing '' , an on-campus commune consisting of 14 polyurethane-insulated fibreglass domes , and an off-campus development known as `` Village Homes '' , a planned community designed to be ecologically sustainable and whose street names are taken from The Lord of the Rings .
The Columbia , Maryland , neighbourhood of Hobbit 's Glen and its street names ( including Rivendell Lane , Tooks Way , and Oakenshield Circle ) come from Tolkien 's works .
In Weston-super-Mare , Somerset , England there are a collection of roads in the ` Weston Village ' named after locales of the Middle Earth ; Hobbiton Road , Bree Close , Arnor Close , Rivendell , Westmarch Way and Buckland Green .
One of the Birmingham plaques commemorates the inspiration provided by Sarehole Mill , near which J. R. R. Tolkien lived between the ages of four and eight , while two mark childhood homes up to the time J. R. R. Tolkien left to attend Oxford University and the other marks a hotel J. R. R. Tolkien stayed at before leaving for France during World War I .
The plaque in West Park , Leeds , commemorates the five years Tolkien enjoyed at Leeds as Reader and then Professor of English Language at the University .
Owing to J. R. R. Tolkien popularity , handsigned copies of J. R. R. Tolkien letters or of the first editions of J. R. R. Tolkien individual writings have however achieved high values at auctions , and forged autographs may occur on the market .
J. R. R. Tolkien is an English writer , poet , philologist , and university professor .
J. R. R. Tolkien is a West-midlander by blood ( and took to early west-midland Middle English as a known tongue as soon as I set eyes on it ) .
Cabell 's supposed involvement in the Scott murder and James Branch Cabell college `` scandal '' were both mentioned in Ellen Glasgow 's posthumously published ( 1954 ) autobiography The Woman Within .
Between 1911 and 1913 , James Branch Cabell was employed by James Branch Cabell uncle in the office of the Branch coalmines in West Virginia .
Today , the modern languages house and an endowed law professorship at the College of William and Mary are named in James Branch Cabell honor .
The case went on for two years before Cabell and James Branch Cabell publisher , Robert M. McBride , won : the `` indecencies '' were double entendres that also had a perfectly decent interpretation , though it appeared that what had actually offended the prosecution most was a joke about papal infallibility .
A number of the volumes of the Biography were also published in editions illustrated by Frank C. Papé between 1921 and 1926 .
James Branch Cabell later novel , The First Gentleman of America : A Comedy of Conquest ( 1942 ) , retells the strange career of an American Indian from the shores of the Potomac who sailed away with Spanish explorers , later to return , be made chief of James Branch Cabell tribe , and kill all the Spaniards in the new Virginia settlement .
James Blish was a fan of Cabell 's works , and for a time edited Kalki , the journal of the Cabell Society .
Cabell was also a major influence on Neil Gaiman , acknowledged as such in the rear of Gaiman 's novels Stardust and American Gods .
This thematic and stylistic influence is highly evident in the multi-layered pantheons of Gaiman 's most famous work , The Sandman , which have many parallels in Cabell 's work , particularly Jurgen .
Swanwick places much of the blame for Cabell 's obscurity on Cabell James Branch Cabell , for authorising the 18-volume Storisende uniform edition of the Biography of the Life of Manuel , including much that was of poor quality and ephemeral .
Alexander II of Epirus was a king of Epirus , and the son of Pyrrhus and Lanassa , the daughter of the Sicilian tyrant Agathocles .
Alexander II of Epirus was , however , dispossessed of both Macedon and Epirus by Demetrius II of Macedon , the son of Antigonus II ; upon which Alexander II of Epirus took refuge amongst the Acarnanians .
By their assistance and that of Alexander II of Epirus own subjects , who entertained a great attachment for Alexander II of Epirus , Alexander II of Epirus recovered Epirus .
Alexander II of Epirus is a king of Epirus , and the son of Pyrrhus and Lanassa , the daughter of the Sicilian tyrant Agathocles .
The language derives much of Java (programming language) syntax from C and C++ , but Java (programming language) has fewer low-level facilities than either of them .
Because Java lacks any formal standardization recognized by Ecma International , ISO/IEC , ANSI , or other third-party standards organization , the Oracle implementation is the de facto standard .
This resulted in a legal dispute with Microsoft after Sun claimed that the Microsoft implementation did not support RMI or JNI and had added platform-specific features of their own .
Programs written in Java (programming language) have a reputation for being slower and requiring more memory than those written in C++ .
Java (programming language) does not support C/C + + style pointer arithmetic , where object addresses and unsigned integers ( usually long integers ) can be used interchangeably .
As in C++ and some other object-oriented languages , variables of Java 's primitive data types are not objects .
The effect of this alternate declaration is semantically identical ( the args parameter is still an array of String objects ) , but Java (programming language) allows an alternative syntax for creating and passing the array .
Criticisms directed at Java (programming language) include the implementation of generics , speed , the handling of unsigned numbers , the implementation of floating-point arithmetic , and a history of security vulnerabilities in the primary Java VM implementation HotSpot .
Google and Android , Inc. have chosen to use Java (programming language) as a key pillar in the creation of the Android operating system , an open-source smartphone operating system .
Gaikai ( Japanese for `` open ocean '' ) is a cloud-based gaming service that allows users to play high-end PC and console games via the cloud and instantly demo games and applications from a webpage on any computer or internet-connected device .
Javadoc comments have an extra asterisk at the beginning , i.e. the tags are / Sun has defined and supports four editions of Java targeting different application environments and segmented many of Java (programming language) APIs so that Java (programming language) belong to one of the platforms .
Jason ( , Iásōn ) was an ancient Greek mythological hero who was famous for his role as the leader of the Argonauts and their quest for the Golden Fleece .
Jason , knowing that he was the rightful king , told Pelias that and Pelias said , `` To take my throne , which you shall , you must go on a quest to find the Golden Fleece '' .
The men then took concubines from the Thracian mainland opposite , and the spurned women , angry at Aphrodite , killed all the male inhabitants while Jason slept .
Medea distracted her father , who chased them as they fled , by killing her brother Apsyrtus and throwing pieces of his body into the sea ; Aeetes stopped to gather them .
The girls , rather naively , sliced and diced their father and put him in the cauldron .
When Medea confronted Jason about the engagement and cited all the help she had given him , he retorted that it was not she that he should thank , but Aphrodite who made Medea fall in love with him .
Infuriated with Jason for breaking his vow that he would be hers forever , Medea took her revenge by presenting to Creusa a cursed dress , as a wedding gift , that stuck to her body and burned her to death as soon as she put it on .
The Oral Law is the oral tradition , as relayed by God to Moses and from Judah ha-Nasi , transmitted and taught to the sages ( rabbinic leaders ) of each subsequent generation For centuries , the Torah appeared only as a written text transmitted in parallel with the oral tradition .
This completed a project which had been mostly clarified and organized by Judah ha-Nasi father and Rabbi Natan .
Alexander Jagiellon was elected Grand Duke of Lithuania on the death of Alexander Jagiellon father ( 1492 ) , and King of Poland on the death of Alexander Jagiellon brother John I Albert ( 1501 ) .
Alexander 's shortage of funds immediately made Alexander Jagiellon subservient to the Polish Senate and nobility ( szlachta ) , who deprived Alexander Jagiellon of control of the mint ( then one of the most lucrative sources of revenue for the Polish kings ) , curtailed Alexander Jagiellon prerogatives , and generally endeavored to reduce Alexander Jagiellon to a subordinate position .
The most the Grand Duke of Lithuania could do was to garrison Smolensk and other strongholds and employ Alexander Jagiellon wife Helena , the Tsar 's daughter , to mediate a truce between Alexander Jagiellon father-in-law and Alexander Jagiellon after the disastrous Battle of Vedrosha ( 1500 ) .
Only the death of Stephen , the great hospodar of Moldavia , enabled Poland still to hold her own on the Danube River ; while the liberality of Pope Julius II , who issued no fewer than 29 bulls in favor of Poland and granted Alexander Peter 's Pence and other financial help , enabled Alexander Jagiellon to restrain somewhat the arrogance of the Teutonic Order .
Alexander Jagiellon is the Grand Duke of Lithuania and later also King of Poland .
Kerouac became an underground celebrity and , with other beats , a progenitor of the hippie movement , although Jack Kerouac remained antagonistic toward some of its politically radical elements .
All of Jack Kerouac books are in print today , among them : On the Road , Doctor Sax , The Dharma Bums , Mexico City Blues , The Subterraneans , Desolation Angels , Visions of Cody , The Sea is Jack Kerouac Brother , and Big Sur .
There is some confusion surrounding Jack Kerouac original name , partly due to variations on the spelling of Kerouac , and partly because of Kerouac 's own promotion of Jack Kerouac name as Jean-Louis Lebris de Kerouac .
This experience , along with Jack Kerouac dying brother 's vision of the Virgin Mary , as the nuns fawned over him convinced that Jack Kerouac was a saint , combined with a later discovery of Buddhism and ongoing commitment to Christ , solidified Jack Kerouac worldview which informs Jack Kerouac work .
In fact , according to Jack Kerouac Columbia professor and mentor Mark Van Doren , Jack Kerouac had outlined much of the work in Jack Kerouac journals over the several preceding years .
Before On the Road was accepted by Viking Press , Kerouac got a job as a `` railroad brakesman and fire lookout '' traveling between the East and West coasts of America to collect money , so Jack Kerouac could live with Jack Kerouac mother .
Jack Kerouac found Jack Kerouac in the sky , in Market Street San Francisco ( those 2 visions ) , and Dean ( Neal ) had God sweating out of Jack Kerouac forehead all the way .
According to Jack Kerouac authorized biographer , historian Douglas Brinkley , On the Road has been misinterpreted as a tale of companions out looking for kicks , but the most important thing to comprehend is that Kerouac was an American Catholic author -- for example , virtually every page of Jack Kerouac diary bore a sketch of a crucifix , a prayer , or an appeal to Christ to be forgiven .
Huncke used the term `` beat '' to describe a person with little money and few prospects .
Kerouac 's novel is often described as the defining work of the post-World War II Beat Generation and Kerouac came to be called `` the king of the beat generation , '' a term that Jack Kerouac never felt comfortable with .
`` A gaping , rabid congregation , eager to bathe , are washed over by the Font of Euphoria , and bask like protozoans in the celebrated light '' .
The CBS Television series Route 66 ( 1960 -- 64 ) , featuring two untethered young men `` on the road '' in a Corvette seeking adventure and fueling their travels by apparently plentiful temporary jobs in the various U.S. locales framing the anthology styled stories , gave the impression of being a commercially sanitized misappropriation of Jack Kerouac `` On The Road '' story model .
Even the leads , Buz and Todd , bore a resemblance to the dark , athletic Jack Kerouac and the blonde Cassady/Moriarty , respectively .

The central features of this writing method were the ideas of breath ( borrowed from Jazz and from Buddhist meditation breathing ) , improvising words over the inherent structures of mind and language , and not editing a single word ( much of Jack Kerouac work was edited by Donald Merriam Allen , a major figure in Beat Generation poetry who edited some of Ginsberg 's work as well ) .
The Dharma Bums contains accounts of a mountain climbing trip Jack Kerouac took with Snyder , and also whole paragraphs from letters Snyder had written to Jack Kerouac .
Some believed that at times Jack Kerouac writing technique did not produce lively or energetic prose .
The technique Kerouac developed that later made Jack Kerouac famous was heavily influenced by Jazz , especially Bebop , and later , Buddhism , as well as the famous `` Joan Anderson letter '' authored by Neal Cassady .

Jeff Mills ( born 18 June 1963 , Detroit , Michigan ) is an American techno DJ and producer .
In Jeff Mills DJ sets , Mills usually uses three decks , a Roland TR-909 drum-machine , and up to seventy records in one hour .
Mills ' Exhibitionist DVD , from 2004 , features Jeff Mills mixing live on three decks and CD player in a studio .
Major 's premiership saw the world go through a period of political and military transition after the end of the Cold War .
This included the rise of the European Union , an issue which was already a source of friction within the Conservative Party owing to its importance in the decline and fall of Margaret Thatcher .
John Major was born at the St. Helier Hospital in Sutton , Surrey , the son of Gwen Major ( née Gwendolen Minnie Coates ) and former music hall performer Tom Major-Ball ( né Abraham Thomas Ball ) , who was 64 years old when John Major was born .
After a period of unemployment , Major started working at the London Electricity Board ( where John Major successor as the Prime Minister , Tony Blair , also worked when John Major was young ) in 1963 , and John Major decided to undertake a correspondence course in banking .
However , even these moves towards greater European integration met with vehement opposition from the Eurosceptic wing of the party and the Cabinet as the Government attempted to ratify the Maastricht Treaty in the first half of 1993 .
In 1992 , David Mellor , a cabinet minister , had been exposed as having an extramarital affair and for accepting hospitality from the daughter of a leading member of the Palestine Liberation Organization .
A string of other Conservative MPs , including Alan Amos , Tim Yeo , and Michael Brown , were involved in sexual scandals .
John Major attempted to draw some of the sting from the financial scandals by setting up public inquiries -- the Nolan Report into standards expected in public life , and the Scott Report into the Arms to Iraq Scandal .
John Major wrote that John Major took a stern line against financial impropriety , but was angered at the way in which a host of scandals , many of them petty sexual misdemeanours by a small number of MPs , were exploited by the press and Opposition for political advantage .
However , John Major also conceded that the issue `` fed the public belief that the Conservative ( s ) ... had been in government too long , and had got into bad habits '' and quoted Labour 's claim in 1997 : `` Nothing better encapsulates what people think of this government .
When John Major declared to the House of Commons in November 1993 that `` to sit down and talk with Mr. Adams and the Provisional IRA ... would turn John Major stomach '' , Sinn Féin gave the media an outline of the secret talks indeed held regularly since that February .
The Downing Street Declaration was issued on 15 December 1993 by Major and Albert Reynolds , the Irish Taoiseach , with whom John Major had a friendly relationship : an IRA ceasefire followed in 1994 .
The Clinton administration , by contrast , was committed to a policy of ` lift and strike ' ( lifting the arms embargo and inflicting air strikes on the Serbs ) causing tensions in the ` special relationship ' ( Douglas Hurd and others strongly opposed this policy ) .
The Sun newspaper , still at this stage supporting the Conservative Party , had lost faith in John Major and declared its support for Redwood in the leadership election , running the front page headline `` Redwood versus Deadwood '' .
Few then were surprised when Major 's Conservatives lost the 1 May 1997 general election to Tony Blair 's `` New Labour '' , although the immense scale of the defeat was not as widely predicted : in 1987 and 1992 the Conservatives had polled better than had been suggested by the opinion polls , but in 1997 this was no longer the case .
In the new parliament , Labour held 418 seats , the Conservatives 165 , and the Liberal Democrats 46 , giving Labour a majority of 179 .

The media ( particularly The Guardian cartoonist Steve Bell ) used the allegation by Alastair Campbell that John Major had observed Major tucking John Major shirt into John Major underpants to caricature John Major wearing John Major pants outside John Major trousers , as a pale grey echo of both Superman and Supermac , a parody of Harold Macmillan .
Major complained in John Major memoirs that these words ( which drew upon a passage in the sociopolitical commentator and author George Orwell 's `` The Lion and the Unicorn '' ) had been misrepresented as being more naive and romantic than John Major had intended , and indeed John Major memoirs were dismissive of the common conservative viewpoint that there was once a time of moral rectitude ; Major wrote that `` life has never been as simple as that '' .

Carroll 's notes for the original in Mischmasch suggest a `` rath '' is `` a species of Badger '' that `` lived chiefly on cheese '' and had smooth white hair , long hind legs , and short horns like a stag .
The appendices to certain Looking Glass editions , however , state that the creature is `` a species of land turtle '' that lived on swallows and oysters .

Full translations of `` Jabberwocky '' into French and German can be found in The Annotated Alice along with a discussion of why some translation decisions were made .
Jabberwocky is a nonsense poem written by Lewis Carroll in his 1871 novel Through the Looking-Glass , and What Alice Found There , a sequel to Alice 's Adventures in Wonderland .
Sir John Sparrow David Thompson , KCMG , PC , QC ( November 10 , 1845 -- December 12 , 1894 ) was a Canadian lawyer , judge , politician , and university professor , who served as the fourth Prime Minister of Canada from December 5 , 1892 until John Sparrow David Thompson death in office on December 12 , 1894 , as well as the fifth Premier of Nova Scotia in 1882 .
Thompson was called to the Nova Scotia Bar in July 1865 , and from 1878 to 1882 served as Attorney General in the provincial government of Simon H. Holmes .
Other matters of concern during Thompson 's tenure as Prime Minister included the reduction of trade tariffs and questions over schooling in Manitoba and in the North West Territories , where disputes over the role of Catholics and Protestants in administering the school system existed .
In the period of his life as heir apparent , the intellectual atmosphere of Saint Petersburg was unfavourable to any kind of change : freedom of thought and all forms of private initiative were being suppressed vigorously .
Soon after the conclusion of peace , important changes were made in legislation concerning industry and commerce , and the new freedom thus afforded produced a large number of limited liability companies .
Now sons of all the `` estates '' , rich and poor , had to serve in the military .
Reorganisation of Judiciary , to include trial in open court , with judges appointed for life , a jury system and the creation of justices of the peace to deal with minor offences at local level .
Encouraging Finnish nationalism and language can also be seen as an attempt to dilute ties with Sweden .
Some of the most prominent intellectuals and politicians on the Continent , most notably Victor Hugo and William Gladstone , sought to raise awareness about the atrocities of the Turks imposed on the Bulgarian population .
Twenty people , with wounds of varying degree , lay on the sidewalk and on the street .
Oscar Wilde 's first play Vera ; or , The Nihilists , written in 1880 -- Alexander II of Russia last year -- features Russian revolutionaries who seek to assassinate a reform-minded Emperor ( and who , in the play , ultimately fail in their plot ) .
Macdonald was a promising student , and in the summer of 1833 , managed the Mackenzie office when John A. Macdonald employer went on a business trip to Montreal and Quebec in Lower Canada ( today the southern portion of the province of Quebec ) .
In 1835 , Macdonald returned to Kingston , and even though not yet of age nor qualified , began John A. Macdonald practice as a lawyer , hoping to gain John A. Macdonald former employer 's clients .
And , while there , John A. Macdonald was learning the arts of argument and of persuasion that would serve John A. Macdonald all John A. Macdonald political life .
All Upper Canadians between 18 and 60 years of age were members of the Sedentary Militia , which was called into active duty during the Rebellions of 1837 .
Macdonald could not represent the prisoners , as they were tried by court martial and civilian counsel had no standing .
Macdonald began to drink heavily around this time , both in public and in private , which Patricia Phenix , who studied Macdonald 's private life , attributes to John A. Macdonald family troubles .
Macdonald resigned , and the Governor General , Sir Edmund Walker Head , invited opposition leader George Brown to form a government .
The law allowed anyone who had held a ministerial position within the last thirty days to accept a new position without needing to face a by-election ; Macdonald and John A. Macdonald ministers accepted new positions , then completed what was dubbed the `` Double Shuffle '' by returning to their old posts .
The final days of the 3rd Canadian Parliament were marked by explosive conflict , as Macdonald and Tupper alleged that MP and railway financier Donald Smith had been allowed to build the Pembina branch of the CPR ( connecting to American lines ) as a reward for betraying the Conservatives during the Pacific Scandal .
Diefenbaker 's recollections do not correspond with John Diefenbaker army medical records , which show no contemporary account of such an injury , and John Diefenbaker biographer , Denis Smith , speculates that any injury was psychosomatic .
On June 30 , 1919 , John Diefenbaker was called to the bar , and the following day , opened a small practice in the village of Wakaw , Saskatchewan .
It was not until 1925 that John Diefenbaker publicly came forward as a Conservative , a year in which both federal and Saskatchewan provincial elections were held .
Journalist and historian Peter C. Newman , in John Diefenbaker best-selling account of the Diefenbaker years , suggested that this choice was made for practical , rather than political reasons , as Diefenbaker had little chance of defeating established politicians and securing the Liberal nomination for either the House of Commons or the Legislative Assembly .
On June 19 , however , Diefenbaker addressed a Conservative organizing committee , and on August 6 , was nominated as the party 's candidate for the federal riding of Prince Albert , a district in which the party 's last candidate had lost John Diefenbaker election deposit .
John Diefenbaker continued a high-profile legal practice , and in 1933 , ran for mayor of Prince Albert .
Angered by the words of John Diefenbaker and fellow Conservative MP Howard Green in seeking to censure the government , the Prime Minister referred to Conservative MPs as `` a mob '' .
Meighen sought to move the Tories to the left , in order to undercut the Liberals and to take support away from the Co-operative Commonwealth Federation ( CCF , the predecessor of the New Democratic Party ( NDP ) ) .
In August 1956 , Drew fell ill and many within the party urged John Diefenbaker to step aside , feeling that the Progressive Conservatives needed vigorous leadership with an election likely within a year .

Because of tax cuts instituted the previous year , the budget presented by the government predicted a small deficit for 1957 -- 58 , and a large one , $ 648 million , for the following year .

This was adopted , although Britain and New Zealand disagreed with John Diefenbaker proposal .
Despite Liberal misgivings that Diefenbaker had committed Canada to the system before consulting either the Cabinet or Parliament , Pearson and John Diefenbaker followers voted with the government to approve NORAD in June 1958 .
With the Cabinet still divided between adherents of Green and Harkness , John Diefenbaker made a speech in the Commons on January 25 that Fleming ( by then Minister of Justice ) termed `` a model of obfuscation '' .
Diefenbaker asked ministers supporting John Diefenbaker to stand , and when only about half did , stated that John Diefenbaker was going to see the Governor General to resign , and that Fleming would be the next Prime Minister .
In 1978 , Diefenbaker announced that John Diefenbaker would stand in one more election , and under the slogan `` Diefenbaker -- Now More Than Ever '' , weathered a campaign the following year during which John Diefenbaker apparently suffered a mild stroke , although the media were told John Diefenbaker was bedridden with influenza .
John and Olive Diefenbaker rest outside the Diefenbaker Centre , built to house John Diefenbaker papers , on the campus of the University of Saskatchewan .
Diefenbaker 's Bill of Rights , although ineffective in its own right , laid the foundation for the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms , which came into force after John Diefenbaker death .
Clark and Mulroney , two men who , as students , worked on and were inspired by John Diefenbaker 1957 triumph , became the only other Progressive Conservatives to lead the party to election triumphs .

Jean-Michel Basquiat father , Gerard Basquiat , was born in Port-au-Prince , Haiti , and Jean-Michel Basquiat mother , Matilde Basquiat , of Afro-Puerto Rican descent , was born in Brooklyn , New York .
Jean-Michel Basquiat parents eventually separated that year and Jean-Michel Basquiat and Jean-Michel Basquiat sisters were raised by their father .
Fred Hoffman hypothesizes that underlying Basquiat 's sense of Jean-Michel Basquiat as an artist was Jean-Michel Basquiat `` innate capacity to function as something like an oracle , distilling Jean-Michel Basquiat perceptions of the outside world down to their essence and , in turn , projecting them outward through Jean-Michel Basquiat creative acts '' .
Two letters of the word `` Nile '' are crossed out and Frohne suggests that , `` The letters that are wiped out and scribbled over perhaps reflect the acts of historians who have conveniently forgotten that Egyptians were black and blacks were enslaved '' .

The catalog for this exhibition , edited by Richard Marshall and including several essays of differing styles , was a groundbreaking piece of scholarship into Jean-Michel Basquiat work and still a major source .
Another exhibition , `` Jean-Michel Basquiat '' , was mounted by the Brooklyn Museum , New York , in 2005 , and traveled to the Museum of Contemporary Art , Los Angeles , and the Museum of Fine Arts , Houston .
In the song `` Ten Thousand Hours '' Macklemore raps `` Jean-Michel Basquiat observed Escher , Jean-Michel Basquiat love Basquiat '' and on Jean-Michel Basquiat song `` Victory Lap '' raps `` unorthodox , like Basquiat with a pencil '' .
In 1985 , Jean-Michel Basquiat was featured on the cover of The New York Times Magazine in connection with an article on the newly exuberant international art market ; this was unprecedented for an African-American artist , and for one so young .

John Graves Simcoe ( February 25 , 1752 -- October 26 , 1806 ) was a British army officer and the first Lieutenant Governor of Upper Canada from 1791 -- 1796 .
In 1778 , Simcoe , during a foraging expedition opposed by rebel militia , commanded the attack on Judge William Hancock 's house , killing 20 American rebels in their sleep and wounding 12 others .
Later that year , Booth played the part of an Indian , Uncas , in a play staged in Petersburg , Virginia , and then became a stock company actor at the Richmond Theatre in Virginia , where John Wilkes Booth became increasingly popular with audiences for John Wilkes Booth energetic performances .
Afterward , Edwin led the younger Booth to the theatre 's footlights and said to the audience , `` John Wilkes Booth think John Wilkes Booth 's done well , do n't you ?
Poet and journalist Walt Whitman said of Booth 's acting , `` John Wilkes Booth would have flashes , passages , John Wilkes Booth thought of real genius '' .
The Philadelphia Press drama critic said , `` Without having John Wilkes Booth brother Edwin 's culture and grace , Mr. Booth has far more action , more life , and , we are inclined to think , more natural genius '' .
Between September -- November 1863 , Booth played a hectic schedule in the northeast , appearing in Boston , Providence , Rhode Island , and Hartford , Connecticut .

The partners , impatient to increase the well 's output , attempted the use of explosives , which wrecked the well and ended production .
When Brown was hanged without incident , Booth stood in uniform near the scaffold and afterwards expressed great satisfaction with Brown 's fate , although John Wilkes Booth admired the condemned man 's bravery in facing death stoically .
Although Maryland remained in the Union , newspaper editorials and many Marylanders , including Booth , agreed with Supreme Court Chief Justice Roger B. Taney 's decision in Ex parte Merryman that Lincoln 's actions were unconstitutional .
In early 1863 , Booth was arrested in St. Louis while on a theatre tour , when John Wilkes Booth was heard saying John Wilkes Booth `` wished the President and the whole damned government would go to hell '' .
`` You have so often been dead in love , '' John Wilkes Booth mother counseled Booth in a letter , `` be well assured she is really and truly devoted to you '' .
Booth , who had promised John Wilkes Booth mother at the outbreak of war that John Wilkes Booth would not enlist as a soldier , increasingly chafed at not fighting for the South , writing in a letter to her , `` John Wilkes Booth have begun to deem myself a coward and to despise John Wilkes Booth own existence '' .
No conclusive proof has linked Booth 's kidnapping or assassination plots to a conspiracy involving the leadership of the Confederate government , although historians such as David Herbert Donald have said , `` It is clear that , at least at the lower levels of the Southern secret service , the abduction of the Union President was under consideration '' .

Among the identifying features used to make sure that the man that was killed was Booth was a tattoo on John Wilkes Booth left hand with John Wilkes Booth initials J.W.B. , and a distinct scar on the back of John Wilkes Booth neck .
Samuel Mudd , Samuel Arnold , and Michael O'Laughlen were sentenced to life imprisonment at Fort Jefferson in Florida 's Dry Tortugas ; Edmund Spangler was given a six-year term in prison .

In 1907 , Finis L. Bates wrote Escape and Suicide of John Wilkes Booth , contending that a Booth look-alike was mistakenly killed at the Garrett farm while Booth eluded John Wilkes Booth pursuers .
The Lincoln Conspiracy , a book published in 1977 , contended there was a government plot to conceal Booth 's escape , reviving interest in the story and prompting the display of St. Helen 's mummified body in Chicago that year .
A sebaceous cyst on the left side of Alexander III of Russia nose caused Alexander III of Russia to be mocked by some of Alexander III of Russia contemporaries , and Alexander III of Russia sat for photographs and portraits with the right side of Alexander III of Russia face most prominent .
Other conservative advisors were Count D. A. Tolstoy ( minister of education , and later of internal affairs ) and Alexander III of Russia .
Mikhail Katkov and other journalists supported the emperor in Alexander III of Russia autocracy -- as did the novelist Dostoevsky .
Alexander and Alexander III of Russia wife regularly spent their summers at Langinkoski manor near Kotka on the Finnish coast , where their children were immersed in a Scandinavian lifestyle of relative modesty .
With such ideas Alexander III of Russia had not been able to be in cordial agreement with Alexander III of Russia father , who , though a patriot , had German sympathies , often used the German language in Alexander III of Russia private relations , occasionally ridiculed the Slavophiles and based Alexander III of Russia foreign policy on the Prussian alliance .
At first the Tsarevich was more Slavophile than the government , but Alexander III of Russia phlegmatic nature preserved Alexander III of Russia from many exaggerations , and any popular illusions Alexander III of Russia may have imbibed were dispelled by personal observation in Bulgaria , where Alexander III of Russia commanded the left wing of the invading army .
Alexander III of Russia remains were interred at the Peter and Paul Fortress in Saint Petersburg .
Dan Quayle was born in Indianapolis , Indiana , to Martha Corinne ( née Pulliam ) and James Cline Quayle .
Dan Quayle maternal grandfather , Eugene C. Pulliam , was a wealthy and influential publishing magnate who founded Central Newspapers , Inc. , owner of over a dozen major newspapers such as The Arizona Republic and The Indianapolis Star .
Dan Quayle then matriculated at DePauw University , where Dan Quayle received Dan Quayle B.A. degree in political science in 1969 , and where Dan Quayle was a member of the fraternity Delta Kappa Epsilon ( Psi Phi chapter ) .
