Jacob Abbott brothers , John Stevens Cabot Abbott and Gorham Dummer Abbott , were also authors .
Jacob Abbott sons , Benjamin Vaughan Abbott , Austin Abbott , both eminent lawyers , Lyman Abbott , and Edward Abbott , a clergyman , were also well-known authors .
John Stevens Cabot Abbott ( September 19 , 1805 -- June 17 , 1877 ) , an American historian , pastor , and pedagogical writer , was born in Brunswick , Maine to Jacob and Betsey Abbott .
Dr. Abbott graduated at Bowdoin College in 1825 , prepared for the ministry at Andover Theological Seminary , and between 1830 and 1844 , when John Stevens Cabot Abbott retired from the ministry in the Congregational Church , preached successively at Worcester , Roxbury and Nantucket , all in Massachusetts .
John Stevens Cabot Abbott was a voluminous writer of books on Christian ethics , and of popular histories , which were credited with cultivating a popular interest in history .
John and Jane had issue : As a part of the 1872 Iwakura Mission Mr. Abbott was given guardianship of Shige Nagai , a Japanese girl sent to the United States to be educated .
In 1910 , a series of twenty short biographies of historical characters by J. S. C. and Jacob Abbott , was published .
John Stevens Cabot Abbott is a voluminous writer of books on Christian ethics , and of popular histories , which were credited with cultivating a popular interest in history .
James Ewell Brown `` Jeb '' Stuart ( February 6 , 1833 -- May 12 , 1864 ) was a U.S. Army officer from Virginia and a Confederate States Army general during the American Civil War .
J.E.B. Stuart established a reputation as an audacious cavalry commander and on two occasions ( during the Peninsula Campaign and the Maryland Campaign ) circumnavigated the Union Army of the Potomac , bringing fame to J.E.B. Stuart and embarrassment to the North .
Arguably Stuart 's most famous campaign , Gettysburg , was marred when J.E.B. Stuart was surprised by a Union cavalry attack at the Battle of Brandy Station and by J.E.B. Stuart separation from Lee 's army for an extended period , leaving Lee unaware of Union troop movements and arguably contributing to the Confederate defeat at the Battle of Gettysburg .
J.E.B. Stuart was the eighth of eleven children and the youngest of the five sons to survive past early age .
J.E.B. Stuart quickly grew a beard after graduation and a fellow officer remarked that J.E.B. Stuart was `` the only man J.E.B. Stuart ever saw that a beard improved '' .
Burke Davis described Flora as `` an accomplished horsewoman , and though not pretty , an effective charmer , '' to whom `` Stuart succumbed with hardly a struggle '' .
Buford 's men , many of whom were new to combat , retreated across Lewis 's Ford and Stuart 's troopers captured over 300 of them .
Stuart began probing the Union lines with more artillery barrages , which were answered with `` murderous '' counterbattery fire and the cavalry movement intended by Jackson was never launched .
Stonewall Jackson died on May 10 and Stuart was once again devastated by the loss of a close friend , telling J.E.B. Stuart staff that the death was a `` national calamity '' .
By June 5 , two of Lee 's infantry corps were camped in and around Culpeper .
Gen. John Buford 's division ) catching Stuart by surprise , waking J.E.B. Stuart and J.E.B. Stuart staff to the sound of gunfire .
However , the fact that the Southern cavalry had not detected the movement of two large columns of Union cavalry , and that they fell victim to a surprise attack , was an embarrassment that prompted serious criticism from fellow generals and the Southern press .
This prevented Stuart from linking up with Ewell as ordered and deprived Lee of the use of J.E.B. Stuart prime cavalry force , the `` eyes and ears '' of the army , while advancing into unfamiliar enemy territory .
The proximity of the Confederate raiders provoked some consternation in the national capital and two Union cavalry brigades and an artillery battery were sent to pursue the Confederates .
Stuart supposedly said that were it not for J.E.B. Stuart fatigued horses `` J.E.B. Stuart would have marched down the 7th Street Road and took Abe & Cabinet prisoners '' .
In Westminster on June 29 , J.E.B. Stuart men clashed briefly with and overwhelmed two companies of Union cavalry , chasing them a long distance on the Baltimore road , which Stuart claimed caused a `` great panic '' in the city of Baltimore .
Gen. Judson Kilpatrick 's cavalry as it passed through Hanover and scattered it on June 30 ; the Battle of Hanover ended after Kilpatrick 's men regrouped and drove the Confederates out of town .
In General Lee 's report on the campaign , J.E.B. Stuart wrote One of the most forceful postbellum defenses of Stuart was by Col. John S. Mosby , who had served under J.E.B. Stuart during the campaign and was fiercely loyal to the late general , writing , `` J.E.B. Stuart made J.E.B. Stuart all that J.E.B. Stuart was in the war .
J.E.B. Stuart wrote numerous articles for popular publications and published a book length treatise in 1908 , a work that relied on J.E.B. Stuart skills as a lawyer to refute categorically all of the claims laid against Stuart .
After the Confederate repulse at Bristoe Station and an aborted advance on Centreville , Stuart 's cavalry shielded the withdrawal of Lee 's army from the vicinity of Manassas Junction .
The commander of the Army of the Potomac , Maj. Gen. George Meade , and J.E.B. Stuart cavalry commander , Maj. Gen. Philip Sheridan , quarreled about the Union cavalry 's performance in the first two engagements of the Overland Campaign .
Sheridan immediately organized a raid against Confederate supply and railroad lines close to Richmond , which J.E.B. Stuart knew would bring Stuart to battle .
A high school in Falls Church , Virginia and a middle school in Jacksonville , Florida are named for J.E.B. Stuart .
In 2006 , the flag and letter , which had been displayed in a single frame in the Stuart Hall front parlor , were sold separately at auction .
Stuart 's birthplace , Laurel Hill , located in Patrick County , Virginia , was purchased by the J.E.B. Stuart Birthplace Preservation Trust , Inc. , in 1992 to preserve and interpret it .
J.E.B. Stuart is the eighth of eleven children and the youngest of the five sons to survive past early age .
John Hanson ( -- November 15 , 1783 ) was a merchant and public official from Maryland during the era of the American Revolution .
In 1903 , bronze statues of John Hanson and Charles Carroll by sculptor Richard E. Brooks were added to Statuary Hall ; Hanson 's is currently located on the 2nd floor of the Senate connecting corridor .
Smith 's book asserted that the American Revolution had two primary leaders : George Washington on the battlefield , and John Hanson in politics .
U.S. Route 50 between Washington D.C. and Annapolis is named the John Hanson Highway in John Hanson honor .
There are also middle schools located in Oxon Hill , Maryland , and Waldorf , Maryland , named after John Hanson .
As guardians of peace and justice in the galaxy , Jedi mediate peace negotiations among planets and other factions and , if necessary , use their formidable fighting skills , agility and wisdom to quickly end unrest or neutralize dangerous individuals or threats .
Obi-Wan Kenobi ( Alec Guinness ) explains that the Galactic Empire had all but exterminated Jedi some twenty years before the events of the film , and seeks to train Luke Skywalker ( Mark Hamill ) to be the Order 's last hope .
In the sequel , , Luke receives extensive Jedi training from the elderly ( and only surviving ) Jedi Master Yoda ( Frank Oz ) , even as he learns that Vader is in fact his father , former Jedi Anakin Skywalker .
The third film in the original trilogy , , ends with Luke redeeming Vader and helping to destroy the Empire , thus fulfilling his destiny as a Jedi .
The sequel , , establishes that Jedi forswear all emotional attachments , including romantic love , which proves problematic when Anakin , now a young adult ( Hayden Christensen ) , falls in love with Padmé Amidala ( Natalie Portman ) , whom Qui-Gon Jinn and Obi-Wan Kenobi had served ten years before .
In , Palpatine ( Ian McDiarmid ) , who is later revealed to be the Sith Lord Darth Sidious , manipulates Anakin 's love for Padmé and distrust of Jedi in order to turn him to the dark side and become his Sith apprentice , Darth Vader .
The New Jedi Order indicates that the Jedi Temple on Coruscant is no longer standing but Jedi is rebuilt as a gift to Jedi for their services and achievements during the Yuuzhan Vong invasion .
The new temple is in the form of a massive pyramid made from stone and transparisteel that is designed to fit into the new look of Coruscant , though internally Jedi is identical to the design seen in Revenge of the Sith .
Jedi lightsabers emit blue or green blades ( or purple , as seen in the case of Mace Windu ) , while the Sith emit red ones .
James Tobin joined the Cowles Foundation , which moved to Yale in 1955 , also serving as its president between 1955 -- 1961 and 1964-1965 .
James Tobin was awarded the John Bates Clark Medal in 1955 and , in 1981 , the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics .
James Tobin `` q '' theory of investment ( Tobin 1969 ) , the Baumol-Tobin model of the transactions demand for money ( Tobin 1956 ) , and James Tobin model of liquidity preference as behavior toward risk ( the asset demand for money ) ( Tobin 1958b ) are all staples of economics textbooks .

Following Julian Lennon father 's murder , Lennon voiced anger and resentment toward Julian Lennon , saying Julian Lennon 've never really wanted to know the truth about how dad was with Julian Lennon .
Recalling Julian Lennon renewed relationship with Julian Lennon father in the mid-1970s , Julian Lennon said , Dad and Julian Lennon got on a great deal better then .

John Abercrombie (physician) FRSE FRCSE FRCPE ( 12 October 1780 , Aberdeen -- 14 November 1844 , Edinburgh ) was a Scottish physician and philosopher .
The son of the Reverend George Abercrombie , the minister of East Church , Aberdeen , John Abercrombie (physician) was educated at the Grammar School and Marischal College , University of Aberdeen .
John Abercrombie (physician) studied medicine at the University of Edinburgh , and after graduating as M.D. in 1803 John Abercrombie (physician) settled down to practise in that city , where John Abercrombie (physician) soon attained a leading position .
John Abercrombie (physician) is a Scottish physician and philosopher .
Judgement of Paris is a story from Greek mythology , which was one of the events that led up to the Trojan War and ( in slightly later versions of Judgement of Paris ) to the foundation of Rome .
The brief allusion to the Judgement in the Iliad ( 24.25 -- 30 ) shows that the episode initiating all the subsequent action was already familiar to Judgement of Paris audience ; a fuller version was told in the Cypria , a lost work of the Epic Cycle , of which only fragments ( and a reliable summary ) remain .
Judgement of Paris asked Zeus to judge which of them was fairest , and eventually he , reluctant to favour any claim himself , declared that Paris , a Trojan mortal , would judge their cases , for he had recently shown his exemplary fairness in a contest in which Ares in bull form had bested Paris 's own prize bull , and the shepherd-prince had unhesitatingly awarded the prize to the god .
However , Hera was the goddess of the marital order and of cuckolded wives , amongst other things .
In ancient art however , only Aphrodite is ever shown naked , and that is not always .
1515 , probably based on a drawing by Raphael , and using a composition derived from a Roman sarcophagus , was a highly influential treatment , which made Paris 's Phrygian cap an attribute in most later versions .
Judgement of Paris is a story from Greek mythology , which was one of the events that led up to the Trojan War and ( in slightly later versions of the story ) to the foundation of Rome .
The term is also used to denote the geographical area or subject-matter to which such authority applies .
Jurisdiction draws Jurisdiction substance from public international law , conflict of laws , constitutional law and the powers of the executive and legislative branches of government to allocate resources to best serve the needs of Jurisdiction native society .
Supranational organizations provide mechanisms whereby disputes between states may be resolved through arbitration or mediation .
If the two sets of bodies do not have concurrent jurisdiction but , as in the case of the International Criminal Court ( ICC ) , the relationship is expressly based on the principle of complementarity , i.e. , the international court is subsidiary or complementary to national courts , the difficulty is avoided .
At a regional level , groups of states can create political and legal bodies with sometimes complicated patchworks of overlapping provisions detailing the Jurisdiction relationships between the member states and providing for some degree of harmonization between their national legislative and judicial functions , for example , the European Union and African Union both have the potential to become federated states although the political barriers to such unification in the face of entrenched nationalism will be very difficult to overcome .
The standard treaties and conventions leave the issue of implementation to each state , i.e.This theory characterizes international and municipal law as a single legal system with municipal law subordinate to international law .
In addition , the Lugano Convention ( 1988 ) binds the European Union and the European Free Trade Association .
Council Regulation ( EC ) 44/2001 now also applies as between the rest of the EU Member States and Denmark due to an agreement reached between the European Community and Denmark .
If the executive or legislative powers within Jurisdiction are not restricted or restricted only by a number of limited restrictions , these government branches have plenary power such as a national policing power .
The problem of forum shopping also applies as between federal and state courts .
As a common law system , jurisdiction is conceptually divided between jurisdiction over the subject matter of a case and jurisdiction over the person of the litigants .
A court whose subject-matter jurisdiction is limited to certain types of controversies ( for example , suits in admiralty or suits where the monetary amount sought is less than a specified sum ) is sometimes referred to as a court of special jurisdiction or court of limited jurisdiction .
Certain courts , particularly the United States Supreme Court and most state supreme courts , have discretionary jurisdiction , meaning that they can choose which cases to hear from among all the cases presented on appeal .
The word `` jurisdiction '' is also used , especially in informal writing , to refer to a state or political subdivision generally , or to Jurisdiction government , rather than to Jurisdiction legal authority .
In the history of English common law , Jurisdiction could be held as a form of property ( or more precisely an incorporeal hereditament ) called a franchise .
The original royal charters of the American colonies included broad grants of franchise jurisdiction along with other governmental powers to corporations or individuals , as did the charters for many other colonial companies such as the British East India Company and British South Africa Company .
John Abernethy (surgeon) attended the anatomical lectures of Sir William Blizard ( 1743 -- 1835 ) at the London Hospital , and was employed to assist as demonstrator ; John Abernethy (surgeon) also attended Percivall Pott 's surgical lectures at St Bartholomew 's Hospital , as well as the lectures of John Hunter .
On Pott 's resignation of the office of surgeon of St Bartholomew 's , Sir Charles Blicke , who was assistant-surgeon , succeeded John Abernethy (surgeon) , and Abernethy was elected assistant-surgeon in 1787 .
John Abernethy (surgeon) Surgical Observations on the Constitutional Origin and Treatment of Local Diseases ( 1809 ) -- known as `` John Abernethy (surgeon) Book '' , from the great frequency with which John Abernethy (surgeon) referred John Abernethy (surgeon) patients to it , and to page 72 of it in particular , under that name -- was one of the earliest popular works on medical science .
John Abernethy (surgeon) taught that local diseases were frequently the results of disordered states of the digestive organs , and were to be treated by purging and attention to diet .
John Abernethy (surgeon) was very blunt with John Abernethy (surgeon) patients , treating them often brusquely and sometimes even rudely .
Judeo-Christian promotes the concept there is a shared intersection of values based on the Hebrew Bible ( `` Torah '' ) , brought into our culture by the founding generations of Biblically oriented Protestants , that is fundamental to American history , cultural identity , and institutions .
The Reason for Antisemitism , and radio commentator , has published an on-going 19-part series explaining and promoting the concept of Judeo-Christian culture , running for three years from 2005 to 2008 , reflecting the interest of this concept to his listeners .
Along with the belief in liberty -- as opposed to , for example , the European belief in equality , the Muslim belief in theocracy , and the Eastern belief in social conformity -- Judeo-Christian are what distinguish America from all other countries .
Supporters of the Judeo-Christian concept point to the Christian claim that Christianity is the heir to Biblical Judaism , and that the whole logic of Christianity as a religion is that Judeo-Christian exists ( only ) as a religion built upon Judaism .
Senator Barry Goldwater noted that Conservatives `` believed the communist projection of man as a producing , consuming animal to be used and discarded was antithetical to all the Judeo-Christian understandings which are the foundations upon which the Republic stands '' .
Interest in and a positive attitude towards America 's Judeo-Christian tradition has become mainstream among Evangelicals .
Theologian and author Arthur A. Cohen , in The Myth of the Judeo-Christian Tradition , questioned the theological validity of the Judeo-Christian concept and suggested that Judeo-Christian was essentially an invention of American politics , while Jacob Neusner , in Jews and Christians : The Myth of a Common Tradition , writes , `` The two faiths stand for different people talking about different things to different people '' .
The concept of Judeo-Christian flows from the Christian theology of supersession , whereby the Christian covenant ( or Testament ) with God supersedes the Jewish one .
Christianity , according to this myth , reforms and replaces Judaism .
James Witherspoon , president of Princeton , teacher of James Madison and later a member of the Continental Congress , and one of the most influential thinkers in the Colonies , joined the cause of the Revolution with a widely publicized sermon based on Psalm 76 , identifying the American colonists with the people of Israel .
Michael Novak , a specialist in the religious beliefs of the Founding Fathers , argues that the promotion of multiculturalism , moral relativism , and secularism among academics results in academic censorship that affects information and analysis supporting the Judeo-Christian heritage .
Judeo-Christian is a term used in a historical sense , especially in the United States , to refer to the connections between the precursors of Christianity and Rabbinic Judaism in the Second Temple period .
Frank Redelius , one of Maroger 's protégés from the Baltimore Realists group , wrote a book that updates , builds upon and revises Jacques Maroger research of the painting techniques and formulas of the Old Masters .
The reduced availability of lead , combined with injunctions against lead use in household products and other factors has caused most major paint makers to discontinue the production of Maroger 's medium .
These products produce effects similar to , but not the same as those of real Maroger medium , which depends on specific chemical reactions between leaded oil , mastic resin , and turpentine ( the mastic varnish vehicle ) .
Joseph Harold Greenberg ( May 28 , 1915 -- May 7 , 2001 ) was a prominent American linguist , principally known for Joseph Greenberg work in two areas , linguistic typology and the genetic classification of languages .
These were interrupted by service in the U.S. Army Signal Corps during World War II , where Joseph Greenberg worked as a codebreaker and participated in the landing at Casablanca .
Joseph Greenberg argued that genetic classification is methodologically prior to comparative reconstruction , or the first stage of it : you can not engage in the comparative reconstruction of languages until you know which languages to compare ( 1957:44 ) .
Borrowing , when it occurs , is concentrated in cultural vocabulary and clusters `` in certain semantic areas '' , making it easy to detect ( 1957:39 ) .
Greenberg 's work on African languages has been criticised by Lyle Campbell and Donald Ringe , who do not believe that Joseph Greenberg classification is justified by Joseph Greenberg data ; they request a reexamination of Joseph Greenberg macro-phyla by `` reliable methods '' ( Ringe 1993:104 ) .
In particular , Edgar Gregersen ( 1972 ) proposed joining Niger -- Congo and Nilo-Saharan into a larger family , which Joseph Greenberg termed Kongo-Saharan .
But , the work of Stephen Wurm ( 1982 ) and Malcolm Ross ( 2005 ) has provided considerable support for Joseph Greenberg once-radical idea that these languages form a single genetic unit .
Wurm stated that the lexical similarities between Great Andamanese and the West Papuan and Timor -- Alor families `` are quite striking and amount to virtual formal identity ... in a number of instances '' .
In Joseph Greenberg 1987 book Language in the Americas , while supporting the Eskimo -- Aleut and Na-Dené groupings as distinct , Joseph Greenberg proposed that all the other Native American languages belong to a single language macro-family , which Joseph Greenberg termed Amerind .
All three editions simultaneously published at The Hague by Mouton & Co. ) ( Reprinted 1980 and , with a foreword by Martin Haspelmath , 2005 .
During the short reigns of the older two of Alfred the Great three elder brothers , Æthelbald of Wessex and Æthelberht of Wessex , Alfred is not mentioned .
This was in accordance with the agreement that Æthelred and Alfred the Great had made earlier that year in an assembly at Swinbeorg .
While Alfred the Great was busy with the burial ceremonies for Alfred the Great brother , the Danes defeated the English in Alfred the Great absence at an unnamed spot , and then again in Alfred the Great presence at Wilton in May .
Bishop Asser claimed that the ` pagans ' agreed to vacate the realm and made good their promise ; and , indeed , the Viking army did withdraw from Reading in the autumn of 871 to take up winter quarters in Mercian London .
Although not mentioned by Asser or by the Anglo-Saxon Chronicle , Alfred the Great probably also paid the Vikings cash to leave , much as the Mercians were to do in the following year .
Hoards dating to the Viking occupation of London in 871/2 have been excavated at Croydon , Gravesend , and Waterloo Bridge ; these finds hint at the cost involved in making peace with the Vikings .
Accordingly , Alfred the Great negotiated a peace which involved an exchange of hostages and oaths , which the Danes swore on a `` holy ring '' associated with the worship of Thor .
The disposition of Essex , held by West Saxon kings since the days of Egbert , is unclear from the treaty , though , given Alfred 's political and military superiority , it would have been surprising if Alfred the Great had conceded any disputed territory to Alfred the Great new godson .
With the signing of the Treaty of Alfred the Great and Guthrum , an event most commonly held to have taken place around 880 when Guthrum 's people began settling East Anglia , Guthrum was neutralised as a threat .
In the year 883 , though there is some debate over the year , King Alfred , because of Alfred the Great support and Alfred the Great donation of alms to Rome , received a number of gifts from the Pope Marinus .
Between the restoration of London and the resumption of large scale Danish attacks in the early 890s , Alfred the Great reign was rather uneventful .
Alfred , in 893 or 894 , took up a position from which Alfred the Great could observe both forces .
This calculates to a total of 27,071 soldiers needed system wide , or approximately one in four of all the free men in Wessex .
This justified the heavy demands Alfred the Great made upon Alfred the Great subjects ' labour and finances .
Characteristically , all of Alfred the Great innovations were firmly rooted in traditional West Saxon practice , drawing as they did upon the three so-called ` common burdens ' of bridge work , fortress repair and service on Alfred the Great campaigns that all holders of bookland and royal loanland owed the Crown .
The landowners attached to Wallingford , for example , were responsible for producing and feeding 2,400 men , the number sufficient for maintaining 9900 ft of wall .
The shires of Wessex went back at least to the reign of King Ine , who probably also imposed a hidage assessment upon each for food rents and other services owed the Crown .
Alfred singled out in particular the laws that Alfred the Great `` found in the days of Ine , Alfred the Great kinsman , or Offa , king of the Mercians , or King Æthelbert of Kent , who first among the English people received baptism '' .
Alfred the Great appended rather than integrated the laws of Ine into Alfred the Great code , and although Alfred the Great included , as had Æthelbert , a scale of payments in compensation for injuries to various body parts , the two injury tariffs are not aligned .
Alfred , according to Asser , insisted upon reviewing contested judgments made by Alfred the Great ealdormen and reeves , and `` would carefully look into nearly all the judgements which were passed issued in Alfred the Great absence anywhere in the realm , to see whether they were just or unjust '' .
Later in the reign the North Welsh followed their example , and the latter cooperated with the English in the campaign of 893 ( or 894 ) .
In the 880s , at the same time that Alfred the Great was `` cajoling and threatening '' Alfred the Great nobles to build and man the burhs , Alfred , perhaps inspired by the example of Charlemagne almost a century before , undertook an equally ambitious effort to revive learning .
As king Alfred the Great saw Alfred the Great as responsible for both the temporal and spiritual welfare of Alfred the Great subjects .
Alfred the Great was equally comfortable distributing Alfred the Great translation of Gregory the Great 's Pastoral Care to Alfred the Great bishops so that they might better train and supervise priests , and using those same bishops as royal officials and judges .
Apart from the lost Handboc or Encheiridion , which seems to have been a commonplace book kept by the king , the earliest work to be translated was the Dialogues of Gregory the Great , a book greatly popular in the Middle Ages .
Although Alfred the Great described Alfred the Great method as translating `` sometimes word for word , sometimes sense for sense , '' Alfred 's translation actually keeps very close to Alfred the Great original , although through Alfred the Great choice of language Alfred the Great blurred throughout the distinction between spiritual and secular authority .
Unlike Alfred the Great translation of the Pastoral Care , Alfred here deals very freely with Alfred the Great original and though the late Dr. G. Schepss showed that many of the additions to the text are to be traced not to Alfred Alfred the Great , but to the glosses and commentaries which Alfred the Great used , still there is much in the work which is solely Alfred 's and highly characteristic of Alfred the Great style .
It is in the Boethius that the oft-quoted sentence occurs : `` Alfred the Great will was to live worthily as long as Alfred the Great lived , and after Alfred the Great life to leave to them that should come after , Alfred the Great memory in good works '' .
Restoring religion and learning in Wessex , Abels contends , was to Alfred 's mind as essential to the defence of Alfred the Great realm as the building of the burhs .
The pursuit of wisdom , Alfred the Great assured Alfred the Great readers of the Boethius , was the surest path to power : `` Study Wisdom , then , and , when you have learned it , condemn it not , for Alfred the Great tell you that by its means you may without fail attain to power , yea , even though not desiring it '' .
The need to persuade Alfred the Great nobles to undertake work for the ` common good ' led Alfred and Alfred the Great court scholars to strengthen and deepen the conception of Christian kingship that Alfred the Great had inherited by building upon the legacy of earlier kings such as Offa as well as clerical writers such as Bede , Alcuin and the other luminaries of the Carolingian renaissance .
If the Christian faith fell into ruin in Alfred the Great kingdom , if the clergy were too ignorant to understand the Latin words they butchered in their offices and liturgies , if the ancient monasteries and collegiate churches lay deserted out of indifference , Alfred the Great was answerable before God , as Josiah had been .
Asser , in Alfred the Great Life of King Alfred , wrote of Alfred the Great , `` Alfred the Great was loved by Alfred the Great father and mother , and even by all the people , above all Alfred the Great brothers , and was educated altogether at the court of the king .
Alfred the Great noble nature implanted in him from Alfred the Great cradle a love of wisdom above all things ; but , with shame be it spoken , by the unworthy neglect of Alfred the Great parents and nurses , Alfred the Great remained illiterate even till Alfred the Great was twelve years old or more ; but , Alfred the Great listened with serious attention to the Saxon poems which Alfred the Great often heard recited , and easily retained them in Alfred the Great docile memory .
How Alfred the Great died is unknown , although Alfred the Great suffered throughout Alfred the Great life with a painful and unpleasant illness -- possibly Crohn 's disease , which seems to have been inherited by Alfred the Great grandson King Edred .
In 1999 , bones excavated in Winchester and thought to be those of Alfred the Great proved to be those of an elderly woman .
By the time of the Reformation Alfred was seen as being a pious Christian ruler , who promoted the use of English rather than Latin , and so the translations that Alfred the Great commissioned were viewed as untainted by the later Roman Catholic influences of the Normans .
Van Goyen was an extremely prolific artist ; approximately twelve hundred paintings and more than one thousand drawings by Jan van Goyen are known .
Other popular Dutch landscape painters of the sixteenth and seventeenth century were Jacob van Ruisdael , Aelbert Cuyp , Hendrick Avercamp , Ludolf Backhuysen , Meindert Hobbema , Aert van der Neer .
Justin Martyr grandfather , Bacchius , had a Greek name , while Justin Martyr father , Priscus , bore a Latin name , which has led to speculations that Justin Martyr ancestors may have settled in Neapolis soon after its establishment or that they were descended from a Roman ` diplomatic ' community that had been sent there .
In the reign of Marcus Aurelius , after disputing with the cynic philosopher Crescens , Justin Martyr was denounced by the latter to the authorities , according to Tatian ( Address to the Greeks 19 ) and Eusebius ( HE IV 16.7-8 ) .
In 1882 Pope Leo XIII had a Mass and an Office composed for Justin Martyr feast day , which Justin Martyr set at 14 April , one day after the date of Justin Martyr death as indicated in the Martyrology of Florus ; but since this date quite often falls within the main Paschal celebrations , the feast was moved in 1968 to 1 June , the date on which Justin Martyr has been celebrated in the Byzantine Rite since at least the 9th century .
The earliest mention of Justin is found in the Oratio ad Graecos by Tatian who , after calling Justin Martyr `` the most admirable Justin , '' quotes a saying of Justin Martyr and says that the Cynic Crescens laid snares for him.Eusebius implies that other works were in circulation ; from St Irenaeus Justin Martyr knows of the apology `` Against Marcion , '' and from Justin 's `` Apology '' of a `` Refutation of all Heresies '' .
The extant work under the title `` On the Sovereignty of God '' does not correspond with Eusebius ' description of it , though Harnack regards it as still possibly Justin 's , and at least of the 2nd century .
The author of the smaller treatise To the Greeks can not be Justin , because Justin Martyr is dependent on Tatian ; Harnack places it between 180 and 240 .
The fragments of the work `` On the Resurrection '' begin with the assertion that the truth , and God the author of truth , need no witness , but that as a concession to the weakness of men it is necessary to give arguments to convince those who gainsay it .
The Against Marcion is lost , as is the Refutation of all Heresies to which Justin Justin Martyr refers in Apology , i. 26 ; Hegesippus , besides perhaps Irenaeus and Tertullian , seems to have used it .
Justin Martyr aim , of course , is to emphasize the absolute significance of Christ , so that all that ever existed of virtue and truth may be referred to Justin Martyr .
The old philosophers and law-givers had only a part of the Logos , while the whole appears in Christ .
The law , however , while containing commandments intended to promote the true fear of God , had other prescriptions of a purely pedagogic nature , which necessarily ceased when Christ , their end , appeared ; of such temporary and merely relative regulations were circumcision , animal sacrifices , the Sabbath , and the laws as to food .
In Justin Martyr character as the teacher of the new doctrine and promulgator of the new law lies the essential nature of Justin Martyr redeeming work .
It is noteworthy that in the `` Dialogue '' Justin Martyr no longer speaks of a `` seed of the Word '' in every man , and in Justin Martyr non-apologetic works the emphasis is laid upon the redeeming acts of the life of Christ rather than upon the demonstration of the reasonableness and moral value of Christianity , though the fragmentary character of the latter works makes it difficult to determine exactly to what extent this is true and how far the teaching of Irenaeus on redemption is derived from Justin Martyr .
Specific points Justin addressed include that the Logos is `` numerically distinct from the Father '' though `` born of the very substance of the Father '' , and that through the `` through the Word , God has made everything '' .
Justin Martyr , in Justin Martyr First Apology ( ca. 155 ) and Dialogue with Trypho ( ca. 160 ) , sometimes refers to written sources consisting of narratives of the life of Jesus and quotations of the sayings of Jesus as `` memoirs of the apostles '' ( Greek : ἀπομνημονεύματα τῶν ἀποστόλων ; transliteration : apomnêmoneúmata tôn apostólôn ) and less frequently as gospels ( Greek : εὐαγγέλιον ; transliteration : euangélion ) which , Justin says , were read every Sunday in the church at Rome ( 1 Apol .
The designation `` memoirs of the apostles '' occurs twice in Justin 's First Apology ( 66.3 , 67.3 -- 4 ) and thirteen times in the Dialogue , mostly in Justin Martyr interpretation of Psalm 22 , whereas the term `` gospel '' is used only three times , once in 1 Apol .
Justin may have preferred the designation `` memoirs of the apostles '' as a contrast to the `` gospel '' of Justin Martyr contemporary Marcion to emphasize the connections between the historical testimony of the gospels and the Old Testament prophecies which Marcion rejected .
However , Justin Martyr use , or even knowledge , of the Gospel of John is uncertain .
Scholar Brooke Westcott notes that this reference to the author of the single prophetic book of the New Testament illustrates the distinction Justin made between the role of prophecy and fulfillment quotations from the gospels , as Justin does not mention any of the individual canonical gospels by name .
33:4 -5 ) According to Skarsaune , the harmonized gospel narratives of Matthew and Luke were part of a tradition already circulating within Justin 's school that expounded on the life and work of Jesus as the Messiah and the apostolic mission .
31-53 ) is believed to have had a Two Parousias Christology , characterized by the belief that Jesus first came in humility , in fulfillment of prophecy , and will return in glory as the Messiah to the Gentiles .
`` And then , when Jesus had come to the river Jordan where John was baptizing , and when Jesus came down into the water , a fire was even kindled in the Jordan , and when Justin Martyr was rising up from the water , the Holy Spirit fluttered down upon Justin Martyr in the form of a dove , as the apostles have written about this very Christ of ours '' .
This indicated that Justin Martyr had a compound name made up of the actions which Justin Martyr performed ; for the word `` Sata '' in the Hebrew and Syrian tongue means `` apostate '' , while `` nas '' is the word which means in translation `` serpent '' , thus , from both parts is formed the one word `` Sata-nas '' .
The harmonization of Matthew and Luke is evident in the following quotations of Mt 7:22 -23 and Lk 13:26 -27 , which are used by Justin twice , in 1 Apol .
In both cases , Justin is using the same harmonized text of Matthew and Luke , although neither of the quotations includes the entire text of those gospel passages .
And those events which have happened , and those which are happening , compel you to assent to the utterances made by them ' '' .
Daniel 's `` time , times , and a half '' , Justin believed , was nearing its consummation , when Antichrist would speak Justin Martyr blasphemies against the Most High .
Halton , TP and M Slusser , eds , Dialogue with Trypho , trans TB Falls , Selections from the Fathers of the Church , 3 , ( Washington , DC : Catholic University of America Press ) .
Johann Tetzel acquired the degree of Licentiate of Sacred Theology in the University of Frankfurt an der Oder , 1517 , and that of Doctor of Sacred Theology , 1518 , by defending , in two disputations , the doctrine of indulgences against Luther .
When Johann Tetzel discovered that Karl von Miltitz had accused Johann Tetzel of perpetrating numerous frauds and embezzlements , Johann Tetzel withdrew , broken in spirit , wrecked in health , into the Dominican monastery in Leipzig .
James Tiptree, Jr. was most notable for breaking down the barriers between writing perceived as inherently `` male '' or `` female '' -- it was not publicly known until 1977 that James Tiptree , Jr. was a woman .
James Tiptree, Jr. was a graphic artist and a painter , and -- under the name `` Alice Bradley Davey '' -- an art critic for the Chicago Sun between 1941 and 1942 .
James Tiptree, Jr. met and married William Davey , James Tiptree, Jr. first husband , at age 19 because James Tiptree, Jr. felt as if it was James Tiptree, Jr. duty as a daughter .
In 1945 James Tiptree, Jr. married James Tiptree, Jr. second husband , Huntington D Sheldon , at the close of the war on James Tiptree, Jr. assignment in Paris and James Tiptree, Jr. was discharged from the military in 1946 , at which time James Tiptree, Jr. set up a small business in partnership with James Tiptree, Jr. husband .
`` James Tiptree, Jr. like some men a lot , but from the start , before James Tiptree, Jr. knew anything , it was always girls and women who lit James Tiptree, Jr. up '' .
`` Tiptree '' never made any public appearances , but James Tiptree, Jr. did correspond regularly with fans and other science fiction authors through the mail .
One well-known name , Tiptree , assisted Sheldon in conveying feministic themes and beliefs to James Tiptree, Jr. audience .
John Clute , noting Tiptree 's `` inconsolable complexities of vision '' , concluded that `` It is very rarely that a James Tiptree, Jr. story does not both deal directly with death and end with a death of the spirit , or of all hope , or of the race '' .
Notable stories of this type include `` Painwise '' , in which a space explorer has been altered to be immune to pain but finds such an existence intolerable , and `` A Momentary Taste of Being '' , in which the true purpose of humanity , found on a distant planet , renders individual human life entirely pointless .
Another major theme is the tension between free will and biological determinism , or reason and sexual desire .
Japanese-language translations of James Tiptree, Jr. fiction also won two Hayakawa Awards and three Seiun Awards as the year 's best under changing designations ( foreign , overseas , translated ) .
By choosing a masculine nom de plume , having her stories accepted under that name and winning awards with them , Sheldon helped demonstrate that the division between male and female science fiction writing was illusory .
To remind audiences of the role gender plays in both reading and writing , James Tiptree, Jr. Award was named in Sheldon 's honor at the suggestion of Karen Joy Fowler .
Juventus Football Club S.p.A. ( from Latin iuventus : youth , pronounced ) , commonly referred to as Juventus F.C. and colloquially as Juve ( pronounced ) , are a professional Italian association football club based in Turin , Piedmont .
The club added two more league championships to Juventus F.C. name in the 1949 -- 50 and 1951 -- 52 seasons , the latter of which was under the management of Englishman Jesse Carver .
This meant Juventus F.C. had won 20 Italian league titles and were allowed to add a second golden star to their shirt , thus becoming Juventus F.C. to achieve this .
Frenchman Michel Platini was also awarded the European Footballer of the Year title for three years in a row ; 1983 , 1984 and 1985 , which is a record .
As well as having to contend with Diego Maradona 's Napoli , both of the Milanese clubs , Milan and Internazionale , won Italian championships .
Former player and fan favourite Antonio Conte , fresh after winning promotion with Siena , was named as Delneri 's replacement .
He had a friend who lived in Nottingham , who being a Notts County supporter , shipped out the black and white striped shirts to Turin .
The old French shield and the mural crown , also in the lower section of the emblem , had a considerably greater size with respect to the present .
During the 1980s , the club emblem was the silhouette of a zebra , to both sides of the equide 's head , the two golden stars and , above this badge , forming an arc , Juventus F.C. name .
After the first two years ( 1897 and 1898 ) , during which Juventus F.C. played in the Parco del Valentino and Parco Cittadella , their matches were held in the Piazza d'Armi Stadium until 1908 , except in 1905 , the first year of the scudetto , and in 1906 , years in which it played at the Corso Re Umberto .
Up until the Calciopoli scandal which saw Juventus F.C. forcibly relegated , the two were the only Italian clubs to have never played below Serie A. Notably the two sides are the first and the second most supported clubs in Italy and the rivalry has intensified since the later part of the 1990s ; reaching its highest levels ever post-Calciopoli , with the return of Juventus F.C. to Serie A .
Stelle d'oro al Merito Sportivo ) on Juventus F.C. shirts representing Juventus F.C. league victories , the tenth of which was achieved during the 1957 -- 58 season and the twentieth in the 1981 -- 82 season .
Juventus F.C. have been proclaimed World 's Club Team of the Year twice ( 1993 and 1996 ) and was ranked in 3rd place -- the highest ranking of any Italian club -- in the All-Time Club World Ranking ( 1991 -- 2009 period ) by the International Federation of Football History & Statistics .
società per azioni ) and since 3 December 2001 the torinese side is listed on the Borsa Italiana .
As of 2011 , the Juventus ' shares are distributed between 60 % to Exor S.p.A , the Agnelli family 's holding ( a company of the Giovanni Agnelli & C.S.a.p.a Group ) , 7.5 % to Libyan Arab Foreign Investment Co. and 32.5 % to other shareholders .
From 1 July 2008 Juventus F.C. has implemented a Safety Management System for employees and athletes in compliance with the requirements of international OHSAS 18001:2007 regulation and a Safety Management System in the medical sector according to the international resolution .
Currently , Juventus F.C. is also ranked 9th on Forbes ' list of the most valuable football clubs in the world , making them the second association football club richest in Italy and , overall , one of the top 50 sporting teams at worldwide level in terms of value .
The team made an aggregate net loss in the following seasons ( 2006 to date ) : - $ 927,569 ( 2006 -- 07 ) , - $ 20,787,469 ( 2007 -- 08 ) , net income $ 6,582,489 ( 2008 -- 09 ) and net loss $ 10,967,944 ( 2009 -- 10 ) After an unaudited $ 43,411,481 net loss was recorded in the first 9 months of 2010 -- 11 season , the BoD announced that a capital increase of $ 120 million was planned , scheduled to submit to the extraordinary shareholder 's meeting in October .
